My main tip is make sure you invest in a good tour guide (especially if not local - the foreigners feel more comfortable to talk about the local reality).

Having said that, it's a terrible place to work from if you need internet (like most people, right!?). Regardless where you are staying (hotels or "casa de familia", which is kind of an airbnb w/ a family, a great option to live the local culture), you need to buy a "pre-paid" internet card and find places where the internet connection actually works. It's usually better in hotels, but if you are in a different place, you will need to find a park or another public space with a strong reception. I was working on a project while there, and thankfully most of what I did was offline. Every time I needed to send an update of my project, I had to walk to a nearby park with my computer to get an "ok" reception (depending on the time of the day; in the evening, you see a lot of people in the park with their phones - forget about using the internet!)

Food is also a problem. Most of restaurants that look nice have a terrible food, and googling for options while you are walking around is impossible (internet is hard to connect, remember?). Do your homework beforehand, and always have a good map pinpointing restaurants and places to visit.

Still worth visiting. The history there is unique - I agree there are better cities in Latin America, but none is that singular. Also, the locals will try to get your money - but this is also the case in many other places in the world (and Havana is not worse than Bangkok, I promise!) You don't need to stay long, just a few days (3-4) is more than enough. Also, don't bother visiting the all inclusive resorts in the country - go somewhere else in the Caribbean (the views will as amazing as in Cuba + the food and drinks will be better)

I can't comprehend why Havana is rated so well here. I couldn't walk anywhere near the center of the city without being constantly hounded to buy something, go to a restaurant, or take a "taxi" in some random car or bicycle cab. The reason is that Cubans have no disposable income because they receive everything from the government, so they are desperate for money to travel or buy something unusual. I never interacted with a single local who wasn't hustling me for cash.

Definitely avoid this place if you're American. Your smartphone's internet and Google Maps don't work here, and Uber etc is nonexistent. American debit and credit cards are forbidden. Air pollution is quite bad due to all of the old cars and vehicles. It really is like stepping back to the 1950's, except in a developing country.

There are far better cities in Latin America. I liked even Santo Domingo far better than Havana. It at least had one or two clean neighborhoods with modern amenities, with far less people hassling you for money.
havana.description:
Havana is a city that is different from others, with lively culture, nice streets, and a special feeling that seems like going back in time. Imagine this: classic American cars passing by old colonial buildings, and everywhere you look, there is colorful art and the sound of music in the air. The people are friendly, always willing to share a smile and a story, but knowing some Spanish can help you talk with them.

While the atmosphere is great, there are some difficulties you should know about. The internet can be unreliable, which can be hard if you need to work or stream videos. Also, finding good food can be a bit tricky, as choices are limited and may not always taste good. It is important to have cash on hand for your transactions.

For visitors, areas like Old Havana are important to see because of their history. Just remember, the infrastructure is not always good—power outages can happen and public transportation is limited. But if you can accept these issues, you will find a city full of great experiences!
havana.description_kor:
하바나는 다른 도시들과는 차별화된 매력을 지닌 곳입니다. 생동감 넘치는 문화와 아름다운 거리들, 그리고 마치 시간여행을 하는 듯한 특별한 감각이 절묘하게 어우러져 있습니다. 여러분이 상상해보세요: 클래식 미국 자동차들이 오래된 식민지 시대 건물 옆을 유유히 지나가고, 어디를 가든 화려한 예술 작품과 음악 소리가 가득합니다. 사람들은 매우 친절하며, 언제나 미소를 지으며 이야기를 나누고 싶어 합니다. 스페인어를 조금 익혀두면 이들과 소통하는 데 큰 도움이 될 거예요.

분위기는 정말 훌륭하지만, 몇 가지 주의할 점도 있습니다. 인터넷이 불안정할 수 있어 업무를 보거나 비디오를 스트리밍할 때 어려움을 겪을 수 있습니다. 그리고 맛있는 음식을 찾는 일이 때로는 번거로울 수 있습니다. 선택의 폭이 좁아서 항상 맛보장을 할 수는 없기 때문이죠. 거래를 위해 현금을 준비하는 것도 잊지 마세요.

방문객에게는 올드 하바나와 같은 역사적인 장소는 꼭 들러봐야 할 곳입니다. 하지만 인프라가 항상 완벽한 것은 아니라는 점을 염두에 두세요. 정전이 발생할 수도 있고, 대중교통은 다소 제한적입니다. 그럼에도 불구하고 이러한 점들을 감수할 수 있다면, 여러분은 정말 멋진 경험을 선사하는 도시를 발견하게 될 것입니다!

reviews: Surprisingly green an pleasant city with all the ancient parks and strolls around the west lake area.
As one of the most livable cities in China, Hangzhou has developed economy and technology, many tourist attractions, an open and inclusive city!
hangzhou.description:
Hangzhou is a city that many find surprising because of its green areas and enjoyable parks, especially around West Lake. Visitors like the calm walks you can take, surrounded by old trees and historic places, making it a nice break from the busy city life. The city is often seen as one of the best places to live in China because it combines modern buildings with traditional culture.

However, like any city, it has its problems. Some people think the cost of living is high, and the public transport options are not as many as in larger cities. Language can also be a challenge, so knowing a few Chinese phrases might be helpful.

When you are exploring, don’t miss the Tea Plantations or the busy streets in the downtown area—there’s a lot to see! For a real local experience, try to visit during a festival; the events here are lively and welcoming. Overall, Hangzhou is a good mix of nature and culture that you should see!
hangzhou.description_kor:
항저우는 많은 이들에게 매력적인 도시로, 특히 서호 주변의 아름다운 자연과 다양한 공원들로 유명합니다. 방문객들은 오래된 나무와 역사적인 장소들로 둘러싸인 고요한 산책을 즐기며, 바쁜 도시 생활에서 벗어나 여유로운 시간을 보낼 수 있습니다. 이 도시는 현대적인 건축물과 전통 문화가 조화롭게 어우러져 있어 중국에서 가장 살기 좋은 곳 중 하나로 손꼽히곤 합니다.

하지만 어떤 도시가 그렇듯, 단점도 존재합니다. 일부 사람들은 생활비가 비쌉니다고 느끼며, 대중교통의 선택이 대도시에 비해 부족하다고 생각할 수 있습니다. 또한, 언어 장벽이 있을 수 있으므로 기본적인 중국어 문구를 알아두면 큰 도움이 될 것입니다.

항저우를 탐방할 때는 차 재배지나 중심가의 활기찬 거리를 꼭 놓치지 마세요—볼거리가 정말 많습니다! 진정한 지역 문화를 체험하고 싶으시다면 축제 기간에 방문해보세요; 이곳의 행사들은 생동감 넘치고 환영받는 분위기로 가득 차 있습니다. 전반적으로, 항저우는 자연과 문화가 조화롭게 어우러진 곳으로 꼭 한 번 가보시길 추천합니다!

reviews: I've been here just under a week so it might be too early to comment on Helsinki, but so far I like it. I'd like to second what the review from 9 mths ago said: I can recommend Noli Studios, specifically the Herttoniemi one. I'll tell you more about Finland once I've been here longer.

Helsinki, FInland, for one week in late July 2023. Short story: I would go there again in a heartbeat. Its safe, fun, trendy. It has great public transit in the core and to the airport, and is REALLY pedestrian friendly. English is readily spoken in the downtown core. Food from local and worldwide tastes is available and I did not have a single bad meal there. Check the opening/closing times for restaurants and bars- they vary wildly (Google maps is good for this, but not infallible). Internet was fast at my Hotel (Hotel Anna). I did not use co-working spaces. Nature is close by with a ferry cruise to local islands, and Estonia is a fast 3 hour boat ride away. Everyone was friendly to me, even though I knew none of the local official languages (Finnish and Swedish). Of course, YMMV but I had a great time as a solo traveller. Check the weather chart for your time of travel.

I've been in Helsinki on New Year's Eve and it's been okay. There isn't lots of fireworks but in front of the main cathedral you'll find some. Cafe-scene is great and you also find lots of places to work from. The city is walkable, although I wouldn't recommend doing that in winter as it'll be freaking cold. 

Surprisingly you can find lots of vegan options. No matter if you're in a super-market (I can tell you, I've never seen so many different replacement products) or in a cafe. It's way better than other Scandinavian cities such aus Lund, Copenhagen and so on. 

All in all I think it's worth a visit but wouldn't stay here for longer or come back, too often. 
Pros:
- great public transport
- lots of vegan options
- great cafe-scene
- suprisingly friendly people (I always heard that Finnish people are rude, but it's not true from my experience)

Cons:
- super expensive (especially alcohol and eating out)
- cold AF in winter
- not too many things to do

If you want to have a great place to stay, meet people and be able to work, I can recommend Noli Studios. I stayed in Noli Sörnäinen with my girlfriend and enjoyed the place. Also has pretty good connections to almost anywhere in Helsinki.

A lot more things to do there on Summer than on Winter, even though the city is beautiful both seasons. Wouldn't recommend going there in the beginning of spring or late autumn since it'd be mostly rainy and cold. On Summer I recommend just walking around the city and checking out all the architecture and drinking beer on the beach of Hietalahti or taking a ferry to Suomenlinna and having a picnic day there. Linnanmäki amusement park is also nice if you are traveling with children. On Winter I recommend you leave the city center and go to f.ex. Mustikkamaa or Central Park. There are places where you can ice skate.
helsinki.description:
Helsinki is a busy city that combines a rich culture with interesting buildings and friendly people. Visitors like its walkable streets and good public transportation, which makes it easy to see the city and take a ferry to nearby islands. The café scene is active, with many comfortable places to relax or work—and for vegans, there are many options!

One thing to keep in mind is that the cost of living can be high, especially for eating out or having a drink. While the city might feel a bit quieter in the winter months, summer is a great time to walk around, enjoy the waterfront, or go to Linnanmäki amusement park if you have children.

However, be ready for some very cold winters! English is spoken by many people, so communication should be easy, but you might find some language barriers outside the main areas. Overall, Helsinki is worth a visit, but plan your trip carefully to enjoy its unique experiences!
helsinki.description_kor:
헬싱키는 풍부한 문화와 매력적인 건축물, 그리고 친절한 사람들로 가득한 활기찬 도시입니다. 방문객들은 보행자 친화적인 거리와 편리한 대중교통 덕분에 쉽게 도시를 돌아다닐 수 있으며, 근처 섬으로 가는 페리도 쉽게 이용할 수 있습니다. 카페 문화가 발달해 있어 편안하게 쉬거나 작업하기에 좋은 공간이 많고, 비건을 위한 다양한 식사 옵션도 마련되어 있습니다!

한 가지 주의할 점은 생계비가 특히 외식이나 음료를 즐길 때 조금 높을 수 있다는 것입니다. 겨울철에는 도시가 다소 고요하게 느껴질 수 있지만, 여름에 방문하면 도시를 탐방하고 해변을 즐기며 아이들과 린난막키 놀이공원에 가기에 좋은 시점입니다.

아울러, 매우 추운 겨울을 대비해야 합니다! 많은 사람들이 영어를 사용하므로 의사소통에는 큰 문제가 없겠지만, 주요 지역을 벗어나면 언어 장벽을 느낄 수도 있습니다. 전반적으로 헬싱키는 방문할 가치가 있는 곳이며, 그 독특한 경험을 만끽하기 위해 신중하게 여행 계획을 세우는 것이 좋습니다!

reviews:
Aloha!

I am a DN stationed in Honolulu, Hawai’i, and I recommend the Kuhio Banyan Club for those wishing to stay longer. It is centrally located in Waikiki, on Kuhio Ave.

I also recommend buying the week pass for the Trolley Hawai’i because it has four lines, and although it works as a hop-on/hop-off tourist thing, it is very useful to get to the main places within the Central/ South Shores of O’ahu. Also, as they hire local drivers ( natives), you help the local community. Tip: Take the Blue Line, get out at Sea Life Park, and walk to Makapu’u Beach. It is a beach frequented by locals, so you will be off the beaten track. Return to Waikiki with The Bus ( local city bus).

Groceries: choose the ABC Store. They are everywhere on the island!!

Aloha Mai!
honolulu.description:
If you’re thinking about Honolulu, you will enjoy your time there. This city is all about the Aloha spirit, and you’ll feel it as soon as you arrive. To see local life, the Kuhio Banyan Club in Waikiki is a good option for longer stays. It’s very convenient and makes it easy to explore!

Getting around is easy with the Trolley Hawai’i. A week pass is a good choice, and the local drivers are friendly—you're supporting the community while you ride! For a different experience, visit Makapu’u Beach after going to Sea Life Park via the Blue Line. This place is popular with locals and a nice break from tourist areas.

For practicality, grocery shopping is simple at the ABC Stores found across the island. While Honolulu is nice, be aware of the high cost of living and some language issues, especially if you’re trying to use Hawaiian phrases. But don’t worry, the friendly locals are always ready to help! Get ready for beach days, interesting culture, and beautiful sunsets!
honolulu.description_kor:
호놀룰루를 생각하고 계신다면, 그곳에서의 시간을 충분히 즐길 수 있을 거예요. 이 도시는 알로하 정신이 넘쳐나며, 도착하자마자 그 분위기를 느낄 수 있습니다. 현지 생활을 경험하고 싶으신 분이라면, 와이키키의 쿠히오 바냐 클럽이 장기 체류에 아주 좋은 선택이에요. 매우 편리하고 탐방하기도 수월하답니다!

Trolley Hawai’i를 이용하면 이동이 편리해요. 주간 패스를 이용해보는 것도 좋은 선택일 것 같고, 친절한 현지 기사분들이 계셔서 탑승하는 동안 지역 사회를 지원하고 있다는 사실도 기쁩니다! 특별한 경험을 원하신다면 블루 라인을 타고 시 생명 공원에 가신 후, 마카푸우 해변을 방문해보세요. 이곳은 현지인들에게 인기 있는 장소로, 관광객들로부터 벗어나기 좋은 곳이죠.

그리고 실용적인 팁 하나! 섬 곳곳에 있는 ABC 매장에서 장보는 것은 아주 간단해요. 호놀룰루는 매력적인 도시이지만 생활비가 조금 높은 편이라는 점과 하와이어에 약간의 언어 장벽이 있을 수 있다는 점도 함께 기억해 두세요. 하지만 걱정 마세요! 친절한 현지인들이 항상 도움을 줄 준비가 되어 있으니까요. 해변에서의 여유로운 나날, 흥미로운 문화, 아름다운 일몰을 기대해보세요!

reviews: In it's current iteration, Houston is a wide-spread, vehicle dependent city and would be a difficult place to exist as a Nomad without a vehicle. Downtown Houston was once a desolate cluster of office buildings that was abandoned at sundown. But now, downtown is currently undergoing a transformation and will soon (5~ years) make for an inhabitable and nomad friendly destination.
houston.description:
Houston is a busy city that has its own appeal, but like most big cities, having a car is almost necessary to get around. Some areas of the city may feel a bit spread out, but the downtown area is changing. What used to be a quiet mix of office buildings at night is now filled with new life and activity. This change is interesting to see.

One thing to keep in mind is that Houston's cost of living can vary—some people find it affordable, while others may think some prices are high. Public transport is not as extensive as in some other places, so having a vehicle will make things easier.

In terms of cultural experiences, Houston has a mix of flavors, traditions, and neighborhoods to explore. As you walk around, you'll find local customs that reflect its diverse community.

So, if you're planning a visit, remember to drive and notice the changes happening in the downtown area. Get ready for a mix of modern and traditional in Texas!
houston.description_kor:
휴스턴은 독특한 매력을 가진 바쁜 도시로, 다른 대도시와 마찬가지로 이동 수단으로 차가 대부분 필수입니다. 도시의 일부 지역은 널찍하게 펼쳐져 있는 느낌이 있지만, 다운타운은 변화의 흐름을 따라 새롭게 변화하고 있습니다. 한때 조용했던 사무실 건물이 이제는 활기찬 공간으로 바뀌어, 생명력과 에너지로 가득 차게 되었습니다. 이러한 변화는 관찰하는 재미를 선사합니다.

또한, 휴스턴의 생활비는 다양하게 형성되어 있다는 점도 기억해야 합니다. 어떤 이들은 생활비가 저렴하다고 느끼기도 하고, 다른 이들은 다소 비싼 편이라고 생각할 수 있습니다. 대중교통이 다른 지역만큼 발달하지 않기 때문에, 차를 소유하면 훨씬 편리하게 이동할 수 있을 것입니다.

문화적인 면에서도 휴스턴은 다양한 맛과 전통, 그리고 동네의 개성을 탐험할 수 있는 곳입니다. 거리 곳곳에서 다양한 커뮤니티의 전통과 문화를 엿볼 수 있습니다.

그러니 방문 계획이 있다면, 꼭 차량을 이용해 다운타운의 변화를 주목해 보세요. 텍사스에서 현대적인 요소와 전통이 어우러진 새로운 경험을 만날 준비를 하세요!

reviews: Cool little town to live in and work from, I was there for 3 weeks in low season. Lots of great restaurants, cafes etc. Nice easy access to the beach, riverside and countryside. Nightlife is quieter, but if you don't care about that, it's great. The Hub coworking there is run by some super friendly people and the new location they are building looks like it should be fantastic..

Such a cute little place. It reminds me of what I thought Vietnam might be. Came for fun and not to work too much. It was quiet in the afternoons and it turns into a festival by the night. Not much to do as someone mentioned. People are very friendly and nice. Lots of food and cheap drinks too. 2-4 days is sufficient here.

I stayed in Hoi An much longer than I planned (10 days) because it was so pleasant. Yes, tourists everywhere. But my hotel was gorgeous and cheap and the wifi was plenty fast for work. When not working I biked out to the beach or through the paddies or into town (too crowded for a bike most times but functional if needed) or just around the countryside. Had some of my friendliest encounters here and as a single woman, always felt safe - night or day.

Completely artificial and touristy city. The only locals you see are there to serve tourists. Gets extremely packed from afternoon to night time. Hoards of Chinese tourists. But tons of great food with many international cuisines, and still cheap to rent. So if all you care about is the comforts of home at a cheap price, maybe you’d like it, but I would never visit here for more than 2-3 days let alone be a nomad here.

I would never go here as a digital nomad. It's a tourist trap. Fun for a few romantic nights, but every closes around 10PM and people try to sell you stuff all the time. The phrase "You want to buy something" is something I remember from Hoi An. Did go there with my girlfriend on a holiday, but I would never go there as nomad. Only Ho Chi Minh/Saigon I would go to.
Loved by solo female travelers for its mellowness and safety. You can bicycle around town, do some work in the cute cafes and coworkings and meet other nomads easily.

Hoi An is awesome! My partner and I are digital nomads and love the life here. It is peaceful, yet has an active, vibrant expat community. It is home to delicious 
 food, world-class art and great people. The internet speed is 15 mbs and up and home to an awesome co-working space and great cafés. Some of those scores need to be updated! 🙏❤🙏😎
hoi-an.description:
Located in Vietnam, Hoi An is a nice little town that feels calm yet has some excitement. Think of drinking coffee in simple cafes, enjoying tasty street food, and biking easily along pleasant paths to the beach or green countryside. This town is beautiful, with views that look like a postcard, and it's a great place to relax, work, or stay for a while—many visitors decide to extend their trip!

The nightlife is relaxed but becomes lively as the sun goes down, although watch out for the crowds of tourists, especially in the afternoons! While the local food has many flavors from around the world, the language can be a little difficult, and some people feel it is too touristy. On the other hand, safety is very good—solo travelers often feel comfortable here.

Thinking about a visit? You’ll find good coworking spaces and friendly locals, but remember that most places close by 10 PM. Bring your sense of adventure, stay for a few days, and enjoy the mix of culture, food, and calm atmosphere that Hoi An offers!
hoi-an.description_kor:
베트남 호이안은 차분하면서도 약간의 흥미로움을 느낄 수 있는 아담한 도시입니다. 여기서 간단한 카페에서 커피를 즐기고, 맛있는 길거리 음식을 맛보며 해변이나 푸르른 시골로 이어지는 아늑한 길을 따라 자전거를 타는 모습을 상상해 보세요. 호이안은 엽서처럼 아름다운 풍경을 자랑하며 휴식을 취하거나 일하기, 잠시 머물기에도 좋은 곳입니다. 그래서 많은 방문객들이 여행을 연장하기로 하곤 합니다!

밤이 되면 차분한 분위기가 활기를 띠지만, 특히 오후에는 관광객들로 붐비니 주의가 필요합니다. 현지 음식은 다양한 세계의 맛을 가지고 있지만, 언어가 조금 어려울 수 있고, 일부 사람은 관광지처럼 느낄 수도 있습니다. 반면에 안전은 매우 좋고, 혼자 여행하는 사람들도 편안하게 느끼는 경우가 많습니다.

방문할 계획이신가요? 좋은 코워킹 스페이스와 친절한 지역 주민들을 만날 수 있으나, 대부분의 장소는 밤 10시쯤 닫으니 이 점을 기억하세요. 모험을 마음껏 즐기면서 며칠 동안 호이안의 문화, 음식, 그리고 차분한 분위기의 조화를 만끽해 보세요!

reviews:
Was really looking forward to Hua Hin after everything we had read. On the plus side, everything is very accessible and of course loads of high quality Thai food everywhere, mixed in with a bunch of expat options. 
Found the western-style markets and prices in general to be considerably more (in relative terms) than Bangkok. I imagine this is due to the large expat community here. Having said that, Covid has decimated the place and many expats have left. As an example, it’s Friday evening here right now (July ‘22) and both Tamarind and Cicada markets are virtually empty. 
On the down side, at least for me, there’s really not that much to do here. Particularly if you want to be somewhere where there are great beaches, at least by Australian, Caribbean or Southern Thailand standards, then think again. If you are ok with brown sand and no surf to speak of then you’ll probably like it.

I was skeptical but have really enjoyed it.

It's considered a growing 'hipster capital' of Thailand, after Chiang Mai, with its easy access to Bangkok for wealthy weekenders on breaks, and the opening of Seenspace, a massive hotel + food and drink emporium. Train to Bangkok is older and slower, but avoids traffic. There are plenty of mini-buses and taxis plying the route as well. Figure 4 hours door to door.

It's blissfully free of digital nomads (even though there is a coworking space and plenty of coffee shops) has great grocery stores, a few clean malls if you need that stuff, and some of the best seafood in Thailand. My advice is to stay south of the main strip of hotels in the quiet, and charming, Khao Takiap area or even farther south in the village of Khao Tao. 

Some nice condos/Airbnbs (monthly rental only), great walking beaches, and cheap seafood restaurants filled mostly with polite, older Euros and Thai families on vacation. Also tons of random expat owned venues like a petanque bar, or a German bakery, or Southern USA BBQ spot. 

Unlike Phuket or Pattaya the sex trafficking is not as overt. You mostly see older, beer-fattened Australians/Brits with their middle-aged Thai wives. 

Overall, highly recommended if you like Thailand but want to try something different. And can eat your weight in crab.

Scooter is a must have, as there is a taxi mafia that forces the Grab drivers to pick up in weird places (mostly 7/11 parking lots instead of in front of wherever you are).

Really amazing national park about an hour south with waterfalls, caves, cave temples, and the largest protected wetland in Thailand (tons of birds). 1. 5 hours west is a national forest/waterfall where you can still see wild elephants on the roads (not the slave labor elephants like you see in Chiang Mai).

I'd recommend coming in the 'rainy' season. By quirk of geography (mountains to the west) it gets much, much less rain than similarly located areas in the wet season.
Great place has everything you need on a smaller scale, good beaches South and Bangkok 3 hours North. Economic, hot, sunny and generally dry.

Boring town full of hotel resorts with European families. The town itself is a destination for expat retirees. Okay if you like lying by a pool for days but Hua Hin itself really has not much to offer.
hua-hin.description:
Hua Hin is a beach town in Thailand that combines local culture with some expat life. The food is good, with many Thai dishes available and options for those who want familiar food. Prices can be higher than in Bangkok because of the expat community, but it is still nice to enjoy the seafood and local markets.

The beaches here may not be as beautiful as those in Southern Thailand, so if you want perfect white sands, you might need to lower your expectations. However, many visitors like the quieter atmosphere and the chance to relax away from tourist crowds.

Getting around can be difficult; scooters are a popular choice because taxi services can be messy. If you want a nice place to stay, the Khao Takiap area is calm and has good rental options.

While Hua Hin may not have many activities, it offers a relaxed vibe that is good for people who enjoy good food and exploring nearby national parks. Just remember, it’s about enjoying the simple things here!
hua-hin.description_kor:
화양(Hua Hin)은 태국의 해변 도시로, 지역 문화와 외국인 거주지가 조화를 이루고 있습니다. 이곳의 음식은 맛이 좋고 다양한 태국 요리를 포함해 익숙한 음식을 찾는 이들을 위한 선택지도 마련되어 있습니다. 외국인 커뮤니티가 형성되어 있어 방콕보다 물가가 다소 비쌀 수 있지만, 신선한 해산물과 지역 시장을 즐기기에 적합한 곳입니다.

해변은 태국 남부의 다른 해변들보다 아름답지 않을 수 있으니, 완벽한 하얀 모래를 기대한다면 그 기대치를 조금 낮추는 게 좋을 것 같습니다. 그러나 많은 방문객들은 조용한 분위기와 관광객들로 붐비지 않는 여유로운 환경을 즐기는 것을 선호합니다.

교통은 다소 불편할 수 있는데, 택시 서비스가 복잡할 때가 있어 스쿠터가 인기 있는 교통수단으로 자리잡고 있습니다. 좋은 숙소를 원하신다면 카오 타키압(Khao Takiap) 지역이 조용하면서도 좋은 렌탈 옵션을 제공합니다.

화양은 다양한 액티비티가 많지 않을 수도 있지만, 맛있는 음식을 즐기고 인근 국립공원을 탐험하고자 하는 분들에게는 편안한 분위기를 제공합니다. 이곳에서는 간소한 즐거움을 만끽하는 것이 중요하다는 걸 기억하세요!

reviews: One of India’s top cities for tech workers
Awesome city. Hyderabad won the top place in the world's best places to live and work.
hyderabad.description:
Hyderabad is a lively city that blends modern life with traditions. It is known as a tech center, attracting many workers and companies, which creates a busy job market and good opportunities. The cost of living in the city is often seen as reasonable compared to other major Indian cities, making it easier for people to enjoy city life without spending too much.

Culturally, Hyderabad has a lot to offer. You can find tasty dishes like biryani and popular street food, along with historic sites like the Charminar and Golconda Fort. However, getting around on public transport can be difficult—traffic can be heavy, and the bus system may be confusing.

English is commonly spoken, but learning a few local phrases can help you communicate better. Safety is usually good, but, like any big city, it's smart to be aware of your surroundings. Explore the local customs and enjoy what Hyderabad has to offer!
hyderabad.description_kor:
하이데라바드는 현대적인 생활과 전통이 조화를 이루는 활기찬 도시입니다. 이곳은 기술 중심지로 알려져 있어서 많은 일자리를 찾는 사람들과 여러 기업들이 모여들어 바쁜 취업 시장과 다양한 기회를 만들어냅니다. 생활비는 대체로 다른 주요 인도 도시들에 비해 합리적인 편이라, 큰 지출 없이도 편안한 도시 생활을 즐길 수 있습니다.

문화적으로 하이데라바드는 다양한 매력을 지니고 있습니다. 비리야니 같은 맛있는 음식과 인기 있는 길거리 음식을 맛볼 수 있고, 찰미나르와 골콘다 요새와 같은 역사적인 명소도 둘러볼 수 있습니다. 하지만 대중교통을 이용하는 데는 조금 어려움이 있을 수 있습니다. 교통 체증이 심해질 수 있고, 버스 시스템도 복잡한 편입니다.

영어는 보통 사용되지만, 몇 가지 현지어 표현을 익히면 의사소통이 더 원활해질 수 있습니다. 대체로 안전하긴 하지만, 대도시인 만큼 주변 상황에 주의를 기울이는 것이 좋습니다. 지역 문화를 탐험하고 하이데라바드의 매력을 만끽해보세요!

reviews:
Spent summer 2020 on Hvar which turned into best summer ever in spite of the pandemic. The most friendly people, great food, beautiful beaches and for a few weeks.. fun nightclubs. All without the normal crush of tourists that would otherwise clog the place up. Made some lifelong friends on this trip and cannot wait to get myself back to Hvar in 2021.

And other than the time difference (stayed on NYC time), I had no issues working remotely from the island whatsoever. For the most part, I tethered from a local sim and was able to keep up video calls throughout the day...usually from a hammock somewhere on the island.

Hvar in 2020 really was paradise island. 10/10 recommend.
hvar.description:
Hvar is a popular summer vacation spot for many visitors. With its nice beaches and welcoming locals, this island makes you feel at home. You can enjoy good food at small restaurants and a lively nightlife—great for when you want to dance at night.

While some may prefer busy tourist areas, many who visited liked a quieter atmosphere, allowing them to connect with the island and meet new friends. Hvar is also good for remote workers; you could take video calls from a comfortable hammock while listening to the waves.

However, there may be some challenges, such as language differences or higher prices for meals. Public transportation is not very good, so you may need to walk or rent a bike to explore the beautiful coastal paths.

Be sure to take time to walk through historic streets or relax on the calm beaches. Whether you want a relaxing time or exciting activities, Hvar offers a memorable experience!
hvar.description_kor:
흐바르는 여름 휴양지로 많은 방문객들에게 사랑받고 있는 곳입니다. 아름다운 해변과 친절한 동네 주민들 덕분에 이 섬은 마치 집에 있는 듯한 편안함을 줍니다. 작은 식당에서 맛있는 음식을 즐기고, 활기찬 밤문화 속에서 음악에 맞춰 춤을 추는 것도 그만큼 즐거운 경험입니다.

북적거리는 관광지를 선호하는 사람들도 있지만, 많은 방문객들은 조용한 분위기를 좋아하기 때문에 섬의 매력을 느끼며 새로운 친구를 만나는 즐거움을 경험합니다. 흐바르는 원격 근무자에게도 안성맞춤인데, 파도 소리를 들으며 편안한 해먹에 누워 영상 통화를 할 수 있습니다.

다만 언어 장벽이나 높은 식사 비용 같은 몇 가지 도전 과제가 있을 수 있습니다. 대중교통이 그리 잘 되어 있지 않기 때문에 아름다운 해안 산책로를 탐험하려면 걷거나 자전거를 빌려야 할 수도 있습니다.

역사적인 거리에서 산책하거나 고요한 해변에서 편안한 시간을 꼭 가져보세요. 편안한 휴식을 원하든, 흥미진진한 활동을 원하든 흐바르는 잊지 못할 경험을 선사합니다!

reviews:
Indianapolis is a great place to visit for a long weekend, and areas like downtown Carmel are great for walkable, neighborhood-centric home base for raising a family. 

There aren't many nomads here. You move here if you want to raise a family while keeping up a lifestyle where you travel for a few months a year. There are good schools, the cost of living is cheap, the food and drink scene are great, and biking is fantastic. 

Source: Indy native who moved to Carmel, Indiana while getting through the pandemic. I've spent the last 4 years spending 6-8 months in Indy and 4-6 months abroad.

Go anywhere other than the north. Stear clear of the Carmel, zionsville, and fishers areas. Mostly intolerant disgusting people there. The rest of city is great. Source: I’ve lived all over Indy for 30+ years

I live in Indianapolis. Even though I don't want to live here in the future, I do now. And what I can tell you from this is that it is a beautiful family friendly city. Broad Ripple is a place for pets and children to come eat lunch and walk around. There are many shops from Ice Cream to Hiking stores. The inner city of Indianapolis though is the most fun. It may have been called a boring city but I highly disagree. I have a blast everytime I come to the city. Yes, there are problems and my tip is to stay downtown and have fun! I find it so sad that my city is ranked so low. I also don't know why the "Female Friendly" ranking is only at an okay. There are women's marches and other things along those lines here. Overall Indianapolis is a beautiful city! :)

Try to stay in the north in the Carmel, Zionsville, and Fishers cities... The rest of Indy is pretty disgusting. The potholes are the worst between Jan - May.
**Source:** I have lived all over this place for the past 8 years.
indianapolis.description:
Indianapolis is a friendly city that is good for a long weekend trip or for families wanting to live there. If you want a neighborhood feel, places like downtown Carmel are family-friendly and easy to walk around, making them great for your plans. The cost of living here is quite low, and people talk highly about the food and drink options. Biking is a common way to get around, so get a bike and enjoy the outdoors!

However, not all areas are the same. Some people suggest avoiding Carmel, Zionsville, and Fishers for a better experience. While the potholes can be annoying from January to May, the inner city has a lively atmosphere with many fun things to do and places to see, especially in Broad Ripple, which is good for pets, kids, and casual lunches.

One thing to remember is that public transport isn’t always reliable, so having a car can be helpful. Overall, Indianapolis has its challenges, but it attracts visitors with its friendly community and many activities!
indianapolis.description_kor:
인디애나폴리스는 긴 주말 여행이나 가족과 함께 살기 좋은 따뜻한 도시입니다. 동네 같은 분위기를 즐기고 싶다면, 다운타운 카멜처럼 가족 친화적이고 돌아다니기 좋은 곳들이 좋습니다. 이곳은 생활비도 저렴하고, 음식과 음료 선택지에 대한 평이 매우 좋습니다. 자전거를 타고 돌아다니는 것이 일반적이니, 자전거를 마련해 야외 활동을 즐겨보세요!

하지만 모든 지역이 똑같은 건 아닙니다. 더 나은 경험을 원하신다면 카멜, 자이온스빌, 그리고 피셔스를 피하는 것이 좋다는 의견도 있습니다. 1월에서 5월까지 도로의 움푹 파인 곳이 신경 쓰일 수 있지만, 도심은 많은 즐길 거리와 볼거리가 있어 활기찬 분위기를 즐길 수 있습니다. 특히 브로드 리플은 애완동물과 아이들과 함께하거나 가벼운 점심을 즐기기에 아주 좋은 장소입니다.

하나 기억해야 할 점은 대중교통이 항상 편리한 것은 아니니 차가 있으면 훨씬 편리하다는 것입니다. 전반적으로 인디애나폴리스는 다소 어려움이 있지만, 따뜻한 공동체와 다양한 활동 덕분에 방문객들을 사로잡는 매력이 넘치는 곳입니다!

reviews:
So it's like a party island, but the clubs are a bit like when you were 16 and you went to the local nightclub in your hometown. It's not very special. Definitely not as decorated and big and modern like clubs in the rest of the world now. I understand Ibiza's legacy in electronic music history very well. But I just feel it's more like a money making factory for DJs with weekly residencies and British, Dutch, German and some American holidayers coming in to spend the money. Which is all good but it doesn't feel it's the place for electronic music now anymore.

Apart from that there's also just not much to do here. You can go on a boat. You can go the old town and see some old architecture with tourist shops with stuff bought mostly from on Aliexpress and Temu.

If you try get a massage or haircut or pedicure or anything, it's usually full, just like many of the good restaurants. I understand this. But it's not like you can't scale this up. In Bali, a similar island, you always have stuff available because they just open new stores, cafes, restaurants. Ibiza instead feels like that happens less.

So yeah a bit of a basic island in my opinion. It's behind of islands in the US, South America, or even Asia. I give it a 6/10.
ibiza.description:
Ibiza is known mainly as a party island, but there is more to it than just nightlife. While the famous clubs may feel similar to venues in your hometown, they still draw a lively crowd. Many visitors think it seems to be a way for DJs to make money, serving a mix of British, Dutch, German, and American vacationers.

If you want to explore beyond the nightlife, you may find options limited. There are nice areas in the old town with attractive buildings that are good for walking. However, some locals say there aren't many activities besides boat trips and sunbathing. If you want a massage or food, be ready for long waits since popular places can fill up fast.

The cost of living here can be high, but the island has great views and a relaxed atmosphere. Just remember that new restaurants or spots to relax don’t open as fast as in some other places. Overall, Ibiza may seem simple compared to flashier locations, but it’s a place where you can enjoy the sun, dance a bit, and enjoy island life.
ibiza.description_kor:
이스라엘은 주로 파티 섬으로 알려져 있지만, 밤문화 외에도 매력이 넘치는 곳입니다. 유명한 클럽들은 고향의 분위기와 비슷하게 느껴질 수 있지만 여전히 활기찬 사람들을 끌어모으고 있습니다. 많은 방문객들은 이곳 DJ들이 돈을 바라며 공연하는 느낌을 받을 수 있으며, 영국, 네덜란드, 독일, 미국의 관광객들이 함께 어우러지는 모습을 자주 볼 수 있습니다.

밤문화 외에 탐험하고 싶다면 선택지가 다소 제한적일 수도 있습니다. 구시가지에는 산책하기 좋은 아름다운 건물들이 즐비한 멋진 지역이 있습니다. 하지만 일부 지역 주민들은 보트 타기와 일광욕 외에 특별한 활동은 많지 않다고 말합니다. 마사지나 맛있는 음식을 원하신다면 인기 있는 장소는 금방 만석이 될 수 있으니 긴 대기 시간에 대비해야 할 것입니다.

이곳의 생활비는 조금 높을 수 있지만, 아름다운 경치와 아늑한 분위기가 매력적입니다. 새로 오픈한 레스토랑이나 휴식 장소는 다른 곳에 비해 빠르게 생겨나기 힘들다는 점도 기억해 주세요. 전반적으로 이비자 섬은 화려함보다는 간소한 매력을 지니고 있지만, 태양을 만끽하고 가벼운 춤을 추며 섬 생활을 즐기기에 정말 좋은 곳입니다.

reviews: I've lived on Isla Mujeres for 8 years and grown my digital agency. It's peaceful, cheap and easy access to the mainland and USA. My business partner is in the UK and I can fly there with no issues.
The wifi conection on all the island maybe can be slower sometimes. i sugesto to have a 50gb plan internet by Didi simcards
isla-mujeres.description:
Isla Mujeres is a special place in Mexico that gives a good mix of island living and modern needs. With its calm atmosphere, many people have found it to be an affordable place to live. Imagine waking up to nice beach views and feeling the warm sand on your feet! The island is also only a short boat ride from the mainland, making trips to Cancun easy, whether for work or fun.

While you will find many good things here, it's important to know that the internet can be unreliable—so if you need good internet access, think about getting a 50GB plan through Didi simcards. The local culture is relaxed, with friendly people and lively traditions that make the island enjoyable.

Popular activities include snorkeling, visiting the beautiful beaches, and eating tasty local seafood. Just a tip: language can sometimes be difficult, so knowing a few Spanish phrases can help you have a better experience. Overall, Isla Mujeres offers a nice mix of relaxation and community that makes people want to come back!
isla-mujeres.description_kor:
이슬라 무헤레스는 멕시코의 독특한 장소로, 섬 생활과 현대적 편의성이 멋지게 어우러진 곳입니다. 조용한 분위기 속에서 생활하기에 부담 없는 가격대여서 많은 사람들에게 사랑받고 있습니다. 상상을 해보세요! 멋진 해변 전망을 바라보며 발 아래 따뜻한 모래를 느끼는 그 순간을! 이 섬은 본토와 가까워 짧은 보트 시간으로 이동할 수 있어 칸쿤으로의 출장이나 여가 여행을 더욱 편리하게 만들어 줍니다.

이곳에는 매력적인 것들이 많지만, 인터넷 연결이 불안정할 수 있다는 점을 염두에 두는 것이 중요합니다. 안정적인 인터넷이 필요하다면 Didi 심카드의 50GB 플랜을 고려해 보세요. 지역 문화는 한가롭고, 친절한 사람들로 가득하며 그들의 전통은 섬 생활을 더 흥미롭게 만듭니다.

이곳에서 인기 있는 활동으로는 스노클링, 아름다운 해변 투어, 그리고 맛있는 지역 해산물 요리를 즐길 수 있습니다. 한 가지 팁을 드리자면, 현지 언어가 다소 어려울 수 있으니 몇 가지 스페인어 기본 문구를 알고 가면 더 좋은 경험을 할 수 있습니다. 전반적으로 이슬라 무헤레스는 휴식과 공동체의 아름다운 조화를 이뤄, 많은 이들이 다시 찾고 싶어하는 곳입니다!

reviews: It's a great city to live in, I am a resident here and you have so many options as a nomad. I am working remotely as a Software Engineer and I am free to go anywhere.
islamabad.description:
Islamabad, the capital city of Pakistan, combines modern features with nature. Residents appreciate the city's parks and clean environment, making it a nice place to live or work remotely. As a Software Engineer, you will find many co-working spaces and a growing tech community that allows for flexibility and creativity.

While public transportation can be limited, taxis and ride-hailing services are useful options for getting around. Street food is tasty and inexpensive, but some areas might be more expensive for dining and entertainment.

The city has a lot of culture, with many parks, museums, and historical sites like the Faisal Mosque and Daman-e-Koh viewpoint, which provides great views of the area. However, language barriers can sometimes be an issue, so learning some basic Urdu phrases can help a lot.

To experience local life, visit neighborhoods like F-6 and F-7, where you will find busy markets and friendly people. Just remember to be aware of your surroundings and enjoy what Islamabad has to offer!
islamabad.description_kor:
이슬라마바드, 파키스탄의 수도는 현대적 요소와 자연이 조화롭게 어우러진 매력을 가지고 있습니다. 주민들은 도시의 공원과 깨끗한 환경을 높이 평가하며, 이곳은 생활하기 좋은 곳이자 원격 근무에도 적합한 장소입니다. 소프트웨어 엔지니어로서 여러분은 다양한 공동 작업 공간과 성장 중인 기술 커뮤니티를 접할 수 있을 것입니다.

대중교통은 다소 제한적일 수 있지만, 택시와 승차 호출 서비스가 이동할 때 유용한 수단으로 자리잡고 있습니다. 거리 음식은 맛있고 가격도 저렴하지만, 일부 지역에서는 식사와 엔터테인먼트 비용이 상승할 수 있습니다.

이 도시에는 파이살 모스크(Faisal Mosque)와 다만-에-코(Daman-e-Koh) 전망대와 같은 많은 공원, 박물관, 역사적인 장소들이 있어 풍부한 문화와 함께 아름다운 경치를 즐길 수 있습니다. 다만, 언어 장벽이 가끔 문제로 작용할 수 있으므로 기본적인 우르두어 구문을 배우는 것이 유용할 것입니다.

지역 문화를 제대로 느끼고 싶다면 F-6와 F-7 같은 동네를 방문해보세요. 이곳에서는 활기찬 시장과 친절한 사람들을 만날 수 있습니다. 새로운 경험을 위해 주변을 잘 살펴보고 이슬라마바드의 매력을 만끽하는 것을 잊지 마세요!

reviews: Great place, I stayed at bug n boats.....epics.s go to gua tempurung
ipoh.description:
Ipoh, Malaysia, is a city that surprises visitors with its charm and history. Many people like its relaxed atmosphere and friendly locals, making it a good place for a calm getaway. If you enjoy nature, don’t miss Gua Tempurung, a large limestone cave with beautiful views and exciting cave tours. 

Staying in areas like Bug & Boats can improve your experience, with comfortable places to stay and a chance to meet other travelers. While living costs here are usually lower than in larger cities in Malaysia, some visitors have said that public transportation may not be very convenient, so having a car might help. 

On the other hand, language can be a challenge for some, but many locals speak English. Overall, Ipoh’s mix of culture, tasty street food, and historical sites makes it a place worth visiting!
ipoh.description_kor:
말레이시아 이포는 방문객들에게 매력과 역사로 가득한 도시입니다. 많은 사람들이 이곳의 여유로운 분위기와 친절한 지역 주민들을 좋아해 평화로운 휴양지로 손꼽히고 있습니다. 자연을 만끽하고 싶으신 분들은 아름다운 경관과 흥미로운 동굴 투어를 경험할 수 있는 구아 템푸룽을 꼭 방문해 보세요.

버그 & 보트(Bug & Boats)와 같은 지역에서 묵으면 편안한 숙소는 물론, 다른 여행자들과의 교류를 통해 더욱 풍성한 경험을 할 수 있습니다. 이곳의 생활비는 말레이시아의 대도시에 비해 상대적으로 저렴하지만, 일부 방문객들은 대중교통이 그리 편리하지 않다고 느낄 수 있어 차량 소유가 도움이 될 수 있습니다.

또한, 언어가 일부에게는 도전이 될 수 있지만, 많은 지역 주민들이 영어를 잘 구사합니다. 전반적으로 이포는 독특한 문화, 맛있는 길거리 음식, 역사적인 명소가 어우러져 있어 꼭 방문해볼 가치가 있는 곳입니다!

reviews: Spent a month here. Too small, but welcoming young people.
I got bored within 3 hours of being here. Great place hunker down and write a novel... otherwise...
ivano-frankivsk.description:
Ivano-Frankivsk is a welcoming city. With its friendly atmosphere and young people, it feels like a good place to relax. The pace here is slow, which is nice if you want to work on a project, like writing a book. However, the city can feel small and quiet after some time—some visitors have felt a little bored after just a few hours.

The cost of living is reasonable, making it easy to visit local cafes and parks. Public transportation is available, but it’s not as good as in larger cities, so having a plan for getting around is important. The local customs are friendly, and the culture is lively during festivals. It can be helpful to know some Ukrainian or Russian to get through any language issues.

Overall, Ivano-Frankivsk has its own characteristics, but it is a great place for a quiet getaway or a short visit.
ivano-frankivsk.description_kor:
이바노-프랑키스크는 정말 환영받는 도시입니다. 친근한 분위기와 젊은 인구 덕분에 이곳은 편안하게 쉴 수 있는 매력적인 장소로 느껴집니다. 이 도시의 삶은 느림과 여유가 있어, 책을 쓰거나 프로젝트에 집중하기에 안성맞춤입니다. 그러나 시간이 흐르면서 도시가 작고 조용하게 느껴질 수도 있습니다. 몇몇 방문객들은 몇 시간 만에 약간 지루함을 느끼기도 했습니다.

생활비는 적당해, 현지 카페나 공원을 쉽게 방문할 수 있습니다. 대중교통은 있지만 대도시에 비해 불편할 수 있어, 이동 경로를 미리 계획하는 것이 중요합니다. 지역 주민들은 매우 친절하고, 축제 기간에는 활기찬 문화를 경험할 수 있습니다. 언어 문제를 줄이기 위해 약간의 우크라이나어 또는 러시아어를 아는 것이 도움이 될 수 있습니다.

전반적으로 이바노-프랑키스크는 특유의 매력을 지닌 도시이지만, 조용한 휴식처로서 또는 짧은 여행을 위한 훌륭한 장소로 추천할 수 있습니다.

reviews:
I'm so surprised to see all these comments. I absolutely love Jakarta !
You can take a gojek bike taxi for 1$ and they bring you anywhere. The skyline is beautiful at night. The food is good. The people are kind and always smiling...
I prefer Jakarta to Bali ! And I've been multiple times in both. For sure it's a city with many skyscrapers, so the quality of the air is not great. But you can drive out of the city and have absolutely beautiful mountains and rice fields (such as Bogor).
In the city center there are many malls with all the big brands you know of. So many delicious restaurants too.
It is true that sometimes people dont speak English but... what's the point of travelling to Asia if you want absolutely everyone to speak the same language as you ?

The ugliest city I've ever set foot in. It is very polluted. Developers are obsessed with "European" style building because it looks "rich". There are an endless amount of shopping malls with new ones coming, which get old quickly. "Parks" here are more of an afterthought, not a legitimate park. Gated communities are the fabric of the city so you must drive or walk through the main roads that are jam-packed with traffic. In other words, the city is made up of exclusive pockets of housing areas that are unintegrated with the rest of the city, meanwhile, the rest are slums. People are (as a previous review mentioned) smug, pretentious, and deeply insecure about themselves but manifested outwardly as being rude. Traffic is a problem in itself but to drive here is entirely another subgenre. To give you an idea about the mentality of the people here; nobody will do anything if there's someone dying in an ambulance. Not a single car would give way for an ambulance or pedestrians crossing the road. Speaking of pedestrians, the city is extremely unsafe to walk.
Skip this place and go to Bali right away. This city only looks beautiful in tourism videos but ugly in person. It is dusty and smelly.

Some things I don't like about Jakarta-
1. Not much English spoken
2. Everything is overpriced especially food and alcohol.
3. People are weird, smug, rude and kind of r-cist actually. 
4. The food isnt good except for nasi goreng and satay and most of it is low quality. 
5. Everywhere is crowded and locals are loud so good luck finding a place to work. 
6. Visas are costly and difficult if you want to stay long term.

"Don't go to Jakarta" is what people from Jakarta tell you. 

But you do. It can't be that bad, right? Then you arrive. Although "arriving" is a big word for getting stuck in traffic first for hours. When you do finally arrive in your apartment, you open the windows and wonder why you can't see further than 10 meters. It must be a foggy day? No, it's not fog, it's smog, and it's an every day occurrence in Jakarta, a city that is now competing with Beijing for worst air quality in the world. 

What's good about Jakarta? It's one of the few places in Indonesia (except maybe Bali) that's open-minded. Jakartans are friendly, helpful and warm acting as if Jakarta is still just a small Indonesian village and that's great. It's also one of the fastest growing cities in Asia. It's cosmopolitan. But all that doesn't weigh up to the negatives that is Jakarta right now.

Clean up the air, fix the traffic, and Jakarta might be liveable in a decade.

"Don't go to Jakarta" is what people from Jakarta tell you. They're right.
jakarta.description:
Jakarta, a busy city in Indonesia, has many differences that will keep you interested. Many visitors talk about the kindness of the locals and the fun of riding a gojek bike taxi for just $1 to get around the city. The skyline looks nice at night, and you can find tasty street food and many shopping malls to see popular brands.

However, Jakarta has its problems. The traffic can be very bad, with long waits in jams, and the air quality is not good. Many people feel overwhelmed by the pollution and crowded streets. Language difficulties may occur, as not everyone speaks English, but you are in Asia—enjoying the local culture can be part of the experience!

If you go out, consider places like Bogor for nice nature. Just remember to be careful on the roads; pedestrian safety can be an issue. While the city has some downsides—like expensive dining and some unfriendly attitudes—there is definitely a unique energy here for you to explore!
jakarta.description_kor:
자카르타는 인도네시아의 분주한 도시로, 여러분에게 흥미로운 경험을 선사할 다양한 매력이 있습니다. 많은 방문객들이 현지인들의 친절함과 고젝 바이크 택시를 단돈 1달러에 이용할 수 있는 즐거움을 자주 이야기합니다. 특히 야경이 아름답고, 맛있는 길거리 음식과 유명 브랜드 매장이 가득한 쇼핑몰도 많아서 즐길 거리가 다양합니다.

하지만 자카르타에는 몇 가지 문제점도 존재합니다. 교통이 매우 혼잡하여 긴 정체가 자주 발생하고, 공기 질도 좋지 않은 편입니다. 많은 사람들이 오염과 혼잡한 거리 때문에 스트레스를 느낍니다. 또한, 모든 사람들이 영어를 사용하지 않기 때문에 언어 장벽이 있을 수 있지만, 아시아의 분위기를 느끼며 현지 문화를 경험하는 것 또한 여행의 일부가 될 수 있습니다!

외출할 계획이라면 보르와 같은 아름다운 자연을 가진 장소를 고려해 보세요. 도로에서는 조심하는 것을 잊지 마세요. 보행자 안전이 중요한 문제입니다. 자카르타는 비싼 음식과 때때로 불친절한 서비스 같은 단점이 있지만, 그럼에도 불구하고 탐험할 만한 독특한 에너지를 지닌 도시입니다!

reviews:
Izmir is off-the-radar of many tourists and nomads, but it has a lot to offer. It's relatively affordable, and it's warmer in the winter than many other parts of Türkiye, it has good public transit, decent food and shopping options, and reliably fast and stable internet. It's also a good jumping-off point for a day trip to Çeşme and several Greek islands that can be reached by ferry. You can pay by card nearly everywhere except the Izmir Metro, Izban — even for small purchases of 50¢ (currently 16TL)

Things that might turn you off:
1. This is not an English speaking city, even among the young university population. You can get by, but you are unlikely to strike up intricate conversations with most locals unless you're attending a language exchange meetup or hanging out near an English school. If however, you are looking for language immersion, I can recommend a homestay and/or making friends with locals here.
2. Turkish people love to smoke. If you want to hang out at a cafe and work, particularly outside most people are lighting up.
3. Internet in Türkiye is censored. Even sites like Booking aren't available without a VPN. The big ones that the government knows about may also be blocked. On the same note, connecting to public wifi requires personal information including your passport, and to be able to receive SMS 2FA, so if your foreign SIM does not have service, you can't use these APs.
4. Pork is really only available at the upmarket Macrocenter supermarket. Every restaurant offers halal as a default, and their version of pepperoni or sausage is all beef based. Beer and liquor, however, are available in every corner store and supermarket. I don't know why.

If you do decide to buy a Turkish SIM, only Tourist plans are available to foreigners without residency, with an inflated price of $21 just for the SIM and activation. (Though the data packages can be competitive.) Therefore, for short visits, it might be more economical to use one of these world roaming eSIMS, which I don't normally recommend.

I wouldn't recommend using the expat FB groups to find short or long-term housing because they are cryptic and never list the price in the ad. Though maybe you'll ask around and find one by word-of-mouth instead and get a better deal, more in line with Turkish incomes.

Lastly, do try to integrate in your local community and chat up locals. Don't be the digital nomad that doesn't talk to anyone. You can live anywhere. This doesn't mean that you need to behave like the place you left behind.

I've lived in İzmir for more than 10 years, so I have the need to say some things that may be valuable to one or the other. Izmir is the most liveable city in Turkey. It's less religious, (therefore) more open to foreigners and just more fun! We have a racism problem, but not against any European, or American. It's more about being associated with other muslim ethnicities like Arabs, Afghans etc. and also because many of these groups cause economic issues in the country - it's complicated.
About the positive stuff: Izmir is for sure a better option than Istanbul, which is waay to packed and crowded. Of course Izmir is crowded too, but not nearly as Istanbul. Yes, people are very friendly, that's just part of turkish culture. It's not 100% safe, since the whole country is still dealing with poverty and has gone trough many crisisis. But I would say, just like any other country/city, it should be fine if you are careful where you place your personal belongings and are not outside after it's getting darker (especially as a woman). Overall, Izmır is very special and should be given a chance 100000%.

Pros
- cheap: lunch for 1 person for less than USD10, grande cappuccino in Starbucks for less than USD2
- good cafes and restaurants, for them go to Mustafa Enver Bey street in Alsancak, to Cengiz Topel street in Bostanli, or to Hilltown, Mavibahce, and Istinye Park malls
- a big city with skyscrapers in the financial district, good public transportation including metro, trams, buses, and ferries, and big malls, but slower, cheaper, more relaxed, and less crowded than Istanbul
- great climate, historic attractions, and perfect beaches and kitesurfing spots in a 30 to 60 minutes drive.
- liberal and cosmopolitan city, with many bars and nightclubs. No problem to buy alcoholic drinks in any supermarket. Also, there are several good wineries near the city where you can go for a wine tour.
- wonderful friendly people who will love your children as their own
- fast and reasonably priced mobile internet (but do not buy a sim card in the airport) 
Cons
- in many parts of the city it is not convenient to walk: pavements are mostly narrow and bumpy and traffic lights work in a weird way
- not so many people speak English, but usually, people are friendly and open to communicating via google translator
- not enough options for short-term accommodation: several good Airbnbs and expensive hotels of international chains are good. Unfortunately, I didn't find any good hostels there. And economic hotels are mostly outdated and usually based in depressive neighborhoods. Hope the situation will change soon.
- many neighborhoods look depressive, but the city is developing and getting more attractive. While you are in Alsancak, Bostanli-Karsiyaka, or several places in Bornova and Bayrakli - everything is perfect and safe. By the way, Izmir is a very safe city.

Pros
- Friendly locals, easy to make friends. Go to a bar and chat with whoever. You'll become friends quickly.
- Coffee and tea shops everywhere with good prices
- Internet is pretty fast in my experience
- I never got foreigner pricing, unlike other reviewers
- Good prices if you're bringing in outside currency
- Younger people speak English, older people don't, but you should be attempting Turkish anyway :)
- Never felt any kind of racism(Korean)

Cons
- Smoking everywhere. It's impossible to sit in a cafe and not smell cigarette the whole time
- Extremely hilly in some areas. Great if you want to perform leg day everyday
- I was disappointed by the quality of food in general. Find a local to show you the best restaurants. Gözleme and kelle paça were my favorites.
- Super hot in September. I hated to stay indoors all day, but that's what I did for many days.
- Taxi drivers all have a dreamcast installed in their car and they're all playing crazy taxi
- Ages seem to skew higher. Hard to come across people my age or younger.

Stayed here for 2 months, it was terrible—internet was slow, people were racist, blatant price gouging of foreigners, and my boyfriend was accosted in the street one night when a random group of brawling men were kicked out of a bar and they came out punching and kicking at anyone who had the misfortune of being in their way. We stayed in 2 different AirbnBs in the most central part of Izmir and both of them had spotty internet. In one of them, the water cut out several times despite being billed as a “luxury” accommodation. Price gouging foreigners is not an uncommon phenomenon in any destination, but when you walk into a corner store and are told that a bottle of water costs 10 Euros, that really takes the piss and leaves an incredibly bad taste in your mouth. Didn’t feel safe as a woman either—a female friend of mine visited for a week and we went to grab some dessert one night, only to be harassed by two men at the table next to us who seemed to think that because we politely responded to their question of where we were from, it was an invitation to try to follow us home and get angry and rude when we asked them to stop. The list of negative experiences goes on and on. To be honest I wanted to leave by the end of the second week but I stuck it out, telling myself to stay open minded. Unfortunately, the longer we stayed, the worse it got. We were very relieved to leave. We did make one very kind local friend here who kept us sane and even they said they wouldn’t live here if they had the choice. There are much cheaper and more pleasant places to stay! The person who left a comment about two beds going for $120 is quite mistaken. Even looking on long term rental sites you would be paying around $600, and if you are foreign the landlords will do things like demand the whole year’s rent up front.

Totally false about the numbers being off, who ever left that comment. There are nice apartments, even two-beds going for about 1,800 lira (120 dollars) if sign a long-term contract so i'm sure $87 is possible
The numbers are completely false here. 1br studio rent in center for $87? That's impossible. You gotta pay at least $300 for a crappy studio. The new and the modern ones is probably around $500-600.

I loved, loved, loved Izmir! It's an excellent place for student exchange programs. Five months was enough for me, though. People are friendly, helpful, and always highly optimistic. 

PROS:

People -> amazing!,
Food (a great place for vegans),
Nature,
Prices,

CONS:
Pavements (or lack of pavements),
Smoking (people smoke everywhere),
Bureaucracy (If you don't speak Turkish, forget about running errands in local municipalities),
Language barrier (Not many people speak English well),
Politics (If you are open-minded and support freedom of speech, and freedom in general, it's not a good place for you. You could suffer from stomach ulcers).
It's an excellent place to see, a fantastic place to meet many friends, but not the best place for the long run.
Cheaper version of Athens. Most liberal city in Turkey. Definitely underrated and amazingly cheap. The city has a great beach, restaurant and bar scene.

In all of Turkey, Izmir is by far the most educated and cosmopolitan city. I have lived in Turkey for 12 years and have been visiting for 30 years. Changes in the geo-political climate have shown restrictions to freedoms that a lot of westerners will find uninviting. Izmir is a city that is that I have found that has a positive attitude amongst the people towards most foreigners.

İzmir is probably the best digital nomad destination in Europe. In terms of: cost of living, access to Internet, places to work from, activities in the city, public transport, safety, city/beach/nature balance. Those who found it boring are probably looking for places where youngsters get drunk in pool parties or such. If you are looking for kind and educated population, ease of access to all amenities, Izmir is definitely a great choice. Yes, it is not a tropical destination, so it gets cold in winter for about two months.

Turkey was a fascinating and exotic place in the eighties and nineties but even then I took a dislike to Izmir after getting robbed and threatened there. In more recent times, the considerable slice of the population has become more and more hostile to Westerners although it's usually disguised. I stopped going in 2015.

Racism is absolutely present in Izmir and Turkey. You only have to take a look here https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racism_in_Turkey to find systemic racism "towards non-Turkish ethnic minorities such as Armenians, Assyrians, Greeks, Kurds, Jews, Yazidis and Zazas as well as hostility towards minority forms of Islam such as Alevis, Sufis, and Shiites."
I don't think nomad list is somewhere to lean all your trust in because I have loads of friends from Izmir and they have never complained or talked about it being racially intolerant.

Izmir is probably the friendliest city I have seen in my life. Seeing bad ratings for racial tolerance here just made me lose trust in nomadlist. Pity, idea is good but data is completely twisted and has nothing to do with reality.

I love Izmir. I taught English in Izmir. There are many things to do and I love the people and the great little restaurants everywhere. Buses provide perfect transportation from Izmir to any destination in Turkey. I wish I were there right now! Walk along the Kordon, explore Alsancak, Karsiyaka and Kemeralta. Take a bus to Kusadasi or Cesme on the weekends. Wonderful! Try the Manisa Kebap. I was a solo female.
Izmir what a horrible boring place. We were there 2 months and we hated it. It is dry and hot and nobody speaks English. We have been all over the world but Izmir was the worst.
izmir.description:
Izmir is a less-known city in Turkey that many travelers overlook, but those who visit enjoy its relaxed atmosphere. If you want a city that feels friendly and warm, this is the place! You can find affordable meals—like lunch for under $10 and a cappuccino for just $2—along with good public transport options like buses and trams.

The city has a rich cultural scene with helpful locals who enjoy making new friends, especially if you try to speak a little Turkish. Areas like Alsancak and Bostanli are known for their busy cafes and restaurants. It's also a good starting point for day trips to nice coastal areas or nearby Greek islands.

However, there are some challenges. English is not widely spoken, so you might find it hard to have conversations beyond basic phrases. The city can also be quite smoky due to its café culture that includes cigarettes. Lastly, while some parts of Izmir are nice and lively, other neighborhoods may look worn. Overall, Izmir combines low prices with a special character, making it an interesting place to visit!
izmir.description_kor:
이스미르(Izmir)는 많은 여행자들이 잘 모르는 터키의 숨은 보석 같은 도시입니다. 이곳을 방문한 사람들은 편안한 분위기를 만끽하게 됩니다. 친근하고 따뜻한 느낌의 도시를 원하신다면 이스미르가 제격입니다! 점심을 10달러 이하로 해결할 수 있고, 카푸치노는 고작 2달러로 즐길 수 있어 매우 경제적입니다. 또, 버스와 트램 같은 훌륭한 대중교통 옵션도 마련되어 있습니다.

이스미르에는 풍부한 문화가 있고, 새로운 친구를 만나기를 좋아하는 친절한 지역 주민들이 많습니다. 특히 조금이라도 터키어로 인사하면 더욱 환대받을 것입니다. 알산자크(Alsancak)와 보스탄리(Bostanlı) 지역은 활기찬 카페와 레스토랑으로 유명하며, 아름다운 해안가와 가까운 그리스 섬으로의 당일치기 여행을 떠나기에도 좋은 출발점입니다.

하지만 이곳에는 몇 가지 도전 과제도 있습니다. 영어 사용이 그리 널리 퍼져 있지 않아 기본적인 문장을 넘어서 대화하는 게 어려울 수 있습니다. 카페 문화에서 담배가 흔하게 피우기 때문에 공기가 다소 탁할 수도 있습니다. 그리고 이스미르의 일부 지역은 매력적이고 활기차지만, 다른 이웃들은 다소 낡아 보일 수 있습니다. 그럼에도 불구하고 이스미르는 저렴한 가격과 독특한 매력을 모두 갖춘 흥미로운 여행지입니다!

reviews:
My first city in Saudi Arabia! Spent a week there and actually had quite an interesting time. Old Jeddah in the center is extremely cool neighbourhood to walk around during evening, a lot of people around, sounds, lights all around, really liked the vibe.

People are really friendly in my opinion, was given some food treats by random Saudi family nearby in some cafe in the center, have never had an experience like that in many countries I've been to. Although I didn't really speak too much with locals apart from taxi driver and hotel worker. City is not very walkable, mostly very car oriented.
Can recommend to have a walk on Corniche as well.
What I didn't like - I just couldn't find any grocery shop which is not small place owned by Indian with shitty low-quality food, more like rice, ramens and snacks. So basically I had to go out to eat all the time.
jeddah.description:
If you are thinking about visiting Jeddah, you will find a good mix of sights and experiences. The city is lively, especially in Old Jeddah, where the evenings are filled with sounds and lights. Walking through this area, you will see friendly locals who may offer you tasty food—it is a place where people are welcoming.

The Corniche is a place you should see, as it has great views and is a nice spot for watching people. However, remember that the city is not very easy to walk in, so be prepared to take a taxi or ride in a car to get around.

Some visitors find it hard to find good grocery stores because many are small and not very stocked. Eating out might be a better option, which is good because the local food is tasty! Just keep an open mind, and you will enjoy the culture and friendliness that Jeddah has to offer. Make sure to stay safe and learn about the local customs—there is a lot to appreciate here!
jeddah.description_kor:
제다를 방문할 계획이라면, 이곳이 다양한 볼거리와 색다른 경험으로 가득 찬 멋진 장소라는 것을 알게 될 것입니다. 특히 구시가지인 올드 제다에서는 저녁 시간마다 소리와 빛으로 가득 찬 활기찬 분위기를 느낄 수 있습니다. 이 지역을 거닐다 보면, 맛있는 음식을 제공하는 친절한 현지인들을 만날 수 있어요. 정말 환영받는 곳입니다.

코르니쉬는 꼭 가봐야 할 명소로, 아름다운 경치를 감상할 수 있으며 사람들의 모습을 구경하기에도 좋은 장소입니다. 다만 이 도시가 걷기에 그렇게 편리하지 않으니, 택시를 이용하거나 차량을 준비해 두는 것이 좋습니다.

일부 방문객들은 적절한 식료품 가게를 찾기 어려울 수도 있습니다. 많은 가게들이 작고 재고가 많지 않기 때문이에요. 외식하는 것이 더 나은 선택일 수 있는데, 다행히도 현지 음식은 정말 맛있답니다! 열린 마음으로 제다의 문화와 따뜻한 환대를 만끽해 보세요. 안전에 유의하고, 현지 풍습에 대해 배우는 것도 잊지 마세요. 여기에는 감사할 만한 것들이 정말 많습니다!

reviews:
Jeju seems gorgeous and cool (very breezy) in the spring, but the nicer the weather, it starts to get overrun with Chinese tourists. The trails along the coast have incredible views of cool islands in the ocean, with crashing waves against rocky cliffs, rolling meadows covered with flowers, and winding tree covered paths, though the trail has so many tourists that it’s very “manicured.” Ask around or just explore and you can find more rustic mountain trails, pass by unexpected mound graves that will make you feel like Lara Croft: Tomb Raider, or climb up wooded trails leading to a surprise temple at the top of a mountain with incredible views of the sunset under the temple eaves. A lot of these places are away from the coast at higher elevations (and much cooler temps), away from where most of the tourists flock.

Compared to before, many more Western tourists have shown up, a lot from Western & Northern Europe, as well as from the Middle East and South Asia. Not too many Americans. English not widely spoken by the Koreans here, but depending on your luck, many Koreans try very hard to help. Education rate is extremely high, so many just pull out the Korean version of Google Translate (ChatGPT is much better with Korean than Google Translate), which then makes everything possible. You’ll run into the occasional grumpy old man, though. Incredibly safe at all hours for both men and women. 

Something I just found out - 119 (Korean 911) is a public service, so if you have a medical emergency, call it, and it’s COMPLETELY FREE, even for non-Koreans with no insurance. But you’ll have to pay for medical services at the hospital if you don’t have traveler’s insurance. Med clinics and hospitals range anywhere in quality from the equivalent of French public clinics to posh Manhattan medical offices. I had an urgent ear problem, lost hearing in my right ear. It turned out to be ear wax I pushed into my ear with a Q-tip, lol. A very kind local pulled out her phone, looked on Korean Google (Naver), found me a highly rated ENT center just 10 minutes away. Gorgeous place, took me right in, and with no insurance I paid $15. I’d never be able to get an ENT appt in the US for weeks, instead would have waited hours at an urgicare center, and would have paid $50-$100 with insurance copayments. AMAZING.

My dog swallowed a small bone, a store clerk recommended a vet across the avenue - small but nice and clean facility. With ChatGPT, they did an exam, took X-rays, and gave him medicine, all for $13.

Some things here are expensive, but some things, even extremely nice or vital, like some medical services or 119, are incredibly cheap. 

An EXCELLENT resource is the Jeju Integrated Call Center a nice man just told me about this morning to confirm potential ambulance costs (after my ear problem, I wanted to be prepared for bigger medical emergencies in a foreign country). On a local cell phone, dial 064-120. They have interpreters, and they are a Jeju tourism Association organization for non-Jeju people (Koreans and foreigners) to help us navigate the Jeju system. They will answer questions from where to go for medical services, to tourist attractions, to how to get around the island. They will also connect you to organizations you may be trying to find to get more detailed information. They helped me figure out how to find where I could easily fly to quickly restart the clock on my 90-day time-limited tourist visa.

Remember that while Jeju is a “subtropical’ island in Asia, it is not Thailand. With only 50 million people, it is the world’s 12th largest economy and one of the most high-tech countries in the world. It doesn’t make sense to expect prices like in Vietnam or the Philippines, and Koreans expect themselves to speak English about as much as Americans expect themselves to speak Spanish, even though there are exponentially more Spanish speakers in the US than English speakers in Korea. 

We are digital nomads, meaning we are supposed have a non-American-centric perspective after traveling to so many places. Travel to Japan to find even fewer people speaking English, and even more annoyance that we expect them to, behind their apologetic facade.

If you are looking for a cheap place for a temporary workplace, Jeju might not be your best choice, but would you expect anything different from Japan or Barcelona? But compared to Seoul, accommodations are cheaper, and it’s a beautiful place to stay at the right season. 

I hope this review helps. Jeju isn’t for everyone, but for some, it’s a real gem, and with the few things that I was lucky to find out, I hope these can make the challenges of being somewhere very different smoother so you can focus on the beauty here!

Cheers!

Jeju now has more coworking spaces across the island due to the remote worker trend going on in Korea. You would have to locate many via google maps though. 1 month stays are trending on the island as well for Korean remote workers. The free coworking space in Jeju city still exists. New hotels are popping up as well. Pandemic travel to the island has given it more life from mainland Koreans. It's good to see the new growth and tech efforts. Jeju still has a lot more potential for the future. It's still a good value for a modern island lifestyle.
Safe for female solo travelers with affordable accommodations. Nature lovers should like it.

I stayed in Jeju for 2 weeks while traveling and I wouldn't recommend it.
The internet is fast, but that's about it.
People do not particularly speak English and it makes it hard to get around. It's hard to visit the island if you don't have a car, and you need an international driving license to rent a car.
Also, prices are high. I spent around 15$ for a main course with no drinks and average service.

Wouldn't recommend. SEA is better.
It's best to go after the crowds and typhoon season ends. It then becomes peaceful and quiet for work and relaxation. Taxis are affordable. Able to get by without knowing too much Korean.

It's hard to get around without a car. it's possible to use the public transportation, but having a car is so much easier. bus system is great but without knowing korean it might take some time to get used to. Food is amazing, the beaches are the world class, locals are generally nice and full of hip cafes and shops if you know where to go. The downside is the price - so expensive compare to Seoul! Seoul has at least the cheap options you can choose from, but Jeju has nothing like that. If you are a meat eater the pork in Jeju is tremendous. Highly recommend to go group fishing on a boat, so cheap and soooo fun!
Kind of deserted after the Chinese are gone. Better stay in a cemetery.
jeju-island.description:
Jeju Island in South Korea is a great place to visit with its natural scenery and local experiences. You will see coastlines where waves hit rocky cliffs, paths leading to quiet temples, and fields full of flowers. It is especially nice in the spring. However, be ready for busy trails during popular travel times, especially with visitors from China.

Many locals want to help you, but English is not commonly spoken, which can make it hard if you don't know Korean. With some patience and a translation app, you will manage fine. The island has various medical services, and many are affordable for visitors.

Eating out can be expensive, so watch your budget—some meals may cost more than you think. Renting a car is a good idea for getting around, as public transport can be difficult.

In general, Jeju is a good place for nature lovers and those looking for a quiet getaway, but make sure to plan your visit to avoid large crowds!
jeju-island.description_kor:
제주도는 아름다운 자연 경관과 독특한 지역 경험이 어우러져 있어 환상적인 여행지입니다. 해안에서는 파도가 암벽에 부딪히는 장관을 감상할 수 있고, 조용한 사원으로 이어지는 길과 화사한 꽃밭도 만날 수 있습니다. 특히 봄철의 풍경은 특히 아름답습니다. 하지만 성수기에는 중국에서 오는 관광객들로 인해 인기 있는 트레일이 붐비게 되니 미리 대비해야 합니다.

현지인들이 도움을 주고 싶어 하지만, 영어를 잘하는 분들이 많지 않아서 한국어를 모르면 조금 어려울 수 있습니다. 그러나 편안한 마음과 번역 앱을 활용하면 여행하는 데 큰 도움이 될 겁니다. 제주도에는 다양한 의료 서비스가 마련되어 있으며, 많은 서비스가 방문객들에게 저렴하게 제공됩니다.

식사는 비용이 많이 들 수 있으니 예산에 유의하세요. 일부 음식은 예상보다 비쌀 수 있습니다. 대중교통이 불편할 수 있으므로 차량 렌트도 고려해보는 것이 좋은 아이디어입니다.

전반적으로 제주도는 자연을 사랑하는 사람들과 조용한 휴식을 원하는 이들에게 안성맞춤인 곳이지만, 붐비는 인파를 피할 수 있도록 방문 계획을 잘 세우는 것이 중요합니다!

reviews: literally one of the worst cities I have ever been, not safe at all, nothing to do, full of retired people, just skip it, Brazil has way better places than this horrible city
A quite underrated city, deserves more visitors! Great beaches, delicious food and probably the cheapest capital in Brazil. Just go!
Joao Pessoa is a really great city very safe and lgbtq+ friendly loved it very much there
joao-pessoa.description:
João Pessoa, a city in northeastern Brazil, has mixed reviews, but it has its appeal. Those who love it talk about the nice beaches and tasty local food, saying it is one of the most affordable capitals in Brazil. Imagine relaxing on the sand, drinking fresh coconut water, and enjoying seafood at local restaurants.

This city is seen as quite safe, especially for the LGBTQ+ community, making it a friendly place for everyone. However, some visitors feel there isn't much to do and notice a more relaxed atmosphere with many retirees around. If you want a busy nightlife or many activities, you might find it quiet compared to other popular places in Brazil.

Getting around can be a bit difficult since public transport isn't very good, so planning is important. Exploring neighborhoods can be enjoyable, with simple streets and welcoming locals eager to share their culture. If you're looking for nice beaches and a friendly feel, João Pessoa might surprise you!
joao-pessoa.description_kor:
브라질 북동부에 위치한 조앙 페소아는 다양한 평가를 받고 있지만, 여전히 매력이 넘치는 도시입니다. 이곳을 사랑하는 사람들은 멋진 해변과 맛있는 지역 음식을 자랑하며, 브라질에서 가장 저렴한 수도 중 하나라고 입을 모읍니다. 모래사장에서 편안히 쉬고 신선한 코코넛 물을 마시면서, 지역 식당에서 신선한 해산물을 맛보는 순간을 상상해 보세요.

특히 이 도시는 LGBTQ+ 커뮤니티에 매우 안전한 장소로 알려져 있으며, 모든 방문객에게 친근한 분위기를 제공합니다. 그러나 일부 방문객들은 할 일이 많지 않다고 느낄 수도 있고, 더 여유로운 분위기 속에서 많은 은퇴자들이 살고 있음을 감지할 수 있습니다. 만약 바쁜 밤문화나 다양한 활동을 원하신다면, 다른 인기 있는 브라질 도시들과 비교했을 때 다소 조용하게 느껴질 수 있습니다.

대중교통은 그리 편리하지 않아서 이동에 조금 불편함을 느낄 수 있으니, 미리 계획을 세우는 것이 중요합니다. 동네를 탐방하는 것은 정말 즐거울 수 있으며, 친절한 현지인들이 간단한 거리 문화와 일상의 이야기를 나누고 싶어합니다. 멋진 해변과 따뜻한 분위기를 원하신다면, 조앙 페소아가 여러분을 놀라게 할지도 모릅니다!

reviews:
As a local, born and bred Joburger, I can tell you that there is a lot to love about this city if you know where to look. For the most part, it's orientated around suburbian living. The main city (Johannesburg CBD) is for the most part a no-go because of crime, but if you know some locals you should definitely check it out there are amazing restaurants, theatres and museums to experience there. 

Having lived here for 30+ years, I'd recommend checking out Sandton CBD, restaurants in Linden, Wanderers and Bryanston, and rent a car to drive out to The Cradle of Humankind, and visit the Maropeng museum there. There is a lot to do here, you just need to think and act like a local. 

If you are travelling to Johannesburg, I also feel like you'd be doing yourself a diss service by not planning a trip to The Kruger National Park.

I am a UK born, East Asian female who lived in Joburg (alone) as an expat for a few years... and I really love it. 
Yes, there are safety concerns so you must take precautions, however, I found the locals to be extremely warm and friendly (the one thing I wasn't expecting when I arrived), the weather is spot on, it's very cheap, good quality new build apartments in places like Sandton, Rosebank, Parkhurt, Bryanston etc and AMAZING quality restaurants e.g you can get an excellent fillet steak and a glass of wine for $15 in a high end restaurant. The going out scene was a little quiet but you could definitely find bars clubs open until 2/3 am. Meeting people I found easy as all the locals want to talk to you. A nomad wanting a high quality and cheap lifestyle I think would enjoy it. With that being said, Cape Town would be the better choice for a Nomad in South Africa.

joburg has been a great place to Nomad. Nice coffee shops in the Sandton, Parkhurst and Rosebank area. Very friendly people and fast internet. Rent is pretty cheap. Not much of a nomad scene but there were a decent amount of online entreprenuers around.

I have been to Jo berg twice. The last time being 3-years ago. Each visit was not pleasant as being in the city reminded me of being in Northern Ireland in the early 1980’s. I was in the British military and engaged in various bits and bobs in the most dangerous village in the country (based upon the number of security forces who lost there lives there). The reason I mention this is the ‘vibe’ in Jo Berg is exactly the same as it was in Northern Ireland’s ‘murder central’. The only exception is i was walking around without the comfort of a weapon in my hands and three other desperados backing me up (we operated in 4 man teams). I have had a look at the ‘scores’ section on Jo Berg and it is in no way representative of the situation on the ground. Whether you are an expat, nomad or a whatever please understand that Jo Berg is not a place to go ‘sight seeing’ in unless you have a couple SUV’s rammed with black water personnel following you. Joking aside there are better places to live in Southern Africa.

Johannesburg is a city in and the capital of South Africa. It is also the largest city in Africa. At an elevation of 2,389 metres (7,895 feet) above sea level, it is located at the centre of the Highveld area of the Transvaal Basin, on the east bank of the upper reaches of the Vaal River. It is one of the most developed cities in Africa, and is the major centre of South Africa's economy.

The city is ranked as the 22nd-largest city in the world, and the largest city in Africa, with a population of approximately four million, encompassing a metropolitan area of over ten million. Johannesburg is the largest of South Africa's four national, co-constitutional capital cities, which are also the largest cities in the country.

Johannesburg is usually called Joburg, its nickname, and has been known as the City of Gold, due to the large gold mining industry, the major source of its prosperity, in the late 19th and early 20th century. The Johannesburg Stock Exchange is one of the largest stock exchanges on the African continent. The city is a major centre for commerce, industry, entertainment, and culture. Gold is mined in Johannesburg, and many of the city's buildings have a mining theme.
johannesburg.description:
Johannesburg, also called Joburg by the locals, is a busy city with many surprises. Living here has good and bad points. The suburbs are lively—areas like Sandton, Rosebank, and Bryanston have nice coffee shops and great restaurants. You can find affordable meals and good steak dinners, which is good for your budget!

However, be careful in the city center, as it is known for crime. Many locals recommend staying in the suburbs and visiting cultural sites when you're with friends. Don't miss The Cradle of Humankind for interesting history, and make sure to visit The Kruger National Park—you will enjoy it!

Joburg has friendly locals and good weather, which helps newcomers feel at home. Just remember, safety is important—stay alert and take basic precautions. The nightlife might be quieter than in other cities, but there are still bars and clubs to enjoy. If you're looking for a mix of culture, friendliness, and fun, Joburg could be a good choice for you!
johannesburg.description_kor:
요하네스버그, 현지인들이 '조브룩'이라고 부르는 이 도시는 다양한 매력으로 가득한 분주한 곳입니다. 이곳에서의 삶에는 좋고 나쁜 점이 함께 존재합니다. 교외 지역은 굉장히 활기차며, 샌튼, 로즈뱅크, 브라이언스톤 같은 곳에는 멋진 커피숍과 훌륭한 레스토랑들이 많습니다. 저렴한 식사와 맛있는 스테이크 저녁을 찾기에도 딱 좋은 곳이에요!

하지만 도심 지역은 범죄율이 높다는 점에서 조심해야 합니다. 많은 현지인들이 교외에서 지내며 친구들과 함께 문화 유적지를 탐방하는 것을 추천합니다. ‘인류의 요람’ 같은 흥미로운 역사적인 장소는 꼭 방문해 보세요. 그리고 크루거 국립공원도 놓치지 말고 가보세요. 잊지 못할 경험이 될 거예요!

조브룩의 현지인들은 매우 친절하고 날씨도 좋기 때문에 새로 온 사람들에게 마치 집에 있는 듯한 느낌을 줍니다. 안전이 최우선인 만큼 항상 주의하고 기본적인 예방 조치를 잊지 마세요. 밤 문화는 다른 도시들에 비해 조용할 수 있지만, 여전히 즐길 수 있는 바와 클럽들이 있습니다. 문화와 친절함, 그리고 즐거움을 원한다면 조브룩이 훌륭한 선택이 될 것입니다!

reviews: There are some lovely communities to base yourself from with very reasonable rents. Check out Leisure Farm, Bayou Creek.

JB is developing nicely. Lot of ultra modern shopping centers, good food everywhere, ppl are more chill than in SGP. 
JB however can't seem to go the distance. Shops and new fashipnable areas are empty. Project disasters like the ghost Forest City. Frequently cancelled public transport projects. Healthcare is still questionable. (Lost 2 rellies to poor/wrong treatment in JB. One of them just recently.)
If JB just pulled off what they intend to do, it would be a great place. 
Still love visiting JB and could stay for extended time. The upsides are bigger than the downsides.

Johor is a dirty, ugly city across the causeway from northern Singapore. It's a very busy crossing both ways. I've been here many times to shop with my wife and MIL but have nothing to recommend. It was at least a cheap place to get glasses. Last time I went the 1MDB project had been launched to great fanfare in Johor. It was supposed to the the project that would unseat Singapore. It turned out to be a big scam and lots of people lost money, especially the Malay taxpayers. 
Other parts of Malaysia are fantastic (Borneo, Penang, KK, KL). Johor is kind of lousy. Got sick a few times eating there.
johor-bahru.description:
Johor Bahru, or JB as the locals call it, is a city with both good possibilities and some problems. Living here offers nice neighborhoods with affordable rents, especially in places like Leisure Farm and Bayou Creek. The food is plentiful and tasty, and there are many modern shopping centers, great for shopping. The atmosphere? It's more relaxed than its busy neighbor, Singapore.
