A really great island. One week before the full moon party it's full of tourists, and a great place to be single. After the party, it empties out completely except for locals, couples and expats. You don't need to go to the party and if it's not your thing you won't really notice. Still lots to do if you have a scooter and make some friends.

 It's not as touristic as Samui or Koh Tao. A scooter is absolutely necessary. If you can't drive you'll need a friend who can. There's a small nomad community and a couple of co working spaces. Overall it's a lovely island with many different scenes.
ko-pha-ngan.description:
Ko Pha Ngan is a place in Thailand that offers both relaxation and fun. You can find nice beaches, green mountains, and a relaxed atmosphere. However, the island feels quite western, with many tourists and fewer local people, which can make some wonder if they are really in Thailand.

For those who enjoy the beach and parties, the Full Moon Party is popular, but be careful as it can increase prices around the area. The cost of living has gone up recently, so look for deals if you are staying longer. Renting a scooter is important for getting around, but some visitors warn about the unpredictable driving you might see, so always wear a helmet!

Nature lovers will enjoy the island’s views and wellness options that include yoga and healthy food places. But if you are looking for a strong coworking scene, you might want to have lower expectations. There are a few coworking spaces, but most people here focus on a relaxed lifestyle rather than a regular work schedule.

In summary, whether you want to party, appreciate nature, or just relax with a drink, Ko Pha Ngan has something for everyone—just be aware of the atmosphere you are entering!
ko-pha-ngan.description_kor:
코팡안은 태국에 위치한 매력적인 섬으로, 휴식과 즐거움을 동시에 제공하는 곳입니다. 이곳은 아름다운 해변, 푸릇푸릇한 산, 그리고 느긋한 분위기로 유명합니다. 그러나 관광객이 많고 현지인은 적어 다소 서양적인 느낌이 강해, 진정한 태국에 있는지 의문을 갖게 할 때도 있습니다.

해변과 파티를 즐기는 사람들에게 특히 인기 있는 풀 문 파티가 있지만, 이로 인해 주변 물가가 상승할 수 있으니 주의가 필요합니다. 최근 생활비가 오르고 있으므로 장기 체류 계획이라면 혜택을 잘 찾아보는 것이 좋습니다. 이동을 위한 스쿠터 렌트는 필수지만, 독특한 운전 스타일 때문에 경험할 수 있는 예기치 않은 상황들에 대비해야 하니 항상 헬멧을 착용하세요!

자연을 사랑하는 분들은 섬의 경치와 요가, 건강식 음식점 등 웰니스 옵션을 즐길 수 있습니다. 하지만 강력한 코워킹 스페이스를 찾는 경우 기대치를 낮추는 게 좋습니다. 몇 군데 코워킹 공간이 있지만, 대다수의 사람들이 규칙적인 업무보다는 여유로운 라이프스타일에 더욱 집중하고 있습니다.

결론적으로, 파티를 즐기거나 자연을 감상하거나 간단히 음료와 함께 휴식을 취하고 싶다면 코팡안은 다양한 매력을 제공합니다—다만, 섬의 분위기에 잘 적응하는 것이 중요합니다!

reviews:
Ko Samui is an amazing place, I don't agree at all with the CON's. I am a Thai-American and have lived all over Thailand. Ko Samui is my favorite. The people, culture and experience of Ko Samui is wonderful. 
The roads are dangerous usually due to tourists. Not the locals LOL! This will be changing with Thai law requiring drivers license's. Of course it is humid and sweaty, my goodness you are in the tropics, and April is the hottest month. I suggest researching the best times of year to visit the islands, and Thailand in general. Most people go from A/C to A/C venues anyhow. The beaches and ocean are magical, the tours to the islands are so inexpensive and you have unique experiences diving, swimming, and meeting new people. In the tourist areas people will speak more English, but then again, you are in their country, there are many apps to help translate. Don't let these CONS deter you from the incredible people and beauty of Ko Samui.. it's our favorite place in Thailand.

We have been living here for 18 months, really love it, it took a while for the island to recover from Covid but general economic activity is back to say 60-70% now and we have two groups for digital nomads (meet monthly or so at various locations) and one for tech startups (Startup Samui on fb meets weekly) plus a few small coworking spaces and friendly cafes for nomads popping up. Our living costs are about $600/month for rent two bedroom+ house near beach and about the same again for food and bike rental and going out. We cook about 40% of the time and eat out mainly. Booze is extra, local beers cheap cocktails are a little expensive 150-250+thb. Air quality and saftey are excellent except need to be careful on roads with motor bikes. Very diverse expat scene.

I stayed in Taling Ngam in a villa at a place called Le Motu for almost a month. I can't recommend it enough. It's amazing, with a very secluded beach, fast wifi, a few great restaurants nearby. If you want to party this is not the area to stay, but if you're looking for a secluded area to just relax and get work done, the southern half of the island is great.

We have been living here for 12 months and love it. Airport is very central for the region and all major hubs. Supermarkets and local markets are plentiful and generally fairly priced especially makro and local. No power outages. Some minor internet fibre outages but mobile generally great. Air quality is excellent except for rare neighbours burning leaves :-) Lots of great beaches, we like the north and west as it is more quiet/family/couples but south and east have more excitement and are arguably more beautiful. Main choice is living on beach or living in hills w view. We are beach people mainly cause it saves 20 mins a day driving up/down and you don't have to plan to run/walk/swim. Prices not that different. We use bikes, 2500thb per month for a newish honda click 125 which is what most locals ride so repairs are cheap and instant. Diving is ok but your really want to do an overnight trip to nearby Koh Phangan or Koh Toa or Koh Team or Ang Thong all of which are close by. Samui is the hub and all the benefits flow from that, choice, price, availability, capacity, information etc... Lots of very long term interested expats what have settled with family, business, local spouse etc. Food panda and lazada and online food are great (and fast) for the things that are not easy to get. I had one bad experience with an oyster (my fault frankly) but otherwise no food poisoning issues. Lots of cool cafes, restaurants etc of all nationalities as in the good years they have 50,000 locals and 2m visitors. There is also a digital nomad group and a startup samui group both with hundreds of members here, nearby koh panghan has lots of crypto. First timers will find it a little expensive but you will soon work out where the local expats go and it is nice, inexpensive, authentic and supportive community. We love climbing waterfalls after rain, exploring new beaches and nearby islands (cheap long boats, sail only too), jet skiing, new restaurants, cafes, setting up the laptop in digital cafes and meeting people and the digital coffee groups.

Samui sucks and is to be avoided by nomads. It's not a nomad hotspot, at all. And probably won't ever become one.

Pros:
- Has an airport, so you can fly in straight from Bangkok and it only takes an hour
- Has nice villas you can rent with beautiful view over the ocean and Ko Phangan in the distance
- Grab and FoodPanda delivery food works okay here, although options are quite limited compared to Bangkok
- WiFi is good and fast around the island, no problems at all
- Driving a bike/scooter here is quite do-able as traffic is not that insane as in Bali or the rest of Thailand
- Nice place to go diving but honestly you're closer to the diving spots from Ko Phangan.
- Big C and Makro supermarkets have all the international food you can wish for like steak, baguettes and camembert, although the raw meat can be dodgy
- You can ship good frozen organic meat in here from Paleo Robbie from Bangkok (just Google this)

Cons:
- There is SO much food poisoning. Me and my 8 friends would get diarrhea every few weeks. It's not about local bacteria that you have to get immunity to, that's bs. You can't get immunity to local bacteria. It's just the food is prepared with bad hygiene, the meat isn't refrigerated and transported properly (see power cuts).
- There was only a few places that we confirmed as clean and we ordered there a lot with high quality food: especially Basilicom and Falafel Factory.
- The scene in Samui is mostly weekend tourists from Bangkok, low class expats who gave up on life with zero ambition and low class neon tanktop tourists in Chaweng who will blast their shitty music on Bluetooth speakers. My friends started calling Samui the "land of losers" cause that's what it feels like. This is not a foreigner opinion either: the Thai we spoke even from Samui would agree.
- Very few hipster cafes. I can count them on one hand. Most other cafes are Thai chains like Amazon and coffee is not good. Even fewer cafes where you can work in A/C
- The young/hipster/nomad scene on the Thai islands still isn't in Ko Samui, instead they're in Ko Pha Ngang (next door) and Ko Lanta (on the other/left coast of Thailand) and Phuket.
- Restaurants are really average but really expensive (see food poisoning above too), and very touristy but more like the touristy you know from your parents going to Thailand riding elephants and buying sarongs in the tourist shop inside the restaurant
- Regular power cuts, which usually also means the water stops running, so no shower, toilet, tap water etc. Unless your house/hotel/villa has a power generator (most don't), you're stuck without. Also AC won't work so it'll quickly become boiling hot inside your place
- In many ways Ko Samui is more expensive than Bangkok, because it's a tourist island and quite small
- Samui lacks a specific identity, it's unclear for who it is, I'd describe it as "Ko Meh"

Summary:
- Samui is nice if you come with a group, book a luxury villa and cook your own food. But then it gets boring after a few weeks.

Where to go instead?
- If you want an island place with nomad scene and hipster cafes, of course Canggu in Bali. Otherwise Ko Phangan, or Ko Lanta might be better. If you want a vibrant social scene go to the south of Phuket or Chiang Mai.

I spent 21 days here. Granted it was in Feb 2021 so there were not many tourists here, that made for a very enjoyable time experiencing the beautiful beaches and viewpoints without the swarm of wailing selfie sticks. Some very nice beach bars and cafes to work from with amazing views. A little more expensive than other areas of Thailand. If you go, a day visit to Ang Thong is a must. That place is just mesmerising.

I stuck here due COVID 19 quarantine. And it's best place to be right now. There are no big diifference compare to normal life. Locals are still friendly. Goverment doesn't pushes too much if you follow 2 simple rules: no partys due carantin and wear mask. Beaches are one of the best i've ever been and now they empty and even more clean. Food delivery works fine, Internet is good if you use your own line, and it's cheap to do. Great place to be here!

Samui is Thailand's second most popular island for tourists, after Phuket. The main areas are Chaweng and Lamai. Chaweng used to be more backpacker and trashy (like Bali's Kuta) but is now rapidly developing into a real clean town. Since 2014, it now has a giant air-conditioned Central World mall, an increasing number of coffee places, good restaurants and more upscale hotels and resorts. 

Lamai Beach used to be the more clean and laidback area but is now deteriorating. The beaches are still okay but the streets are now filled with sex bars and bad restaurants. Worse, prices in Lamai are often higher than in Chaweng due to less competition.

The preferrable spot to stay in Ko Samui now is the more mellow South Chaweng.
ko-samui.description:
Ko Samui is a popular place that many travelers talk about for its beautiful beaches, local culture, and friendly people. You can spend your time relaxing on the sand or taking cheap tours to nearby islands—the ocean here is very nice! While it can be very hot and humid, especially in April, the island has comfortable places to stay and many areas to find relief from the heat.

Now, let’s talk about the atmosphere. There are busy tourist areas like Chaweng, but some people feel it’s a mix—great for a relaxing vacation but can be a bit crowded and commercialized with common tourist issues. Traffic can be difficult, especially with scooters, but the relaxed vibe makes it easy to adapt. While the island has a good expat community, some visitors mentioned it doesn’t have the trendy feel found in places like Koh Phangan.

For those who enjoy food, be ready to explore; cleanliness can vary a lot, so it’s smart to go to trusted places. Still, with low living costs and good internet options, it’s easy to see why many people love Ko Samui. Enjoy the great views, discover quiet beaches, and don’t miss a day trip to Ang Thong—it’s worth it!
ko-samui.description_kor:
코사무이는 많은 여행자들이 아름다운 해변, 독특한 지역 문화, 그리고 친절한 사람들 덕분에 사랑하는 인기 있는 여행지입니다. 해변에서 여유롭게 쉬거나 인근 섬으로 저렴한 투어를 즐길 수 있습니다. 이곳의 바다는 정말 아름답답니다! 특히 4월에는 덥고 습할 수 있지만, 편안하게 지낼 수 있는 숙소와 더위를 피할 수 있는 다양한 장소들이 있어 걱정하지 않으셔도 됩니다.

이제 분위기에 대해 이야기해볼까요? 차웽 같은 관광지에서는 많은 사람들이 몰리지만, 일각에서는 여기서의 휴식이 다소 혼잡하고 상업적인 느낌이 든다고도 하더군요. 스쿠터가 많아 교통이 불편할 수도 있지만, 느긋한 분위기 덕분에 금방 적응할 수 있습니다. 이 섬에는 외국인 커뮤니티도 잘 형성되어 있지만, 일부 방문객들은 코팡안처럼 힙한 느낌이 부족하다고 언급하기도 했습니다.

음식을 좋아하는 분들은 미식 탐험을 준비하세요! 청결 상태가 제각각일 수 있으니 믿을 수 있는 장소를 선택하는 것이 중요합니다. 그럼에도 불구하고 저렴한 생활비와 안정적인 인터넷 덕분에 많은 사람들이 코사무이를 좋아하는 이유를 쉽게 알 수 있습니다. 멋진 풍경을 감상하고 조용한 해변을 탐험하며 앙통으로의 당일치기 여행도 꼭 즐겨보세요—정말 가볼 만한 곳입니다!

reviews: Lived in Kobe for 4 years now as a foreigner. Fantastic city, clean, very safe, lots to do and see, you have the mountains, the city and the sea so it’s perfect setting. Close to osaka, and only an hour from Kyoto. Lived here with young kids and there are some open spaces and fun family things to do with children. It’s all round a really great place to live.
kobe.description:
Kobe is a city that mixes city life with nature. Imagine living just minutes away from mountains, the busy city, and the sea – that's daily life in Kobe! The city is very clean and safe, making it a good place for families. With nice parks and activities for kids, there’s always something to do.

Being close to Osaka and about an hour from Kyoto means you can enjoy both cities. However, some people say that public transportation isn’t very extensive, so getting around might need some planning. The cost of living can be a bit higher compared to other cities, but many believe that the quality of life makes it worthwhile.

Don’t miss out on Kobe’s local customs, like enjoying their famous beef and walking along the waterfront. Just remember that while many locals understand basic English, learning a few Japanese phrases can be helpful here. Overall, Kobe is a good place to explore and live!
kobe.description_kor:
고베는 도심 생활과 자연이 조화롭게 어우러진 도시입니다. 산과 분주한 도시, 바다가 몇 분 거리에 있다는 상상을 해보세요. 이것이 바로 고베에서의 일상입니다! 이 도시는 매우 깨끗하고 안전하여 가족들에게 안성맞춤입니다. 아름다운 공원과 아이들을 위한 다양한 활동이 있어 항상 할 거리가 풍성합니다.

오사카와 가깝고 교토까지는 약 한 시간이면 도착할 수 있어 두 도시의 매력을 동시에 즐길 수 있습니다. 다만, 일부 사람들은 대중교통이 별로 넓지 않다고 말해 이동하기 위해서는 약간의 계획이 필요할 수도 있습니다. 생활비가 다른 도시들에 비해 약간 높은 편이지만, 많은 이들은 그만큼 삶의 질이 보장된다고 믿고 있습니다.

고베의 독특한 지역 문화도 놓치지 마세요. 예를 들어 유명한 고베 소고기를 맛보고 해안가를 여유롭게 걷는 것이죠. 많은 현지인들이 기본적인 영어를 이해하지만, 몇 가지 일본어 표현을 배우면 더욱 좋습니다. 전반적으로 고베는 탐험하기에도, 살기에도 훌륭한 곳입니다!

reviews: In Kolkata January 14-27 2020, staying within 10 blocks of the Park Street area. . I was enchanted. The juxtaposition of old and new, rich and poor, high-end retail and street fare was something to see. Apparently one of the cheapest places to rent in India, although I fell back on a hotel (I know, not very nomad).... Still, it was not bad. Internet was fast enough for research and posting work, but there are filters on access in various places in India, so for example I couldn't get my Tunnel to function here (may have just been my chosen access points filtered it). There are internet cafes (Starbucks, etc) in the Park Street area that I could use. English is widely (but NOT universally) understood, but you will also run up against Bengali, Hindi, and Urdu. The food is fabulous, with every possibility you can imagine (oh yeah, nice brewpubs and pizza for the unadventurous). Even if you are not a vegetarian, trust me, these folks can cook in ways that you won't miss meat (and this from a guy who likes BBQ). Currency exchange is best done at a bank, don't trust the ATM's that are stuck to the side of a building. Although the NomadList says otherwise, I was able to use my plastic for a lot of purchases- India is pretty progressive depending on where you are. Use a "Prepaid taxi" to get from the airport to town, which you can get from a booth inside the main terminal... Don't use UBER at the airport as the crazy insanity of the pickup area makes getting your ride nearly impossible (otherwise UBER in Kolkata is fine). I miss Kolkata, I will be back.
kolkata.description:
Kolkata is a lively city where the past and present meet. If you walk through the busy Park Street area, you'll see a mix of shops and street food stalls that show the city's culture and its diverse people. It is known to be one of the more budget-friendly places to stay in India, making it a good place to live. Internet access is generally good, but you may face some restrictions, so plan for that.

The food here is an interesting experience! Even if you eat meat, you'll be surprised at how tasty the vegetarian options are. Don’t miss local flavors, and for something different, visit the brewpubs in the area.

Getting around can be challenging. Public transport options are limited, so it’s best to use prepaid taxis from the airport, as finding an Uber can be difficult. While English is often spoken, knowing a little Bengali or Hindi can help. Just remember to exchange currency at banks, and you’ll be ready to enjoy your time in Kolkata!
kolkata.description_kor:
콜카타는 과거와 현재가 조화를 이루는 생동감 넘치는 도시입니다. 바쁜 파크 스트리트를 걸어가다 보면, 도시의 문화와 다양한 사람들을 보여주는 상점들과 길거리 음식 노점들이 어우러져 있는 모습을 쉽게 만날 수 있습니다. 인도에서 비교적 저렴한 숙소가 많아 살기 좋은 곳이기도 하죠. 인터넷 연결가 일반적으로 양호하지만, 가끔 제한이 있을 수 있으니 미리 계획하는 것이 좋습니다.

여기 음식은 정말 흥미로운 경험이에요! 육식 좋아하시는 분들도 채식 메뉴의 맛에 놀랄 거예요. 지역 특유의 맛을 꼭 즐겨보세요. 색다른 경험을 원하신다면, 이 지역의 브루펍에 한 번 가보는 것도 추천합니다.

이동하는 것은 조금 번거로울 수 있습니다. 대중교통 수단이 다소 제한적이기 때문에, 공항에서 사전 예약한 택시를 이용하는 것이 가장 편리합니다. 우버를 찾는 것은 조금 어려울 수 있어요. 영어는 통용되는 편이지만, 간단한 벵골어 혹은 힌디어를 아는 것이 도움이 될 수 있습니다. 마지막으로, 은행에서 환전하는 것도 잊지 마세요. 그러면 콜카타에서 멋진 시간을 보낼 준비가 완료됩니다!

reviews: Nice and laid back city with good infrastructure. 4G coverage was good
kota-kinabalu.description:
Kota Kinabalu is a relaxed city that acts as a gateway to some of Malaysia's natural beauty. You’ll enjoy visiting the busy markets, where the smell of local street food fills the air. The atmosphere here is friendly, which makes it a good place to relax.

One nice thing is the good infrastructure — getting around the city is easy. Most visitors appreciate the public services, and with reliable 4G coverage, staying connected is simple. However, keep in mind that English isn’t spoken everywhere, so knowing a few local phrases can be helpful.

In terms of safety, many people feel it is generally safe, but like in any city, it’s wise to watch your belongings. The cost of living is quite reasonable, making it affordable for both visitors and residents. For a true local experience, visit the waterfront to see a beautiful sunset or explore nearby beaches and hiking trails. Just remember to enjoy the slower pace of life — it’s part of what makes Kota Kinabalu special!
kota-kinabalu.description_kor:
코타키나발루는 말레이시아의 아름다운 자연을 만나는 편안한 도시입니다. 바쁜 시장을 거닐다 보면 현지 길거리 음식의 매력적인 향기가 코를 자극합니다. 이곳의 분위기는 매우 친근하여 편안하게 쉬기 좋은 장소입니다.

이 도시의 장점 중 하나는 뛰어난 인프라입니다. 덕분에 도시 내 이동이 용이합니다. 대부분의 방문객들은 공공 서비스에 만족하며, 안정적인 4G 통신 덕분에 계속해서 연결 상태를 유지할 수 있습니다. 다만, 영어가 모든 곳에서 통하지 않기 때문에 몇 가지 현지 표현을 알면 도움이 될 것입니다.

안전 부분에서는 많은 사람들이 코타키나발루를 일반적으로 안전하다고 느끼지만, 어떤 도시나 마찬가지로 개인 소지품에는 항상 주의하는 것이 좋습니다. 생활비는 꽤 합리적이며, 방문객과 현지 주민 모두에게 부담이 덜합니다. 만약 진정한 현지 경험을 원한다면 아름다운 해안에서 일몰을 감상하거나 인근 해변과 하이킹 코스를 탐방해 보세요. 느긋한 삶의 속도를 만끽하는 것도 잊지 마세요. 이게 코타키나발루의 특별한 매력 중 하나입니다!

reviews:
This is my hometown and a city I lived in for around 20 years of my life. If you want a place with a climate much warmer that Moscow and lower prices - look no further. This town would be great for you. In terms of speaking the language - you need to know Russian at certain degree, otherwise it might a bit a hard for you to navigate in the city. 
The main street of the city is Krasnaya street and you can take a bike and go through the whole street and enjoy the beauty and the peace of the city.
In terms of natural beauty, go to parks like Solnechniy ostrov, Dendrarium, Zaton, etc. Most likely you'll enjoy the most in the center of the city. If you need to go shopping look no further and go to "Gallery Krasnodar" - a huge shopping mall where you can eat, go to movies (in Russian of course, no subtitles) or shop for groceries.
Uber is widely used there, although it's operating under the brand Yandex.Taxi nowadays, so you might rather use that service in Russia.
Overall, a good city to live in and not expensive. If you want to eat cheap go to a small family-restaurants.
Air is quite polluted, unfortunately. Driving also not recommended. Streets are narrow and driving is chaotic.
If you want something nearby the sea consider Sochi - it's a bit more expensive, but more developed for foreigners, I think.
krasnodar.description:
Krasnodar is a city that many locals like for its warm weather and lower cost of living compared to larger cities like Moscow. If you want a friendly environment and nice parks, this is a good place for you. You can take a bike ride down Krasnaya Street, the main area, where you can enjoy the city's character.

Nature fans will appreciate the parks, such as Solnechniy Ostrov and the Dendrarium, which are good for walking or having picnics. If you want to shop, visit "Gallery Krasnodar," a large mall where you can eat, watch a movie, or shop. Just note that most movies are in Russian, so it might help to know some of the language.

You will enjoy the affordable living costs and friendly restaurants, but be aware of the air pollution and busy traffic—driving is not easy here. Uber works under Yandex.Taxi, which is useful for getting around. Overall, Krasnodar offers a mix of culture, nature, and warmth that makes it a nice place to live.
krasnodar.description_kor:
크라스노다르는 많은 현지인들이 모스크바 같은 대도시에 비해 따뜻한 날씨와 저렴한 생활비 덕분에 선호하는 도시입니다. 아늑한 분위기와 아름다운 공원을 원하신다면 이곳은 훌륭한 선택이 될 것입니다. 주요 거리인 크라스나야 거리를 따라 자전거를 타면서 도시의 매력을 만끽할 수 있습니다.

자연을 사랑하시는 분들은 솔네치니이 오스트로프와 덴드라륨 같은 공원을 매우 좋아하실 것입니다. 이곳은 산책이나 소풍을 즐기기에 안성맞춤입니다. 만약 쇼핑을 원하신다면 "갤러리 크라스노다르"를 방문해 보세요. 이곳은 식사, 영화 관람, 쇼핑을 모두 한곳에서 즐길 수 있는 대형 쇼핑몰입니다. 다만, 대부분의 영화가 러시아어로 상영되므로 일부 언어를 아는 것이 유리할 수 있습니다.

생활비가 저렴하고 친절한 레스토랑이 많지만, 공기 오염과 혼잡한 교통 상황에 주의해야 합니다. 이곳에서 운전하는 것은 쉽지 않을 수 있습니다. 우버와 야ндекс 택시가 함께 운영되니, 이동할 때 매우 유용합니다. 전반적으로 크라스노다르는 문화와 자연, 따뜻함이 어우러져 살기 좋은 매력적인 장소입니다.

reviews: Krabi is a nice weekend getaway if you stay in Bangkok and wanna escape the city for a few days. That being said, the best area for staying is Ao Nang beach. From here, you can go to the famous Railay beach with a longtail boat within 15 minutes and also the tours to Phi Phi and Hong Island start from here. There is a club called Upbeat Bar/Loft RNB in the middle of Ao Nang that gets kinda busy, although not super crowded in the rainy season. Maybe main season is different. Stay away from Krabi Town however, its just an ugly town without anything to do and its not possible to get a taxi to Ao Nang after 10-11pm. Stay around Ao Nang!
krabi.description:
Krabi is a great place to take a break from the busy life in Bangkok. Ao Nang beach is a good spot, offering a calm atmosphere and easy access to beautiful places like Railay beach, which you can visit by a short longtail boat ride. If you want to go island hopping, you can join tours to the lovely Phi Phi and Hong Island from here.

Although Krabi Town may not look very nice and can seem a bit dull, Ao Nang has a lively atmosphere with places like Upbeat Bar/Loft RNB, which is quite fun in the evenings. Just be aware—taxis can be hard to find in Krabi Town after 10 pm, so it’s better to stay in Ao Nang.

The cost of living here is affordable, but keep in mind that prices can go up during the busy season. With a mix of adventure and relaxation, Krabi is a nice place to explore!
krabi.description_kor:
크라비는 방콕의 바쁜 생활에서 벗어나 여유를 즐기기에 완벽한 곳입니다. 아오낭 비치는 조용한 분위기를 자아내며, 롤레 비치와 같은 멋진 명소에 쉽게 접근할 수 있는 장소입니다. 롤레 비치는 짧은 긴 꼬리 배를 타고 간편하게 다녀올 수 있습니다. 만약 섬 hopping을 원하신다면, 여기서 아름다운 피피 섬이나 홍 섬으로 가는 투어에 참여할 수 있습니다.

크라비 타운은 그리 매력적이지 않아 보일 수 있고 조금 지루하게 느껴질 수도 있지만, 아오낭에는 저녁 시간에 즐길 수 있는 Upbeat Bar와 Loft RNB 같은 신나는 장소들이 있어 활기찬 분위기를 만끽할 수 있습니다. 단, 10시 이후에는 크라비 타운에서 택시를 구하기 어려울 수 있으니, 아오낭에 머무는 것이 더 편리할 것입니다.

여기서의 생활비는 상대적으로 저렴하지만, 성수기에는 가격이 오를 수 있으니 이 점도 주의하세요. 모험과 휴식이 잘 어우러진 크라비는 탐험하기에 정말 좋은 곳입니다!

reviews:
Some feedback how Kuching looks like from my perspective these days (because I guess city vibe changed a lot since covid):

Place has a lot of potential but as of right now (mid-2023) it is just OKAY but kind of boring for staying longer than 1 month and having a base here for solo nomads. I was ready to bail after 2 weeks but committed for 1 month anyway

1. SOCIAL/COMMUNITY
This was the biggest drawback for me.
- There is no any community right now (or is dead by now), I'm not talking only about DN community but also there is no any FB Hiking Group, Board games group, Couchsurfing group etc.
- Get ready you won't meet ANY nomads within 1 month even if really trying hard and asking on different FB groups, Slacks etc.
- There is barely any couchsurfing travelers. Most people come here for 3-7 days, most of them are couples. Couchsurfing hangout is dead - met only one local girl and she told these days maybe 2 people a month wanna hangout
- If you travelling solo you will get bored after 2 weeks.
- there are some expats but mostly those are 50/60+ years old retired people and all expats even those younger mostly only active in their inner circles
- found it hard to make any friends with locals. Even when starting conversation yourself feels like pulling teeth...
- dating apps (tinder/bumble) also not helpful to get someone to have a coffee or lunch - looks like everybody has long covid, depressed or lazy to get out of home and do anything during weekends

2. COWORKINGS
There are 2 good coworkings (as a space): thegrounds and icube but:

Shared CONS:
- both are mostly empty (most of the time only 1-2 locals in open space, other locals in private offices -> you won't have much interaction with them)
- both open only from 8.00-18.00 and closed during weekends.
- zero initiative - no any members lunch or trying to make community alive

==Icube
- has WIFI speed only around 10MB/10MB (seems limited per user)
- only allow to login to WIFI with one device
- it's more far away from oldtown (but no problem if you have motorbike)
- hot desk are big NO NO - those are tiny circular desk and plastic chairs that are only OK to have a tea and chitchat
- cold desks are good but they have only 13 sits for those - most are rented by locals/companies but not used for 90% of days in a week -> I was only one nomad, place looked empty but still it was the last cold desk I could rent. During my 2 weeks on average there was 1-3 other people in open space

+ on the good side cold desk is very cheap and the price per week is pretty much the same -> don't need to commit for 1 month. But I don't like fixed desk -> harder to get to know someone if cowork is mostly empty
+ downstairs lots of shops for having a lunch
+ having more startup vibe look

==The Grounds
- freaking cold air-con (had to go with long pants and shoes instead of shorts + flip-flops and still felt cold)
+ pretty much inside downtown - don't need transport if living nearby
+ more modern look than icube
+ have 5 days flexible pass

2. INTERNET
I would say overall mobile internet is slow in Kuching. I tried both Digi and Yoodo (by Celcom). Even though speed test was showing 10MB/10MB often everything was very sluggish even when signal was strong (just simple website browsing, restaurant images in google maps, etc.)

3. ACTIVITIES/NATURE
- closest beach is ~40min away on motorbike (too far away to randomly each day go to see sunset and it's raining most of the evenings anyway), all beaches are very 'meh' (I though Penang or even Langkawi beach is meh but Kuching was even lower league). Probably not safe to swim (they have warning sign about "watch out crocodiles")
- even if you busy most of the week you can tick off most places worth to visit within 2 weekends
- nothing spectacular, sure there is wildlife center to see orangutans (if you lucky) but that's event only for like 2h
- national parks are ok but e.g. bako national park has only 2 routes open (those more interesting are closed)
- borneo culture museum or sarawak culture center was ok but nothing mind blowing (and not cheap)
+ the only thing that I liked is waterfront area during evening, musical fountain and vibe around there.

Now go search instagram for hashtag #Kuching or #sarawak for inspiration -> probably you won't find many interesting spots that are "must see"

4. WEATHER
- at least in whole May was raining a lot! pretty much every day mostly after 17.00 though. Raining is not like raining in thailand or indonesia that after 15-30min it stops and after another 30min everything is dry. When it's raining it will be raining probably for 1-2h minimum. This makes evenings more boring and need to force yourself to get out especially if you are on motorbike

5. COSTS
- not easy to find some decent accomodation on AirBnB for $1000 or less. I stayed in Kozi Square (many airbnbs there) for ~$550. Room was ok but tiny but a little better than most average hotels. I recommend to just rent Hotels weekly around waterfront instead

- motorbike for 1 month is around 600 RM but that's semi-automatic, if you want automatic it's 800 RM. Can drive only around Kuching. The semi automatic was very good though (waterproof phone holder, and waterproof storage in the back)
+ lots of hotel choices for around 20-30$ in downtown so don't have to commit for 1 month

As a rule of thumb cost of living is similar to Penang (though in Kuching accommodation rental cheaper) and around 2-3x of cost in Chiang Mai

6. TIPS
a) don't commit for 1 month upfront, better just commit for 2 weeks, see how much you like it or if you click with someone and then decide if worth to stay longer or go to e.g. Sabah instead
b) choose accommodation in walking distance to waterfront (oldtown/chinatown). This is where city is most alive in the evening and even if you are 5min away on motorbike like me was, it's still better to be there because often raining and easier to meet some random travelers randomly walking
c) this is not Thailand. Many places closes at 15.00 or 17.00. Other only opens at 17.00 but stay open until 22.00. Most places outside of waterfront area will be closed very early (before 18.00). Even most food places around iCube cowork closes before 18.00. The good things is that easier to find place open for breakfast.
d) you will probably have better experience if not traveling solo but with partner or travel-mate and co-living (can share nicer flat and car, feeling less boring)
e) consider first 2 days staying maybe in some nicer social hostel - at least you can maybe meet some travelers and do something together. Or even maybe renting better single room in some nicer hostel if you are solo nomad (even if it's less comfortable than having own studio/condo)
f) many AirBnB places have not good WIFI (because using mobile internet instead of wired) - double check it before renting since remember coworking spaces are only open between 8.00-18.00 and closed during weekends.

Kuching is a great place to base yourself, it's a vibrant yet quiet little city with access to all sorts of outdoor activities. I stayed at the Borneo Seahare Guesthouse for about 5 months. It is run by a western guy called Ben and his wife Syeda, they really helped me out with everything I needed and gave me a very reasonable rate on a private room. The internet was good and the place had everything I needed including a full kitchen for me to cook. Based right in the city center with loads of shops, restaurants and bars close by. I can highly recommended Kuching its a wonderful city and I will be returning next year for sure!
kuching.description:
Kuching, the capital of Sarawak, is a small place ready to be discovered. It is a relaxed city surrounded by nature and culture, but it has some oddities. The atmosphere has changed a bit after COVID, and while it is a good place for short visits, staying for a long time can be a bit boring, especially for those traveling alone. Community life seems to have decreased—finding other travelers or locals to meet may take some effort.

On the positive side, Kuching has nice co-working spaces like The Grounds and iCube, although they can be quite calm. The cost of living is fair, and you can find comfortable places to stay near the busy waterfront, which comes alive at night with its musical fountain and lively scene.

Nature fans can visit nearby national parks and see orangutans, but be aware that some paths may be closed. In terms of weather, be ready for some rain, especially in the evenings. Renting a motorbike is a great option if you want to explore outside the city.

So, whether you are walking along the waterfront or relaxing in a local café, Kuching is a special mix of calmness and possibilities waiting for you!
kuching.description_kor:
쿠칭(Kuching)은 사라왁(Sarawak)의 수도로, 가볼 만한 매력적인 작은 도시입니다. 자연과 문화가 어우러진 느긋한 분위기를 가지고 있지만, 몇 가지 독특한 특징이 있습니다. COVID 이후에 어느 정도 분위기가 변했으며, 짧은 여행에는 적합하지만 혼자 여행하는 경우에는 장기간 머무르기 다소 지루할 수 있습니다. 지역 사회의 활동이 줄어든 것 같아 타 여행자나 현지 주민과의 만남을 위해 조금의 노력이 필요할 수 있습니다.

긍정적인 점으로는 쿠칭에 있는 더 그라운드(The Grounds)와 아이큐브(iCube)와 같은 훌륭한 공동 작업 공간이 있지만, 이곳은 꽤 조용할 수 있습니다. 생활비는 적당하며, 밤이 되면 음악 분수와 함께 활기 넘치는 해안가에서 여유로운 숙소를 찾을 수 있습니다.

자연을 좋아하시는 분들은 가까운 국립공원을 방문해 오랑우탄을 볼 수 있지만, 일부 보행로는 폐쇄될 수 있으니 주의가 필요합니다. 날씨에 관해서는 특히 저녁에 비가 올 가능성이 있으니 준비를 하셔야 합니다. 도시 외곽을 탐험하고 싶다면 오토바이를 렌트하는 것이 아주 좋은 선택입니다.

따라서 해안가를 따라 산책하거나 지역 카페에서 느긋한 시간을 보내든, 쿠칭은 당신에게 차분함과 다양한 가능성을 동시에 제공하는 특별한 장소가 될 것입니다!

reviews:
We loved our time in Krakow this July and August. The city exceeded our expectations with its charm and affordability. There are so many great restaurants that are affordable, and getting around couldn’t be easier. Whether you're walking, biking, or hopping on a tram, everything is within reach and super budget-friendly.

I was worried Krakow might be overhyped, but honestly, it’s still underrated in my opinion. Yes, there’s a noticeable amount of tourism, and prices have risen like everywhere else, but it’s still a very affordable city if you’re mindful.

Winter might be a different story, but we’ve definitely found our new summer base.

It is cold, and dark, and sad in the winter and fall and spring. people are hard to meet and connect with. food is bland. the old town is nice, but small. not much to do. lots of locals try to convince tourist to go into seedy strip clubs where there are scams.

I lived in Kraków for 13 years. Before I was nomad I worked in Kraków from office, studied here. I see lots of reviews mention Stare Miasto. In fact biggest gem these days is Podgórze neighbourhood, for lots of locals and expats this is trending area now. It's close to old town an to Kazimierz and has growing numbers of restaurants and delicatessen of various cusines, besides Polish mostly Italian, Jewish, Middle-Eastern, Georgian, Ukrainian, Indian. You can see it's reflected on the neighbourhoods map. In free time after working you can do lot's stuff like go for walk by the river, party in Forum, go to tourist areas in Old Town and Kazimierz, go to gym, train martial arts like Krav Maga, Boxing, go for kayak or SUP in river, in summer spend time by lakes in Zakrzówek or Kryspinów. You can enjoy nature in Las Wolski. You can play football in Góra Parkowa or watch game of Perła Kraków, even try playing for class C football club if you like. There's also lot's of cool museums and cool stuff to do.
I'm Polish and after being an expat nomad for 10+ years I returned to stay in Kraków. It truly is a gem of this region and my favorite small city

Incredible city for nomads. In autumn/winter you'll have to deal with the cold, but there's still stuff going on.

- Using the tram and uber was rare. Stay in Kazimierz or Stare Miasto and you get anywhere interesting in

I studied here. Old town is too busy with tourists to live in for my tase, but there are plenty of districts to choose from. Accommodation is cheap, and you can get mobile data plan in every convenience store. It's also quite safe - local girls aren't afraid to walk alone after dawn. Just don't bother drunk people in front of the bar and you will be fine.

Also if you didn't take some 1-2 day tours to nearby places you're missing out: Wieliczka, Energylandia, Zakopane, Auschwitz. Air quality and temperature in the winter can be annoying, but in case you find yourself there when it is snowing, grab a hot beer "grzaniec".

Krakow is a brilliant city to live and work from. Friendly, easy to get around (usually able to walk everywhere), great internet and busy nightlife. Really pretty city, too. Kazimierz, the old Jewish district, is the obvious place to live. Loads of great cafes and other digital nomads there.
I was there during the summer when it was between 24 and 30 degrees each day, which is perfect. No doubt a different experience in the winter, though!

Enjoyed Krakow. I was only there for 4 days which I think was perfect. It's a small big city with a beautiful old town square, great restaurants, fun sites, and good history. But if I stayed for a month or longer I believe it would have become a tad too small and boring for myself. Personally, enjoy Warsaw (where I have been for a month) more than Krakow if you're debating between the two Polish cities.
Really enjoyed Krakow, it is the perfect 'small city'. Will definitely be returning!
I visited Krakow 10 years ago and it was one of my favorite cities. This recent trip destroyed that memory. Very hard to find good wifi. Small city.

Krakow is my favorite city !
Cheap - you can buy a lunch in around 4$, and rent apartments in the center in around 600EUR. take an uber in less than 3 EUR

Friendly - The locals are very friendly and cool and easy to connect with. there is a lot of expats there so there is enough things to do. also i never had problem with language.. they all know english well

Beautiful - its one of the most beautiful cities i've been at - even more than prague.. everything here maintained like hundreds years ago and be in the old town is magical

Clean - the city is extremely clean

I lived in Stare Miasto for a year and loved it. As an American who doesn't speak the language I had no problem getting anywhere, felt safe the entire time and genuinely loved my time spent here. 

Internet was faster than anywhere I've seen in the US, the food was delicious, the nightclubs don't close until daylight and the entire City is inexpensive. 

Since I left it seems that racial tensions are growing and I'm hearing from Asian friends that they are being harassed more than ever before. I don't think is much of an issue if you're in the old town tourist area (Stare Miasto) as opposed to the more rural areas of Krakow...but for this reason I'm not going to move back anytime soon.
krakow.description:
Kraków is a city in Poland that combines history and modern life. Visitors may find it affordable, with meals costing around $4 and apartments for under €600. While many enjoy the Old Town’s cobblestone streets, neighborhoods like Podgórze and Kazimierz offer local food and various restaurants.

Getting around is easy, whether you walk, bike, or take the tram. The city is mostly safe, with friendly locals who speak English and are willing to help, making it simple for newcomers to adjust. However, keep in mind that winter can be cold and dark, with fewer social activities.

For great experiences, don’t miss nearby places like the Wieliczka Salt Mine and the beautiful Zakopane. The local nightlife is active, especially in the summer when the city is full of life and events. Whether you visit for a weekend or a longer stay, Kraków has a mix of history and lively culture to offer.
krakow.description_kor:
크라쿠프는 역사와 현대적 생활이 조화를 이루는 폴란드의 매력적인 도시입니다. 방문객들은 식사가 약 4달러 정도이고, 아파트도 600유로 이하로 저렴하다는 사실에 놀랄 것입니다. 많은 사람들이 구시가지의 아기자기한 자갈길을 즐기고, 포드구르제(Podgórze)와 카지미에르(Kazimierz) 같은 이웃 지역에서는 다양한 지역 음식과 식당을 경험할 수 있습니다.

이 도시는 걷거나 자전거를 타거나 트램을 이용해 쉽게 돌아다닐 수 있어 매우 편리합니다. 대체로 안전한 도시이며, 영어를 구사하는 친절한 현지인들이 많아 처음 오는 사람들도 빠르게 적응할 수 있습니다. 하지만 겨울철에는 춥고 어두워질 수 있으며, 사회 활동이 줄어든다는 점도 염두에 두셔야 합니다.

특별한 경험을 원하신다면 가까운 웨일리치카 소금광과 아름다운 자코파네를 꼭 방문해 보세요. 현지의 밤문화도 활기차고, 특히 여름철에는 도시가 생기와 다양한 이벤트로 가득 차기 마련입니다. 주말 여행이든 긴 체류든, 크라쿠프는 역사와 활기찬 문화를 모두 즐길 수 있는 도시입니다.

reviews: Kyoto is definitely one of the most beautiful cities I’ve ever stayed in - my only regret was not staying longer and spending more time in Tokyo.
kyoto.description:
Kyoto is a lovely city, often noted by visitors as one of the most beautiful places they have seen. Imagine walking through old temples next to quiet gardens or walking along streets that feel like the past. The city has a strong culture, with famous tea ceremonies and traditional kaiseki meals that let you taste real Japanese food.

However, some people think the cost of living is a bit high, and they say that public transportation can be difficult. The bus system is good, but it is not as big as in larger cities like Tokyo, so plan your travel in advance! In terms of safety, Kyoto is usually very safe, making it easy to walk around, even at night.

Make sure to visit popular sites like Kinkaku-ji, the Golden Pavilion, or the lively Arashiyama Bamboo Grove! Just remember to follow local customs, like being quiet in temples. If you want a special experience, spend some time in the Gion district, where you might see a maiko, a geisha apprentice. Overall, take your time here—you may wish you could stay longer!
kyoto.description_kor:
교토는 사랑스러운 도시로, 방문객들이 손꼽는 가장 아름다운 장소 중 하나입니다. 조용한 정원 옆을 거닐며 오랜 사원을 탐방하거나, 과거의 분위기가 느껴지는 거리를 걷는 모습을 상상해 보세요. 이 도시는 전통적인 다도와 정통 일본 요리인 가이세키로도 유명하며, 강한 문화적 전통을 자랑합니다.

다만, 몇몇 사람들은 생활비가 조금 높다고 느끼기도 하며, 대중교통이 다소 불편할 수 있다고 이야기합니다. 교토의 버스 시스템은 괜찮지만, 도쿄와 같은 대도시에 비해 규모가 작기 때문에 여행 계획을 미리 잘 세우는 것이 좋습니다. 안전 측면에서 교토는 일반적으로 굉장히 안전하여, 밤에도 걱정 없이 걸어다닐 수 있습니다.

금각사와 같은 인기 명소와 생동감 넘치는 아라시야마 대나무 숲은 꼭 들러보세요! 또한 사원 방문 시 지역의 관습을 존중하며 조용히 하는 것을 잊지 마시길 바랍니다. 특별한 경험을 원하신다면 기온 지구에서 시간을 보내보세요. 이곳에서는 마이코(게이샤 견습생)를 만날 기회도 있을 것입니다. 전반적으로 이곳에서 여유롭게 시간을 보내세요—아마도 더 오래 머물고 싶어질지도 모릅니다!

reviews:
I stayed one month (28 male) in La Paz and during this time I worked in Selina Cowork. No problem with INTERNET, both at home and Selina I've had at least 20 mb/s on WiFi connection. I felt very SAFE compared to other latam countries, the city is very calm and also CHEAP. Bolivians from La Paz are very nice people, a bit more reserved but I was able to make friends anyway. There are no big expats groups / digital nomads, however there are some hostels where one can go for a party and meet some international people.
Although the city is pretty small (less than 1 million) it's a good point to see Bolivia and area, it has great culture to explore there are comfortable buses going to Uyuni and other places in Bolivia, so it's a good point to see other parts of Bolivia. Especially that staying in the city gets one accustomed to the altitude. It's both amazing city and the country and makes for a memorable stay.

La Paz and Bolivia in general is a very interesting place to visit!
The city is fairly cold all year around, and so is the hotels and restaurants… basically make sure to bring warm clothes.

The city is messy, ugly and unorganized, but the city have a character! The surroundings of the nature and environment around is amazing, beautiful mountains and such.

When getting a SIM card it is 3G and LTE.
I never found Wi-Fi reaching 10 Mbps (At the Selina Hostel where I stayed).

Prices here doesn’t make sense. You basically never know if a bottle of 0,5 water is going to cost you 30 cent or 3 USD. I’ve eaten a burger that cost as much as 5 courses fine dining meal. And so on.

I always felt very safe in this city. There is a lot of poverty, but I didn’t find them as aggressive as in example Rio de Janeiro.

There is plenty of things to do here: 
Death road cycling, Moon Valley, Weekend trip to Uyuni, and also going out in this city (They have a similar drinking culture as the UK when the brits go on vacation to Spain)
la-paz.description:
La Paz, Bolivia, is a city that may surprise you with its charm. Located high in the mountains, it is a place where the beautiful surroundings are almost as interesting as the lively culture. Visitors often say that the locals are friendly, even if they can be a bit reserved at first. You are likely to meet new friends around the hostels, especially if you want to have a good time!

While the city might seem a bit messy and chaotic, it is part of its character. Remember to pack some warm clothes since temperatures can drop, and you will want to stay warm while exploring. The public transport is fairly good with comfortable buses to places like Uyuni, making it easy to travel beyond La Paz.

Travelers talk about activities like cycling the famous Death Road and visiting Moon Valley. However, be ready for some differences in prices - a 0.5-liter water bottle can cost anywhere from 30 cents to 3 dollars! For those looking for safety, La Paz feels more peaceful compared to many other Latin American cities, making it a good place to experience Bolivian life and culture.
la-paz.description_kor:
라파스, 볼리비아는 그 매력으로 당신을 놀라게 할 도시입니다. 높은 산속에 자리한 이 도시는 아름다운 자연경관과 활기찬 문화가 어우러져 흥미로운 분위기를 자아냅니다. 방문객들은 현지인들이 친절하다고 입을 모으기도 하지만, 처음에는 조금 내성적인 모습을 보일 수 있습니다. 특히 즐거운 시간 보내고 싶다면 호스텔 주변에서 새로운 친구들을 만날 기회가 많습니다!

도시는 다소 복잡하고 혼잡할 수 있지만, 그 또한 도시의 독특한 매력의 일부분입니다. 기온이 떨어질 수 있으니 따뜻한 옷을 챙기는 것을 잊지 마세요. 탐방 중에는 따뜻함을 유지하는 것이 중요합니다. 대중교통이 잘 되어 있어, 우유니 같은 다른 지역으로의 이동도 편리한 버스가 있습니다.

여행자들은 유명한 데스 로드에서 자전거를 타거나 문 계곡을 방문하는 경험에 대해 많이 이야기합니다. 그러나 가격 차이에 유의해야 합니다. 0.5리터 생수 한 병의 가격이 30센트에서 3달러까지 다양하니까요! 안전을 중시하는 사람들에게 라파스는 다른 많은 라틴 아메리카 도시들보다 덜 위험하게 느껴질 수 있으며, 볼리비아의 삶과 문화를 체험하기에 좋은 장소입니다.

reviews: Best suited for surfers..
la-union.description:
La Union, often called the "Surfing Capital of the North," is a relaxing place in the Philippines that many people enjoy. If you’re a surfer or just like the beach, this place is great. The waves here are good for all skill levels, so whether you're experienced or just starting, you will have a good time!

The local culture is lively, with friendly people who are always happy to help. The cost of living is quite affordable, making it a good place for both locals and visitors. Although public transportation can be limited, getting around by tricycle or renting a scooter can be fun.

Some people find the language barrier a bit difficult, but a few friendly gestures can help a lot. Be sure to visit the nearby waterfalls and local markets for a taste of Filipino culture.

In summary, La Union offers a mix of relaxation and fun, making it a nice getaway for anyone wanting to enjoy the sun and surf!
la-union.description_kor:
라 유니온, 흔히 "북부의 서핑 수도"라고 불리는 이곳은 필리핀에서 많은 사람들이 쉽고 편안하게 즐길 수 있는 장소입니다. 서핑이나 해변을 좋아하는 분들께 이곳은 최적의 선택이 될 것입니다. 이곳의 파도는 모든 수준의 서퍼에게 적합하여, 초보자든 숙련자든 상관없이 즐거운 시간을 보낼 수 있습니다!

현지 문화는 정말 활기차고, 언제나 도움을 주려는 친절한 사람들이 많습니다. 생활비가 비교적 저렴하여 지역 주민 뿐만 아니라 방문객들에게도 좋은 환경을 제공합니다. 대중교통은 조금 제한적일 수 있지만, 트라이시클이나 스쿠터를 빌려 다니는 것도 즐거운 경험이죠.

일부 분들은 언어 장벽 때문에 어려움을 느낄 수도 있지만, 몇 가지 간단한 제스처로 충분히 소통할 수 있습니다. 필리핀 문화를 제대로 느끼고 싶다면 근처의 폭포와 현지 시장을 꼭 방문해 보세요.

결론적으로, 라 유니온은 휴식과 재미가 조화를 이루는 곳으로, 태양과 서핑을 즐기고 싶은 모든 이들에게 완벽한 여행지입니다!

reviews:
Pakistani people are amazing and as long as you get enough data on your phone (20GB goes for about 4$) internet is not an issue at all. All hotels have Wi-Fi and even though not always great, generally it's good enough.

Like I said, Pakistani people are incredible and the food is super super cheap. You'll have a hard time spending more than 10$ in a day. Next to that, you're gonna be the only foreigner in Lahore, even though it's such a big city. Most people have never seen a foreigner and are very happy to be your friend. 

They'll never ask anything of you and actually, will want to pay EVERYTHING for you. Your drinks, your food... no way a Pakistani is gonna let you pay. 

Lahore is an amazing town with lots to discover and an amazing culture.

The downsides are the heavy pollution, not only the air, but also the trash people leave on the streets. Cars keep honking at each other for fun, including noise pollution. If you can get over that, it's an amazing place to stay for a week to a few weeks.
lahore.description:
Lahore is a busy city full of life, culture, and friendly people. You can walk through the crowded streets where you might be the only foreigner—locals are happy to smile and welcome you. The food is great; you can enjoy a filling meal for just a few dollars! Most hotels have Wi-Fi, so it's easy to stay connected, especially with cheap mobile data plans.

However, be ready for some challenges of city living—pollution can be a problem, with air quality and litter being clear issues. The traffic is busy, with many cars honking.

If you want to explore, don’t miss the interesting history and parks in Lahore. Just remember to have some cash, as many locals like to pay when eating out. Neighborhoods to visit include Gulberg and DHA for a mix of modern comforts and local culture. Get ready for a memorable experience in this lively and friendly city!
lahore.description_kor:
라호르는 생명력 넘치고 문화가 풍부하며, 친절한 사람들로 가득한 바쁜 도시입니다. 여기에서 사람들로 붐비는 거리 속을 걸으면, 당신이 유일한 외국인일지도 모릅니다. 하지만 현지인들은 기꺼이 미소를 지으며 당신을 따뜻하게 맞아줍니다. 음식은 정말 훌륭하고, 몇 달러만으로도 푸짐한 식사를 즐길 수 있습니다! 대부분의 호텔에서 Wi-Fi를 제공하니, 저렴한 모바일 데이터 요금제로 언제든지 편리하게 인터넷에 연결할 수 있습니다.

하지만 이 도시 생활에도 몇 가지 도전이 따를 수 있습니다. 오염은 큰 문제이며, 공기 질과 쓰레기 문제가 명백한 이슈로 떠오릅니다. 교통은 상당히 혼잡하고, 많은 차량들이 경적을 울리곤 합니다.

탐험을 원하신다면, 라호르의 흥미로운 역사와 아름다운 공원들을 놓치지 마세요. 외식을 선호하는 많은 현지인들이 현금을 이용하니, 현금 준비는 잊지 마세요. 현대적인 편안함과 지역 문화를 조화롭게 갖춘 굴버그와 DHA 같은 동네를 방문해보시는 것도 좋습니다. 이 활기차고 따뜻한 도시에서 잊지 못할 경험을 준비하세요!

reviews:
Lake Balaton is Eastern Europe's treasure, an expansive freshwater lake that offers a medley of activities and experiences for both tourists and the growing nomadic community. But there are a few pointers and oddities that digital nomads, in particular, should be aware of.
🌍 **Neighbourhood Map Inaccuracy** 
Firstly, I was quite surprised to find that NomadList's neighbourhood map for Lake Balaton is somewhat inaccurate. For a start, it glaringly omits Siófok, which is probably the largest city by the lake. Siófok isn't just a popular summer destination but an essential point of reference for anyone considering Lake Balaton as a potential remote work destination.
👩‍💻 **Co-working Spaces** 
To my knowledge, the region's most notable coworking space is "AZ iroda - Közösségi Iroda, Coworking Office Balaton", conveniently located in Balatonfüred. It's a charming, functional space that adds a touch of modernity to the largely traditional locale.

🏖️ **Attractions & Activities** 
Lake Balaton has a range of neighbourhoods, each brimming with its unique attractions. Swimming, fishing, and sailing are the staples here, with the lake's calm waters inviting all and sundry. For the thrill-seekers, the hyper jet 800 HP boat tours offer an adrenaline-infused experience of the lake's vastness. As the sun sets, the lakeside towns, each with their distinct character, beckon with their laid-back vibes and scenic views.

📡 **Connectivity** 
If you're relying on internet connectivity, here's the deal: Mobile internet speeds are impressive if you're equipped with an EU SIM. However, WiFi in public places, cafes, and hotels can often be disappointingly slow. So, a good cellular data plan would be your best bet.
👩‍💼 **Nomadic Potential** 
Despite its charm, Lake Balaton hasn't become a hotspot for digital nomads. Perhaps it's the tranquillity or the seasonal attractions, but it feels more like a place for relaxation and holidays than intense productivity. That said, its serenity, combined with its budding infrastructure, gives it untapped potential.
🕰️ **A Blast From the Past** 
A peculiar charm of some parts of Lake Balaton is that they feel as if they've been preserved in amber since 1989. This has both its pros and cons. On the upside, there's an authentic, untouched feel to these places. However, the flip side is that they might lack some modern amenities that digital nomads take for granted. Most people are super friendly, more friendly in ex eastern block countries, however some are still stuck in homo sovieticus mindset. Also there are some tourist traps, beware.
**Verdict**: Lake Balaton, with its quaint towns and vast expanses of freshwater, is more of a holiday destination than a digital nomad hotspot. But with a few tweaks and broader awareness, this Hungarian gem could shine brighter in the nomadic world. For now, it remains a delightful secret, ideal for relaxation and short-term stays.
⭐⭐⭐☆☆
lake-balaton.description:
Lake Balaton is a well-known lake in Eastern Europe. This large freshwater lake offers many activities for everyone, from those who want to relax in the sun to those looking for adventure. You can swim in the calm waters, fish from the shore, or take an exciting jet boat ride. Each town by the lake has its own feel, inviting you to check out small cafes and watch beautiful sunsets.

If you plan to stay longer, Siófok is a place you should visit; it's the biggest city in the area and very busy. Balatonfüred also has a co-working space that provides modern comfort while keeping some traditional charm, but don't expect very fast WiFi everywhere.

While the local culture feels friendly, it's important to know that some places may seem a bit old-fashioned. You might find a lack of modern conveniences at times, and language differences can occur, so having a basic Hungarian phrasebook could be useful.

If you want a holiday away from the busy city, Lake Balaton is a great choice!
lake-balaton.description_kor:
발라톤 호수는 동유럽에서 널리 알려진 아름다운 호수입니다. 이 거대한 담수호는 태양을 만끽하고 싶은 사람들부터 모험을 즐기고 싶은 사람들까지 다양한 활동을 제공합니다. 고요한 호수에서 수영을 하거나, 해안에서 낚시를 하거나, 짜릿한 제트 보트를 타며 스릴을 느낄 수 있습니다. 호수 주변의 각 마을은 독특한 매력을 뽐내고 있어, 아기자기한 카페를 탐방하거나 멋진 일몰을 감상하는 것을 추천합니다.

좀 더 오래 머무를 계획이라면, 시오폭(Siófok)을 꼭 들러보세요. 이곳은 이 지역에서 가장 큰 도시로 정말 활기찬 분위기를 가지고 있습니다. 발라톤퓌레드(Balatonfüred)에도 현대적인 편안함과 함께 전통적인 매력을 유지하는 코워킹 스페이스가 있지만, 빠른 WiFi는 기대하지 않는 것이 좋습니다.

현지 문화는 친근하지만, 일부 장소는 다소 구식으로 느껴질 수 있다는 점을 유의해 주세요. 때때로 현대적인 편의시설이 부족할 수 있으며, 언어 소통에 어려움이 있을 수도 있습니다. 따라서 기본적인 헝가리어 회화책을 챙기는 것이 유용할 수 있습니다.

분주한 도시를 벗어나 휴식을 원하는 분들께, 발라톤 호수는 정말 훌륭한 선택입니다!

reviews: Not quite as bad as Paphos, but still quite ugly and empty feeling, and, as with everywhere in Cyprus, way too expensive for what you get.

I was in Larnaca for 10 days at the end of February. I cannot recommend this city in this part of the year.

It feels really cold because it is very windy and there is not much you can do.
larnaca.description:
If you go to Larnaca, you might see that it has a mix of feelings. It is not as crowded as some other places in Cyprus, but it has its own appeal—think of it as a place that might surprise you if you take some time to explore. The waterfront is nice, but some visitors feel the city can seem a bit quiet and not very lively, especially in the quieter months like February when the wind can be strong and temperatures drop.

The cost of living can feel high for what you get, so it is important to budget carefully. Public transport is available, but many find it not very good, so renting a car can be a good choice for seeing nearby areas. Safety does not seem to be a big concern, which is a positive point!

While you explore, don't miss the Church of Saint Lazarus and the pleasant promenade with cafes. Just remember to dress appropriately if you visit in the off-season—windy weather can catch you by surprise! Overall, Larnaca shows a different side of Cyprus that is worth visiting, just keep your expectations in check.
larnaca.description_kor:
라르나카를 가면 다양한 감정을 느낄 수 있습니다. 사이프러스의 다른 지역에 비해 덜 혼잡하지만, 그 자체로 매력을 지닌 곳이에요. 조금만 시간을 내서 탐험해보면 정말 놀라운 곳이라는 걸 깨닫게 될 거예요. 해변이 아름답긴 하지만, 어떤 방문객들은 이 도시가 다소 조용하고 활기차지 않다고 느낄 수도 있어요. 특히 바람이 강하고 기온이 떨어지는 2월 같은 한산한 달에는 그 느낌이 더 강할 수 있습니다.

제공되는 것에 비해 생활비가 조금 비싸게 느껴질 수 있으니, 예산을 잘 세우는 게 중요해요. 대중교통이 있긴 하지만 많은 사람들이 그 수준에 불만을 갖고 있어서, 주변을 탐험하기 위해 자동차를 렌트하는 것도 좋은 선택일 수 있어요. 안전 문제는 큰 걱정거리가 아니라는 점이 긍정적이에요!

탐방하는 동안 성 라자루스 교회와 느긋하게 앉아있기 좋은 카페가 있는 산책로를 꼭 놓치지 마세요. 비수기에 가면 적절한 복장을 갖춰야 해요—바람이 세게 불 수 있으니까요! 전체적으로 라르나카는 사이프러스의 색다른 매력을 보여주는 곳이며, 기대는 적당히 하는 게 좋습니다.

reviews: Ungodly hot year round, but some cool things to see. Can't imagine working from here, but it a cool enough place to visit for a few days if you can stand the heat. Volcano boarding is a great time!
leon.description:
Leon, Nicaragua, is a lively city, especially if you can deal with the heat! Expect warm weather all year, which can be a lot, but that shouldn’t stop you from enjoying the area's special experiences. There are many interesting places to see, like old colonial buildings and busy markets with local crafts.

One of the most fun activities here is volcano boarding—yes, you get to slide down a volcano! It's an exciting way to enjoy the beautiful scenery.

While the heat might make you think twice about staying long, Leon is great for a few days of exploration. Be ready for some limited public transportation, but walking around town is a good way to enjoy the local feel. When visiting, drink plenty of water and wear a hat! Local people are friendly; just remember to respect the slower pace of life here. Overall, Leon offers a unique experience that’s definitely worth a visit!
leon.description_kor:
레온, 니카라과는 정말 활기찬 도시로, 특히 더위를 잘 견딜 수 있다면 더욱 즐겁게 보낼 수 있는 곳입니다! 연중 내내 따뜻한 날씨가 이어지는데, 가끔은 꽤 더울 수 있지만, 그 덕분에 이 지역에서만 누릴 수 있는 특별한 경험을 쌓는 데는 전혀 문제가 되지 않을 거예요. 오래된 식민지 건축물과 지역 공예품이 넘치는 번화한 시장 등 볼거리가 정말 많답니다.

여기서 가장 재미있는 활동 중 하나는 화산 보딩이에요—맞아요, 화산을 타고 미끄러져 내려가는 거죠! 멋진 경치를 한눈에 즐길 수 있는 짜릿한 방법입니다.

더운 날씨 때문에 오래 머물고 싶지 않을 수도 있지만, 레온은 며칠 동안 탐방하기에 정말 좋은 곳이에요. 대중교통이 다소 불편할 수 있으니 미리 준비하시는 게 좋습니다. 하지만 마을을 걸어 다니는 것은 지역의 분위기를 느끼기에 정말 좋은 방법이에요. 방문하는 동안에는 수분 보충을 잊지 말고 모자도 꼭 챙기세요! 지역 사람들은 특히 친절하니까, 이곳의 여유로운 생활 속도를 존중해 주는 것도 기억하시면 좋겠어요. 전체적으로 레온은 반드시 가볼 가치가 있는 독특한 경험을 제공합니다!

reviews: I study in Leiden, and I love it here! The city is beautiful, and quaint enough that you can bike from end to end in 10-15 minutes. Because it's a student town there's also a lot to do here, even for non-students. By West-European standards the prices are reasonable. Pretty much everyone speaks English fairly well, and Dutch is not too hard to pick up on. The location of Leiden in the Netherlands is also neat: 10 min by train to The Hague, 20-ish to Schiphol Airport, 30 min to Rotterdam, 40-ish min to Amsterdam and Utrecht. The biggest drawback I can think of is the fact that the housing market is very oversaturated because of the number of students who live here, so it might be tough to find a place to stay.
leiden.description:
Leiden is a nice city in the Netherlands that attracts both residents and visitors. This city is great for biking—there is no need for long trips, as you can travel from one end to the other in just 10-15 minutes! With a student atmosphere, there is a lot of activity and many things to explore, even for those not studying.

When it comes to cost, you will find Leiden’s prices quite reasonable compared to other Western European cities. The locals are friendly, and most speak English well, making it easy to get around and feel comfortable. The city's location is also good—just a short train ride to larger cities like The Hague, Amsterdam, and Rotterdam.

However, there is a downside; the housing market can be difficult because many students are looking for places to live. If you plan to visit or move here, be ready for this challenge! Overall, Leiden provides a good mix of culture and convenience, making it a nice place to experience Dutch life.
leiden.description_kor:
라이덴은 네덜란드에 위치한 매력적인 도시로, 주민들과 관광객 모두에게 특별한 경험을 제공합니다. 이곳은 자전거 타기에 최적화되어 있어서 시내 한 끝에서 다른 끝까지 이동하는 데 단 10-15분밖에 걸리지 않아요. 그래서 긴 여행을 할 필요가 없답니다. 학생 분위기가 느껴지는 이 도시는 다양한 활동과 볼거리가 있어 공부를 안 하는 사람들에게도 큰 재미를 줍니다.

비용 면에서 라이덴은 서유럽의 다른 도시들에 비해 비교적 합리적인 편입니다. 지역 주민들은 매우 친절하며, 대다수가 영어에 능숙해 이동이 쉽고 편안함을 느낄 수 있습니다. 또한 이 도시는 헤이그, 암스테르담, 로테르담과 같은 대도시에 가까워 교통이 매우 편리합니다.

하지만 단점도 존재합니다. 많은 학생들이 거주할 곳을 찾고 있어서 주택 시장이 경쟁이 치열할 수 있습니다. 만약 이곳을 방문하거나 이사할 계획이라면 이러한 점을 염두에 두는 것이 좋습니다. 전반적으로 라이덴은 문화와 편리함이 잘 어우러져 있어 네덜란드의 매력을 느끼기에 아주 좋은 곳입니다.

reviews: People move here because it is/was cheap. Period. There is nothing wrong with wanting affordable housing, but there is not much more to it. It is cold, winters are absolutely depressing, it is getting exponentially expensive, AfD is rising in power in Saxony and even in Leipzig and if you don't have neo-nazis, there are the extreme left which are equally depressing, especially for more liberal minded nomads. People from Berlin move here because Berlin is becoming crazy expensive, not because Leipzig is so cool. I fail to understand the hype around it and this nonsense has to stop. It is/was cheap, that's it.

Fucking rad if you make the most of it. Buy a shit bike (50-100 eur) and fix it at the community bike centres if it breaks. Cycle to Cospudner See all the time. Go to heaps of live music, and check out the punk scene. Can be expensive if you rent a place (and want to get anmeldung) but if you just sublet (look on WG Gesucht) then you can probably get a steal deal (we paid 500 eur/month warm rent for a couple sharing a room in a 2 bedroom place in Sudvorstadt). The west of the city has a nice vibe, and Connewitz is the counterculture area. Make sure to get the Deutschlandticket (49eur/mo) for unlimited local public transport (can get you across Germany and even across some borders). Can easily do a side trip to Berlin, to the Saxon Swiss national park, to Bavaria or to Prague. Leaving because we don't like the cold, but this city is pretty cool. Germans can be a bit cold, but you should be able to make some friends if you want.

Super green city with lots of cool places and cafes to hang out. young people are super left there and old people tend to be right. Prices aren't cheap in comparison to other cities in the east of Germany. Also, don't expect older people to be super open to strangers, if you don't speak German. If you want a Berlinish vibe Kollwitz is the place to be. Everything is super walkable or bikeable which is amazing. Can recommend going there.

I lived here for a summer. This city has beautiful nature with lots of parks, incredibly parties/clubs, few cafes to work from and is extremely bike friendly. It's a city that is very hyped and a lot of Berliners are moving here as they are fed up with Berlin. This place is however nowhere near as packed and eventful as Berlin. It's a very calm city and often not so much going on in the summers as all students are on holiday.

Overall you might have a hard time making friends but if you join the co-working space in the center, meetups and language exchanges you should be good. It's even easier if you know German as people don't speak such good English here. If you go here I recommend getting a bike and checking out the parks and also go canoeing near the river.
leipzig.description:
Leipzig is a city that attracts many people for its low cost of living and lively culture, though it has its oddities. Many locals enjoy the relaxed atmosphere, but winters can be quite cold and difficult if you don’t like cold weather. With a mix of left and right political views, newcomers might find it a little hard to understand the social situation, especially if you don't speak German.

On the positive side, there is a lot of creativity here! The city has live music, punk scenes, and cozy cafes – good places for relaxing and meeting people. Renting a place can be expensive if you want a long-term home, but subletting offers good options at lower prices. Don’t miss the nice parks or the good biking opportunities; it’s a bike-friendly city!

For those thinking about a visit, get the Germany ticket for unlimited public transport, and you'll easily reach nearby attractions, like the Saxon Swiss National Park or a trip to Berlin. Just keep in mind, making friends might take some time, so connecting through co-working spaces or language exchanges is a good way to get into the local scene!
leipzig.description_kor:
라이프치히는 낮은 생활비와 활기찬 문화로 많은 사람들을 매료시키는 도시입니다. 다소 특이한 점도 있지만요. 많은 현지인들이 평화로운 분위기를 즐기긴 하지만, 겨울철에는 꽤 춥고 날씨를 싫어하는 사람들에게는 힘든 시기가 될 수 있습니다. 좌우 정치적 견해가 공존하는 이곳에서는 독일어를 하지 못하는 이들이 사회 상황을 이해하는 데 어려움을 겪을 수 있습니다.

하지만 긍정적인 점이 많아요! 이 도시는 창의성이 넘쳐납니다. 라이브 음악, 펑크 씬, 아늑한 카페들이 많아 긴장을 풀고 사람들을 만날 수 있는 좋은 장소입니다. 장기적으로 집을 임대하려면 비용이 비쌀 수 있지만, 서브렛을 이용하면 더 저렴하게 좋은 선택지를 찾을 수 있습니다. 멋진 공원이나 자전거 타기에 좋은 환경도 놓치지 마세요; 이곳은 자전거 친화적인 도시니까요!

방문을 고려하시는 분들을 위해, 무제한 대중교통을 이용할 수 있는 독일 티켓을 구매하면 작센 스위스 국립공원이나 베를린 같은 근교 명소에 쉽게 갈 수 있습니다. 친구를 만들기까지 시간이 걸릴 수 있다는 점을 염두에 두세요. 코워킹 스페이스나 언어 교환을 통해 사람들과 연결되는 것은 현지 문화에 적응하는 좋은 방법입니다!

reviews: Only shop in Liberia. Playa Hermosa/Ocatal is simply lovely. As a female traveler, havent had any issues/concerns. My Spanish is basic and no issues there either.
liberia.description:
Liberia, located in Costa Rica, is a city that is a good starting point for nearby beaches like Playa Hermosa and Ocotal. Visitors enjoy the views and relaxed feel of these coastal areas. The locals are friendly, and even if your Spanish is basic, you should have no trouble communicating.

Many people like that Liberia is safe, making it a good choice for female travelers. While exploring the city, you will find many shopping options, so it's easy to buy souvenirs or local products. However, as in many places, the cost of living can be a bit high, especially in tourist areas.

Public transportation can be limited, so planning your routes is a good idea. Don't forget to learn about local customs and enjoy the friendly atmosphere! Some neighborhoods are very busy, but always be aware of your surroundings, especially in unfamiliar places. Overall, Liberia has a good mix of culture, nature, and community waiting to be explored!
liberia.description_kor:
리베리아는 코스타리카에 위치한 매력적인 도시로, 플라야 에르모사와 오코탈 같은 아름다운 해변으로 가는 좋은 출발점입니다. 이곳을 방문하는 사람들은 해안의 멋진 풍경과 여유로운 분위기를 만끽할 수 있습니다. 현지인들은 매우 친절하며, 스페인어를 조금만 할 줄 알아도 의사소통에 큰 어려움이 없을 것입니다.

리베리아는 안전하다는 점에서 많은 사람들에게 선호되며, 특히 여성 여행자들에게 좋은 선택이 됩니다. 도시를 둘러보면 다양한 쇼핑 옵션이 있어 기념품이나 지역 특산물을 쉽게 구입할 수 있습니다. 다만, 관광 지역에서는 생활비가 다소 비쌀 수 있다는 점도 고려해야 합니다.

대중교통이 다소 제한적일 수 있으니 미리 경로를 계획하는 것이 좋습니다. 현지 문화를 배우고 친근한 분위기를 즐기는 것을 잊지 마세요! 일부 지역은 매우 붐빌 수 있지만, 낯선 곳에서 항상 주변을 잘 살피는 것이 중요합니다. 전반적으로 리베리아는 문화, 자연, 커뮤니티가 잘 어우러져 있는 탐험할 가치가 충분한 곳입니다!

reviews:
Many people get the wrong idea about this city because they don't know where to go or stay at a touristy place. It's one of the best cities for me personally to live in (decided to move here full-time). If you still want to live in a city with it's amenities, but want to have the ability to run to nature within 10-20 minutes, this might be it for you. Yes, it's not cheap, and I would put Limassol into the exact cost of living brackets as Lisbon or Berlin. For long-term living, the costs are much lower because of lower local taxes (12.5% for freelancers and companies), while Germany has a 45% tax an example. Another main con is public transportation, hence you need to rent a car to experience the real Cyprus.

Pros:
- Perfect for work/life balance (for me)
- Beaches are in and around the city, you live in the middle of the island, so Troodos mountains, white sandy beaches of Ayia Napa, other cities (Paphos, Larnaca) are just a 1h drive away.
- Rapidly growing and improving. A completely different experience from 5/10 years ago. Lots of great coffee shops to work from and improving internet connection (most coffee shops have good enough internet).
- Some of the friendliest locals I've seen. On and they all speak English
- The weather is great 95% of the time. August is too hot for most people and January/February can be too cold or rainy (15-20 C) compared to alternatives such as Asia
- Nightlife improved drastically in the last few years with cool bars, nightclubs, tech/house or techno music, day parties, restaurants that have djs playing chill music and so on.
- Very safe
- Cyprus has this charming "villagy" vibe that Greece and other southern countries have, so don't expect to find Bangkok here:) 

Cons:
- Getting more expensive here (Berlin level). Other cities in Cyprus are much cheaper. If you live here as a resident tax savings cover for it.
- Lack of public transportation. You need to rent a car to get around the places (Limassol is a very "long" city, so going from one point to another might take awhile).
- Limassol still has some abandoned or not clean buildings that you could find in other Middle Eastern countries, but don't let that fool you.
- This is not a con to me (even though I don't speak Russian/Ukranian/Belarussian): There is quite a community of Belarussians, Russians and Ukrainians fleeing the war, but most of the ones I met are super friendly and very nice. If you really don't like hearing Slavic languages, most of the nice bars and restaurants have mainly locals, Greeks or Europeans. Almost all of them are very friendly and come from amazing cities like Kiev.

It's not an attractive city, and prices are not really that great. You can get to great beaches, and if you have a car the mountains have some beautiful hikes, but I would not list it as the best of cities. Most remote workers seem to be Russians fleeing the war.

Ehh, wasn't really impressed. The beach is ok. There's a surprisingly good Israeli restaurant. I guess if I wanted to launder Russian money in an ugly condo this would be a decent option, but Turkey or even Albanian coast are far more interesting...
limassol.description:
Limassol, Cyprus, is a city that may surprise you. It is often ignored, but many who come here find a good balance of work and relaxation. This active city has nice beaches nearby and easy access to the lovely Troodos mountains for nature trips. The local atmosphere is welcoming, with many people speaking English, making it easy to meet the locals.

Limassol may not be the cheapest place in the world, but the lower taxes can help with long-term living costs. It is not as budget-friendly as some other places in Cyprus, but many residents feel it is worth it for the good quality of life and new services, including popular coffee shops with good internet.

However, public transportation is limited, so having a rental car is important to get around the city and visit nearby areas. While you might see a few unattractive buildings, do not let that put you off—the nightlife is lively, with busy bars and relaxed spots, and has improved a lot. Just be ready for some heat in the summer and a little rain in the winter, but that is a small issue for living in a nice place.
limassol.description_kor:
리마솔, 키프로스는 여러분을 놀라게 할 수 있는 매력적인 도시입니다. 종종 간과되곤 하지만, 이곳을 찾는 많은 사람들은 일과 휴식을 잘 조화시킬 수 있는 곳을 찾고 있습니다. 이 활기찬 도시는 아름다운 해변과 자연 탐험을 위한 사랑스러운 트로오도스 산에 쉽게 접근할 수 있는 장점이 있습니다. 지역 분위기는 따뜻하고 환영하는 느낌이며, 많은 사람들이 영어를 구사해 현지인들과의 소통이 쉽습니다.

리마솔은 세계에서 가장 저렴한 도시라고 할 수는 없지만, 낮은 세금 덕분에 장기적인 생활비를 절감할 수 있는 환경이 조성되어 있습니다. 키프로스의 다른 지역만큼 경제적이지는 않지만, 많은 주민들은 좋은 삶의 질과 인터넷이 잘 갖춰진 인기 있는 카페 등 새로운 서비스 덕분에 충분히 그 가치가 있다고 느끼고 있습니다.

하지만 대중교통이 다소 불편할 수 있으므로, 도시를 돌아다니고 주변 지역을 방문하기 위해서는 렌트카를 이용하는 것이 매우 중요합니다. 다소 미관이 좋지 않은 건물들이 있을 수 있지만, 그로 인해 실망하지 않으셨으면 좋겠습니다. 리마솔의 밤문화는 매우 활기차고 바와 여유로운 장소들이 많이 있어 크게 개선되었습니다. 여름철에는 더위가 오고 겨울철에는 가끔 비가 내릴 수 있으니 미리 준비하시는 것이 좋습니다. 그러나 이러한 작은 불편함은 멋진 곳에서의 생활과 비교하면 사소한 문제에 불과합니다.

reviews: "Not safe for women" are you kidding? 🤣 one of the safest places for women in the world, hands down!

Ljubljana is amazing. Lots of options for beautiful coffee shops with free wifi. Hard to find an outdoor charging outlet. If you are staying for longer, definitely recommend getting a portable laptop battery bank.

Ljubljana (and Slovenia in general) is an AMAZING place. I cannot recommend it enough. All I ask is - please don't write public blogs and make vlogs about it. It is still sort of undiscovered except among Europeans and mostly Italians. Let's try and keep it that way as long as possible.
It has a romantic feeling when you walk in the old center + it's really cheap in comparaison with other eastern european cities! Fully recommend you see it if you have the chance to be around!
ljubljana.description:
Ljubljana is a nice place in Slovenia that attracts many visitors. With its coffee shops and pleasant atmosphere, you'll find many places to relax and have a drink, and there is free WiFi available. If you plan to work remotely, it’s a good idea to bring a portable laptop battery since it can be hard to find outdoor power outlets.

This city is safe, especially for women, so you can walk around the quiet streets without fear. The old town has nice views and some history. Also, it is less expensive than other Eastern European cities, which is good for travelers on a budget.

While it has a strong cultural scene, public transportation can be limited, so walking or biking is usually the best way to get around. Try to visit before it becomes more popular – it is a place worth exploring while it still feels less crowded. Enjoy your time in this lovely city!
ljubljana.description_kor:
류블랴나(Ljubljana)는 슬로베니아의 매력적인 도시로 많은 관광객들의 발길을 끌고 있습니다. 이곳은 아늑한 커피숍과 즐거운 분위기로 가득 차 있어, 편안하게 휴식을 취하며 음료를 즐길 수 있는 곳이 많습니다. 또한, 무료 WiFi를 제공하는 곳도 있어 원격 근무를 계획하신다면 참고하시면 좋습니다. 다만 야외에서 전원 콘센트를 찾기 어려울 수 있으니, 휴대용 노트북 배터리를 가져가는 것이 좋습니다.

이 도시는 전반적으로 안전한 편이며, 특히 여성에게 더욱 안전한 환경입니다. 조용한 거리에서도 걷는 것에 대한 걱정이 없으니 안심하셔도 좋습니다. 구시가지에서는 아름다운 경관과 함께 다양한 역사적 유적들도 만나볼 수 있습니다. 게다가 다른 동유럽 도시들에 비해 비용이 비교적 저렴해 예산이 한정된 여행자들에게 알맞은 장소입니다.

문화적인 씬이 활발하지만 공공교통은 다소 제한적일 수 있어, 보통 걷거나 자전거를 이용하는 것이 최적의 이동수단입니다. 붐비기 전에 이곳을 방문해 보세요. 아직 덜 알려진 이 매력적인 도시는 탐험할 가치를 충분히 지니고 있습니다. 이 멋진 도시에서 즐거운 시간을 보내시기 바랍니다!

reviews: Surprisingly lovely and lively town, with great people and beautiful places.
louisville.description:
Louisville is a city that surprises many with its friendliness and energy. You will find a mix of helpful locals and nice places that are hard to ignore. The city is filled with culture, especially known for big horse racing events like the Kentucky Derby, which is an experience to enjoy.

Living here is quite affordable, and while transportation can be a bit different, you will get used to it. Just be ready for some difficulties if you do not speak English well; communication can sometimes be hard.

Make sure to visit the waterfront and try local foods, like the famous Hot Brown dish. Different neighborhoods offer different experiences, with areas like Old Louisville and the Highlands being good choices for their unique feel. Safety is generally good, but like in any city, pay attention to your surroundings. Overall, Louisville is a friendly city with a lot to offer, making it a good place for visitors and residents.
louisville.description_kor:
루이빌은 많은 이들에게 친절함과 생동감으로 놀라움을 안겨주는 도시입니다. 이곳에서는 도움을 주고받는 따뜻한 지역 주민들을 만나게 될 것이며, 눈길을 사로잡는 멋진 장소들도 발견할 수 있을 것입니다. 루이빌은 풍부한 문화로 가득 차 있고, 특히 켄터키 더비와 같은 대규모 경마 행사로 유명해 잊지 못할 경험을 선사합니다.

여기서의 생활은 비교적 저렴하며, 교통수단이 다소 낯설 수 있지만 금방 익숙해질 것입니다. 영어에 자신이 없다면 약간의 불편함이 있을 수 있으니, 미리 준비하셔야 합니다. 가끔 의사소통이 어려울 수 있습니다.

해안가를 방문할 때는 꼭 유명한 핫 브라운 요리 같은 지역 음식을 맛보세요. 루이빌의 다양한 동네들은 각각 독특한 매력을 지니고 있으며, 올드 루이빌이나 하이랜즈 지역은 특히 특별한 분위기를 느낄 수 있는 좋은 선택입니다. 안전은 대체로 양호하지만, 다른 도시와 마찬가지로 주변을 잘 살피는 것이 중요합니다. 전반적으로 루이빌은 방문객과 거주자 모두에게 많은 매력을 지닌 친절한 도시입니다.

reviews: No reason to ever go here unless you are injured enough to need the hospitals, which are pretty good. Boring town, super conservative and newly built strip malls that each feature 1 salon or beauty shop, 1 whitewashed mildly ethnic restaurant, 1 bbq or sandwich place, 1 store selling either vitamins or tangentially MLM related items, a tax preparation place, and 1 tea place. Huge number of dental offices. Tons of big churches full of big hair, cowboy boots, and not a lot of anyone who seems truly to have faith, which I could respect. Decent population of college frat boys who call you ma'am. As a city, it occupies the same mental space as a "Target" store but more racist.

God this city is terrible. Had the misfortune of spending my teens and a couple college years here. Although I hear it's a bit better now. If there's one thing it has going for it is a solid coffee scene and tons of talented musicians - although in general they quickly abandon ship to Austin or DFW. In general, avoid like the plague. It's a 300,000 pop hub of consumerism, ultra-christian-conservatism, obesity, fast-food chains, college bros, STDs and mega churches.
lubbock.description:
Lubbock, Texas, is a place that may surprise you in both positive and negative ways. On the positive side, this city has a good hospital system and a lively coffee scene that locals enjoy. Music fans will like the skilled musicians who often perform locally, even if many move to bigger cities like Austin. 

On the negative side, Lubbock can feel a bit dull because the shopping options are similar—mostly new strip malls with the same stores. If you like a conservative atmosphere, large churches, and a relaxed college vibe, you may find it appealing. The city has many dental offices and beauty salons, but many visitors notice a lack of variety in dining and entertainment.

Getting around can be difficult since public transportation is not very good, and housing costs can be high. It is also important to be aware of local cultural norms and the strong conservative views in the area. If you visit, try to enjoy the local music and coffee culture to make your stay better!
lubbock.description_kor:
텍사스주 러벅은 긍정적인 면과 부정적인 면 모두에서 여러분을 놀라게 할 수 있는 곳입니다. 긍정적인 면으로는 이곳의 훌륭한 의료 시스템과 지역 주민들이 즐기는 활기찬 커피 문화가 있습니다. 음악 팬이라면 지역에서 활발히 활동하는 재능 있는 뮤지션들의 공연을 즐길 수 있을 것입니다. 물론 많은 뮤지션들이 오스틴과 같은 큰 도시로 이사하지만요.

반면 부정적인 면은 쇼핑 옵션이 비슷해서 약간 지루하게 느껴질 수 있다는 점입니다. 새로운 스트립 몰들이 대부분 같은 상점으로 구성되어 있기 때문입니다. 보수적인 분위기와 대형 교회, 느긋한 대학생들의 분위기가 좋은 분들에게는 매력적일 수 있지만, 많은 방문객들은 식사와 엔터테인먼트의 다양성이 부족하다고 느끼곤 합니다.

또한 대중교통이 그렇게 발달하지 않아 이동하기 어려울 수 있으며, 주택 비용이 비쌀 수 있습니다. 지역의 문화적 규범과 지배적인 보수적 관점을 이해하는 것도 중요합니다. 방문하신다면 지역의 음악과 커피 문화를 꼭 즐겨보세요! 여러분의 체류가 더욱 특별해질 것입니다.

reviews:
Lusaka is a bustling city full of surprises if you look. The downside is rent is on the pricey side than say what you would expect to pay in most places in SEA. You can find some low rental places but then you'd be putting yourself in an environment that's not particularly safe. I'd pick a neighbourhood like Kabulonga, Woodlands, Chilenje, Ibex Hill or Makeni. Getting around is easier if you have a car or find a reliable cabby. You can also use the local rideshare app called Ulendo Taxi, it works well and even has female drivers, which I think is great for solo female travellers.
Public safety is okay, best not to travel to compounds where safety can be a major issue, especially if you're a muzungu, a local word for 'White person' or someone considered well-off. Expect to be crowded around by street vendors selling everything from phone accessories, clothing, and sometimes local crafts. I wouldn't advise purchasing from these as you'll get ripped off - best go to the weekend markets or the craft village. 
Zambia doesn't have a café or coffee culture per se but you can find some pretty decent coffee shops that have great coffee and free wifi. Zam Bean Coffee, The Corner Café and 3Tree's are my favs. I'd advise to join the Expat Group's on Facebook for more tips and questions.
lusaka.description:
Lusaka is a city that has a lot of activity and some surprises if you look more closely.
