Staying here can be difficult if you have a small budget. Many cheap places to stay have slow Wi-Fi and lack some services, so be ready to adjust your budget for a better stay. The BKK1 and BKK3 areas are popular for their cafes and workspaces, making them decent places to work, although reliable internet can be a common issue.

You should keep your belongings safe as pickpocketing can be a problem here. However, Phnom Penh is a good starting point to visit nearby places like Kampot, which is much quieter. If you are open to new experiences and keep an eye out for the right ones, this city has its appeal, especially for food fans and culture lovers!
phnom-penh.description_kor:
프놈펜은 동남아시아의 다른 분주한 수도들과는 달리 여유로운 분위기를 자아냅니다. 이 도시에서는 저녁 9시가 지나면 점차 조용해지기 시작해, 밤 문화를 즐기고 싶은 사람들에겐 다소 고요하게 느껴질 수 있습니다. 볼거리는 풍부하며 다양한 문화, 맛있는 음식, 역사적인 명소들이 가득하지만, 진정한 명소를 찾기 위해서는 조금 더 탐색해야 할 수도 있습니다.

예산이 적다면 이곳에서 지내기가 어려울 수 있어요. 저렴한 숙소들은 느린 와이파이를 제공하거나 서비스가 부족할 경우가 많으니, 더 나은 숙박을 원하면 예산을 조정할 준비를 해 두는 것이 좋습니다. BKK1과 BKK3 지역은 카페와 작업 공간이 많아 일하기에 적합하지만, 안정적인 인터넷 연결이 문제될 수 있습니다.

소매치기 사건이 발생할 수 있으니, 소지품을 안전하게 지키는 것이 중요합니다. 하지만 프놈펜은 조용한 캠폿과 같은 근처 장소를 탐방하기에 좋은 출발점이에요. 새로운 경험에 열려 있고 알맞은 활동을 찾아낸다면, 이 도시는 특히 음식과 문화를 사랑하는 이들에게 매력적으로 다가올 것입니다!

reviews:
Pipa is the best kept secret of Brazil, a small surf town with a thriving community of interesting people. Right now there are weekly popup coworking days, weekly meetups and weekend trips with other nomads. 
If you like sports this is heaven: Surf, beach tennis, padel, Crossfit... Brazil is a very sport focused country and that shows every day on the lifestyle here.

Pipa is a small surf village just 1h south of Natal and the first nomad village in Brazil. 
There's a small coworking space, accommodation is widely available for monthly deals except in January and February (high season). There are a lot of good restaurants, internet is good and the nightlife very busy. 
Pipa is definitely an upcoming destination in Brazil.
pipa.description:
Imagine a small town on the northeastern coast of Brazil, and you have Pipa. This surf town, just an hour from Natal, has a nice mix of beach life and community feel. Think of relaxing afternoons in the sun, followed by fun activities like surfing, beach tennis, and CrossFit. If you enjoy being active, you will like the sporty lifestyle in Pipa!

The atmosphere here is friendly and open - it’s a place where interesting people come together for coworking days, meetups, and weekend fun. While there is a small coworking space, many places to stay become available, especially outside the busy January and February season.

One thing to note is that Pipa can get crowded during busy times, but the nightlife is always good! Just keep in mind that there is limited public transportation and some language challenges. So pack your beach items, and enjoy the sun, surf, and good company in this growing destination!
pipa.description_kor:
브라질 북동부 해안에 위치한 작은 마을, 피파(Pipa)를 떠올려 보세요. 나탈에서 단 1시간 거리에 있는 이 서핑 마을은 해변 생활과 따뜻한 공동체 감정이 완벽하게 어우러져 있습니다. 햇살 아래에서 여유로운 오후를 보내고, 서핑이나 비치 테니스, 크로스핏 같은 다양한 액티비티를 즐기는 모습을 상상해보세요. 활동적인 라이프스타일을 선호하신다면, 피파의 스포츠 문화에 푹 빠지실 것입니다!

이곳은 아늑하고 개방적인 분위기로, 흥미로운 사람들이 모여 코워킹 데이, 미팅, 그리고 주말의 즐거움을 나누는 곳입니다. 작은 코워킹 스페이스도 있지만, 바쁜 1월과 2월을 제외하고는 다양한 숙소가 마련되어 있습니다.

다만, 피파는 혼잡한 시즌에는 많은 인파로 북적일 수 있다는 점을 유의해야 합니다. 하지만 밤문화는 언제나 활기차답니다! 대중교통의 선택이 제한적일 수 있고, 언어적인 어려움이 있을 수도 있으니 이 점도 고려해 주세요. 그러니 해변 용품을 챙기고 이 매력적인 여행지에서 태양과 서핑, 좋은 사람들과 함께 즐거운 시간을 만끽하세요!

reviews:
Plovdiv is as far as we can tell the nicest part of Bulgaria, but we can't see any reason why a person should choose to be in Plovdiv or Bulgaria when there are better options available for all aspects of life that we care about. Bulgaria is the poorest country in Europe, with very high rates of smoking - people can smoke inside restaurants with impunity here. Quality of life seems generally low. However, the food is delicious! :)

The expat community, even for a relatively large city such as Plovdiv, is a fraction the size of a relatively small city like e.g. Paphos, Cyprus. In Paphos there's all kinds of activities organised for any day of the week. In Plovdiv, even in peak season, it seems quiet, with little to do.

We didn't have high expectations for Bulgaria, but we were curious and wanted to explore. Bulgaria was below our expectations, and sadly we plan never to return. We can't think of any reason to recommend Bulgaria above one of the many better choices out there such as Prague, Krakow, Budapest, Paphos, most other European cities.

The pollution from cars is the worst thing about Plovdiv. Well, also the showers that take up the entire bathroom. The fascinating, long history is the best thing here. People are polite, decent, and helpful.

I've been here for the last 5 months. People are extremely friendly, the weather has been amazing (on the too hot side, during the summer). You can drink tap water, Nomadlist, check that. It is very cheap, walkable, plenty of cafes, bars and restaurants. It is very safe. The gym scene is not great but you can survive. Not many hipsters, but overloaded with instagrammers (like everywhere else, I guess). All in all, it's a beautiful city, safe, affordable, welcoming (if you are white). Racist graffiti is all over, but I haven't heard of any violence. That part is sad.
Sometimes I think I'll stay here forever, sometimes other cities want me to know them.

According to all the sources I've read, the tap water in Plovdiv is completely fine to drink. Not sure why Nomadlist is saying it's contaminated.

Nice and green city, lot of parks and hills. Very cheap!

By far, one of the best cities in Bulgaria, located in the center of the country, with good views upon the Balkans + Rila Rodopi mountains. Has good scenery from 2-3 hills + cheap food/drinks and so on! Fully recommend for those who wanna see it!
plovdiv.description:
Plovdiv is a city in Bulgaria that many people think is very nice. It has a lot of history and hills that give good views of the Balkan and Rila Rodopi mountains. While it is a pleasant city, some visitors find it a bit quiet compared to busier places like Prague or Krakow.

The local food is a highlight – you will enjoy it! Plus, it is inexpensive. You can have tasty meals without spending too much money. It is easy and safe to walk around, so you can explore the parks and cafes.

However, be aware that the city has issues with air pollution and indoor smoking can be unpleasant. Public transport could be better, so be prepared to walk a lot. Although Plovdiv may not have many expats living there, the people are friendly and willing to help. Just remember that the tap water is safe to drink, so make sure to stay hydrated while enjoying this nice city!
plovdiv.description_kor:
플로브디프는 많은 사람들이 매우 아름답다고 여기는 불가리아의 도시입니다. 이 도시는 풍부한 역사와 함께 발칸 및 릴라 로도피 산맥의 멋진 경치를 감상할 수 있는 언덕들로 둘러싸여 있습니다. 쾌적한 분위기가 매력적이지만, 일부 방문객들은 프라하나 크라쿠프 같은 북적이는 곳에 비해 조금 한적하다고 느낄 수도 있습니다.

지역 음식은 꼭 맛봐야 할 하이라이트입니다. 저렴한 가격에 훌륭한 식사를 즐길 수 있어 큰 돈을 들이지 않고도 만족스러운 경험이 가능합니다. 도보로 돌아다니기 쉽고 안전해서 공원과 카페를 자유롭게 탐험할 수 있습니다.

다만, 이 도시에서는 대기 오염과 실내 흡연이 불쾌할 수 있다는 점은 염두에 두셔야 합니다. 대중교통이 개선이 필요한 상황이니 많이 걸어 다닐 준비를 하시는 게 좋습니다. 플로브디프에는 외국인이 많이 살고 있지는 않지만, 현지 사람들은 친절하고 도움을 주고자 하는 마음이 큽니다. 수돗물은 안전하게 마실 수 있으니, 이 아름다운 도시에서 탐험을 즐기면서 충분히 수분도 섭취하는 것 잊지 마세요!

reviews:
Small city, very safe and chill. Internet in general was good, more affordable much less crowded than Kotor and all the beach cities in Montenegro.
 Bars and restaurants during summer nights were full, mostly with locals, nice atmosphere.
There is nothing much to see in the city, besides the river and some parks, but it's good to work and focus.

It's a small city and a great place to work and go about your day.
Not very touristy and there are much better places in Montenegro to visit as a tourist but Podgorica is great as a base to explore both the north and south of the country as it's very well connected with roads in each direction.
It's very affordable compared to the coast and there are a lot of restaurants, cafes, and shops.

Google "ugliest Balkan capital city reddit" and you see what is the most popular answer. I've been to all the Balkans, and Podgorica is probably the most "meh" and uninteresting city I remember visiting. Abandoned building without windows right on the main square of the capital of the country, are you kidding me? Really boring and although there are some things to see, but overall it's extremely generic, and you'd be better off going to other cities of Montenegro instead of Podgorica. Kotor for example is much more interesting, as well as some other cities on coast, or nature on the north.
podgorica.description:
Podgorica is a small, quiet city where safety is important. If you want a place that is not too busy, it is a nice change from the larger coastal towns like Kotor. The internet connection is good, making it a suitable place for people who want to work. When the sun goes down, the local bars and restaurants become lively with friendly locals.

Some travelers find Podgorica a bit plain, with not much to see besides its parks and the river, but it is a good base for exploring Montenegro’s varied landscapes. It is very affordable compared to the tourist spots on the coast. Just be ready for some unusual sights, like a few empty buildings. English is not commonly spoken, which can be difficult, but people are usually friendly. For a look at local life and easier access to beautiful lakes and mountains, Podgorica might surprise you if you see it as a place to explore rather than just a destination.
podgorica.description_kor:
포드고리차는 안전하고 조용한 작은 도시로, 바쁘지 않은 환경을 원하시는 분들께는 코토르와 같은 큰 해변 도시에서의 멋진 변화가 될 수 있습니다. 인터넷 환경이 좋아서 일을 하려는 분들에게도 적합한 장소입니다. 해가 지고 나면 지역의 바와 레스토랑이 친절한 현지인들로 활기를 띠게 됩니다.

일부 여행자들은 포드고리차가 다소 평범하게 느껴질 수 있으며, 공원과 강 외에는 특별한 볼거리가 없다고 생각할 수 있지만, 몬테네그로의 다양한 풍경을 탐험하기 위한 훌륭한 기지가 됩니다. 해안 지역의 관광지에 비해 가격도 매우 저렴하죠. 몇몇 빈 건물 같은 이색적인 풍경이 있긴 하지만, 그 정도는 문제되지 않습니다. 영어가 널리 통용되지 않아 어려움이 있을 수 있지만, 사람들은 대체로 친절합니다. 지역 주민들의 삶을 느끼고 아름다운 호수와 산들에 쉽게 접근할 수 있는 곳으로 포드고리차를 바라본다면, 단순한 목적지가 아닌 독특한 탐험의 장소로서 매력을 느낄 수 있을 것입니다.

reviews: English spoken by most and locals are friendly. Pretty good mall outside of town 10 minutes drive AFI Mall. Affordable place to live.

Ploiești is a city and county seat in Prahova County, Romania.

Part of the historical region of Muntenia, it is located 56 km north of Bucharest. The area of the city is around 60 km2. It borders the Blejoi village in the north, Bărcănești and Brazi villages in the south, Târgșoru Vechi in the west and Bucov village in the east. Ploiești has direct access to the Prahova Valley, one of the most important alpine tourism areas in Romania.

Ploiești is an important transport hub, linking Bucharest with Transylvania and Moldavia. According to the 2011 Romanian census, there were 201,226 people living within the city of Ploiești, making it the 9th most populous in the country.
ploiesti.description:
Ploiești is a city in Romania, located 56 km north of Bucharest. It has friendly locals who often speak English, which helps newcomers to interact. The cost of living is affordable, benefiting both visitors and residents. If you want to shop, you can drive to AFI Mall, which is a 10-minute drive away.

The city has a rich history and is an important transport hub, connecting Bucharest with the regions of Transylvania and Moldavia. People who like nature can enjoy the nearby Prahova Valley, which is good for mountain tourism.

While Ploiești has many things to enjoy, there are some issues like limited public transportation options. However, it is a safe place where you can experience local customs and festivals. Whether you are visiting historical sites or enjoying the local culture, Ploiești has something for you.
ploiesti.description_kor:
플로이에쉬티는 루마니아에 위치한 도시로, 부쿠레슈티에서 북쪽으로 56km 떨어져 있습니다. 이곳은 친절한 주민들이 많아 영어로도 쉽게 소통할 수 있어 새로 온 이들에게 매우 편리합니다. 생활비도 합리적이어서 방문객과 주민 모두에게 이점이 있습니다. 쇼핑을 원하신다면 차로 10분 거리의 AFI 몰을 방문하시면 됩니다.

이 도시는 풍부한 역사를 가진 곳으로, 부쿠레슈티와 트란실바니아, 몰다비아 지역을 연결하는 중요한 교통 허브 역할을 합니다. 자연을 사랑하는 분들은 인근의 프라호바 계곡에서 산악 관광을 즐길 수 있습니다.

플로이에쉬티에는 많은 즐길거리와 매력이 있지만, 제한된 대중교통 수단 등 일부 아쉬운 점도 있습니다. 그럼에도 불구하고 이곳은 안전하며, 현지 풍습과 축제를 체험할 수 있는 좋은 기회를 제공합니다. 역사적인 명소를 방문하거나 지역 문화를 즐기고 싶다면, 플로이에쉬티는 여러분을 위해 다양한 경험을 제공할 것입니다.

reviews: Port harcourt is no doubt an amazing city. Enjoyed every single second of the days spent there. The SME and tech start-up space is really buzzing and growing real fast. Met quite a few interesting entrepreneurs and looking forward to visiting again sometimes soon!
port-harcourt.description:
Port Harcourt is an active city that has its own appeal. Many visitors enjoy the atmosphere and energy here. If you like new ideas and technology, you will find that small and medium-sized businesses (SMEs) and tech startups are very lively. There is a sense of community among business people, and you may meet new people and find inspiration.

While the city has much to see, it's important to know about a few difficulties. Some people say that public transportation can be unreliable, so having your own vehicle or taking a taxi is a good choice. Safety is also something to think about; like in any place, it is best to choose your areas carefully when going out.

On the positive side, the local customs and friendliness are often mentioned. When you visit, be sure to try the tasty local food! The people are friendly and welcoming, contributing to a nice atmosphere. So, if you are looking for an adventure with culture and business, Port Harcourt should be on your travel list!
port-harcourt.description_kor:
포트하르코트는 독특한 매력을 지닌 활기찬 도시입니다. 많은 방문객들이 이곳의 생동감 넘치는 분위기와 에너지를 즐깁니다. 새로운 아이디어와 기술에 관심이 있다면 중소기업과 기술 스타트업들이 활발히 운영되고 있는 점을 알게 될 것입니다. 이곳의 비즈니스 관계자들 사이에는 강한 공동체 의식이 있어, 새로운 사람들을 만나고 영감을 얻기에도 좋은 환경입니다.

도시에는 볼거리가 많지만 몇 가지 주의할 점도 있습니다. 일부 사람들은 대중교통이 다소 불편하다고 느끼기 때문에 개인 차량이나 택시를 이용하는 것이 더 편리할 수 있습니다. 또한, 안전 문제도 중요합니다. 다른 지역과 마찬가지로 외출할 때는 주변 환경을 잘 살피는 것이 좋습니다.

그러나 긍정적인 면도 많습니다. 지역 주민들의 친절함과 따뜻한 환대는 자주 언급되는 특징입니다. 방문하신다면 꼭 맛있는 현지 음식을 경험해 보세요! 친절한 사람들과의 만남이 좋은 분위기를 만들어줍니다. 그래서 문화와 비즈니스가 어우러진 멋진 여행을 원하신다면 포트하르코트는 반드시 방문해야 할 곳입니다!

reviews: I stayed in Pokhara for a few months and it is a friendly place with a good music scene. there are plenty of amazing trekking opportunities around in the Himalayas. the people are very friendly and it's easy to make friends. Lots of travelers here are smoking weed, it seems to be pretty legal here. internet speeds are good (probably 15 up and down on average but I stayed in one place that was hitting 30) but power cuts are frequent in the summer (monsoon) months. Many hotels, guest houses, airbnbs are fitted with an inverter to combat this (which basically means one or two sockets and lights in the place will still work during a power cut, so make sure your place has an inverter and your modem is plugged into one of the working sockets. No co-working spaces available in Pokhara at this time. Overall I'd definitely recommend it but the inverter is a must! If you are doing research about Pokhara and you are worried about load shedding, rest assured it doesn't happen anymore (just be aware of the power outages in the monsoon months).
pokhara.description:
Pokhara is a special place in the center of Nepal, great for anyone looking for adventure and relaxation. If you enjoy hiking, you are in a good spot; the Himalayas have some beautiful trails nearby. The people here are friendly, making it easy to meet other travelers and locals.

However, be ready for some difficulties. Power outages can occur during the monsoon season, so it’s wise to check if your hotel has a backup power supply. The internet is okay, usually around 15-30 Mbps, but don't expect workspace for working online.

If you enjoy music, you will like the vibrant atmosphere, but note that some travelers use marijuana here. Overall, Pokhara has its unique features but offers memorable experiences, nice views, and a welcoming community. Just make sure to keep your phone charger close during rainy days!
pokhara.description_kor:
포카라는 네팔 중앙에 위치한 특별한 곳으로, 모험과 휴식을 원하는 이들에게 안성맞춤입니다. 하이킹을 즐기는 분들에게는 정말 좋은 위치인데, 히말라야의 아름다운 트레일이 근처에 있습니다. 이곳의 사람들은 매우 친절해서 다른 여행자들과 현지인들을 쉽게 만날 수 있습니다.

하지만 몇 가지 유의해야 할 점도 있습니다. 몬순 시즌에는 정전이 발생할 수 있으니, 호텔에 백업 전원이 있는지 미리 확인하는 것이 좋습니다. 인터넷 속도는 보통 15-30Mbps 정도로 괜찮지만, 온라인 작업을 위한 전용 공간은 기대하지 않는 게 좋습니다.

음악을 좋아하신다면 이곳의 활기찬 분위기를 만끽할 수 있을 거예요. 다만, 일부 여행자들이 마리화나를 사용할 수 있다는 점은 참고하시기 바랍니다. 전반적으로 포카라는 독특한 매력을 지니고 있으며, 잊지 못할 경험과 멋진 경치, 그리고 따뜻한 커뮤니티를 제공합니다. 비 오는 날에는 핸드폰 충전을 가까이 두는 것을 잊지 마세요!

reviews:
Mauritius is indeed a great place to live in as a Digital Nomad ! They have recently released the Premium Visa for digital nomads that allows to live on the island for at least 1 year (renewable). Best places to live in are the North (very well developed with all facilities and business centres) and the West of the island (more for those who prefer to surf the waves and hike the mountains in between 2 video calls !). 

The Mauritians are very welcoming and smiling people. I am not the first one to be touched deeply by their generosity. Food is very nice, people are helping, music and culture are the best. Wind in the South is perfect for kite surfing, wind foil, windsurf, etc 
There are also new coworking spaces opening all around the island and you can hop from The Hive coworking spaces to a nice South African café such as Bloom in the North or to a tea place/colonial house such as Les Aubineaux in the centre of the island. All with nice wifi and great vibes. 

My personal recommendations : visit the tea factory of Bois Cheri, taste the Vanilla Rum of Saint-Aubin, hop in the beautiful lagoon of Pointe d'Esny, and hike Le Morne at sunrise. I cherish every single one of these visits. 

I would also recommend to be accompanied by an agency to get your visa, find a trusted real estate agency, choose your local insurance, etc. I asked Smart Traveller, they are specialised in helping digital nomads come settle in Mauritius and they were the best. Young and friendly team, professional and human. Cannot recommend them enough actually. 

Still a great adventure to be here in Mauritius working remotely and a dream come true for my family and I.

Hi, I would recommend to not spend too much time in Port Louis if you are in Mauritius. It is a less interesting place in Mauritius to stay or spend time. I would recommend either the North or the west coast of the Island. Trou aux Biches or Flic en Flac are two really good options. You will be at most 5 mins walk away from a postal card beach while still having very good working conditions (good wifi). What I love about Mauritius is the variety of things to do, even though it is quite a small Island, you have numerous amazing hikes (I would clearly recommend Le Morne Hike), lots of postal cards beaches, natural parks, all type of sea activities from submarine tube to perfect kiting conditions. Also, one thing I can't really agree is the racial tolerance score that Nomad List gave them because it is quite ironic in a country where 25% of people are Christians, 40% are Hindus and 15% are Muslims that there is no racial tolerance. Mauritius is one of the most peaceful countries I had the chance to visit where the mix of culture is the most unique. You can literally find a Church, a Mosque and a Temple 30 meters away from each other. It is also one of the most politically stable and the 2nd most developed country of Africa so they have that mix of modernity and Island vibes. If you are a digital nomad going to Mauritius, I would clearly recommend you to contact Island trotter (it is a kind of digital nomad consultant based there) and they will organize everything for you so that you get the best experience. Gael and Jean have been very very helpful during my visit there and they made my trip amazing.

Be careful of the many tourist traps. Restaurants have two menus, one for the locals and one for the tourists. Booze and cigarettes are very expensive and people are generally quite homophobic. The place is quite dirty with building rubble and half built homes all over the place. Lots of wonderful public beaches and the south has beautiful stretches with untouched flora.
port-louis.description:
Port-Louis, the main city of Mauritius, offers a mix of island life and city living. It may not be the best choice for a long visit, but it gives a lively sense of the local culture. The people are friendly and often greet you with a smile. You will see a variety of traditions, with churches, mosques, and temples close together, showing the island's different backgrounds.

Life in Mauritius is good for remote workers, especially with the new Premium Visa that lets you stay longer. Many suggest living in the North or West, where the beaches are beautiful and there are good places to work with strong Wi-Fi. You can find coworking spaces like The Hive and nice cafes, great for taking a coffee break or having lunch.

While Port-Louis has things to see, watch out for common tourist traps. Local menus are different from those for visitors, so it's wise to ask locals for the best places to eat. Also, the city can be a bit rough and not very clean, but the nearby nature—from hikes at Le Morne to calm beaches—offers great experiences! Always look for local tips and connections to improve your visit, and you will enjoy your time in Mauritius!
port-louis.description_kor:
포트루이스는 모리셔스의 주요 도시로, 섬의 독특한 생활과 도시의 편리함이 잘 어우러진 곳입니다. 짧은 여행에는 최선의 선택이 아닐 수 있지만, 지역 문화를 생생하게 경험할 수 있습니다. 사람들은 매우 친절하고, 종종 따뜻한 미소로 인사를 건넵니다. 교회, 모스크, 사원이 모두 가까이 있어 섬의 다양한 전통과 배경을 엿볼 수 있습니다.

모리셔스에서의 생활은 원격 근무자들에게 아주 좋으며, 특히 더 오랜 기간 머무를 수 있는 새로운 프리미엄 비자도 도입되었습니다. 많은 사람들이 북쪽이나 서쪽 지역에 살기를 추천하는데, 그곳의 아름다운 해변과 안정적인 Wi-Fi를 갖춘 작업 공간 덕분입니다. '더 하이브'와 같은 코워킹 스페이스와 함께, 커피를 마시거나 점심을 즐기기에 적합한 멋진 카페들도 많이 있습니다.

포트루이스에는 관광할 만한 곳들이 있지만, 흔히 있는 관광지의 함정에 빠지지 않도록 주의해야 합니다. 현지 식당의 메뉴는 관광객을 염두에 두고 만들지 않기 때문에, 가장 맛있는 식사 장소를 찾기 위해 현지인에게 물어보는 것이 좋습니다. 또한, 이 도시는 다소 거칠고 깨끗하지 않을 수 있지만, 인근의 자연—르 모르뉴에서 하이킹을 하거나 조용한 해변에서 시간을 보내는 경험은 훌륭합니다! 항상 방문을 한층 더 즐겁게 만들기 위해 지역의 팁과 인맥을 찾아보세요. 그러면 모리셔스에서 아주 즐거운 시간을 보낼 수 있을 것입니다!

reviews:
Porto Alegre (POA) is a city brimming with beautiful Nature. Trees and birds galore. Unfortunately, there is much wasted potential where historical architecture and intelligent zoning are concerned. I've traveled throughout Brazil and lived in Sao Paulo, and I can attest that POA has the best food hands down. Customer service is top notch, and the shopping is good. Love the vintage stores and antique shops too. Sunsets on the lake are a treasure. 

Gauchos are the most "talkative" people I've ever met in my life (and I am a world traveler who has lived in other countries). Being chatty isn't a bad thing, but the problem here is that the vast majority of people only talk about THEMSELVES. Oftentimes, non-stop. They don't ask questions about you because they have no interest. It's about showing off where they've eaten, traveled, studied, etc. Even the taxi and Uber drivers behave in this manner. Living in a city full narcissists / braggarts gets draining. After years of being here, I've arrived at the conclusion that it's cultural (not malicious). Aside from this, they are very nice people. NOTE: In the countryside, the Gauchos tend to be polite, modest, and well-mannered.

Porto Alegre is so much fun, peaceful and has tons of things for you to do. Two of the major Brazilian soccer teams have their homes here. Weather is great all year long and the beaches are less than 100k away. Gotta love the gaucho food, the best steak in the world no doubt about that.
The profile photo is from Porto, Portugal, Not Porto Alegre in Brasil.
porto-alegre.description:
Located in Southern Brazil, Porto Alegre is a city that combines nature and culture. It has many trees and colorful birds, making it pleasant to see. Food lovers will be happy—Porto Alegre has some of the best food in Brazil! From tasty steaks to local dishes, the food scene here is very good. Additionally, customer service is helpful and vintage shops provide a special touch to shopping.

The locals, often called Gauchos, are known for being talkative, which can be both nice and tiring. Many visitors notice how friendly the people are, even if conversations often focus on their own lives. This is a part of the culture! For sports fans, the city's love for soccer is clear, with two major teams.

While Porto Alegre has good weather all year and nearby beaches for a quick getaway, it's important to remember that public transportation options are somewhat limited. The city is enjoyable and calm, perfect for those looking for relaxation, but some patience with the locals' conversations may be needed. Enjoy sunsets by the lake and take in all the experiences Porto Alegre has to offer!
porto-alegre.description_kor:
브라질 남부에 위치한 포르투 알레그레는 자연과 문화가 어우러진 매력적인 도시입니다. 이곳은 무성한 나무와 형형색색의 새들로 가득해 아름다운 경관을 자랑합니다. 음식의 맛을 즐기는 사람들은 이곳에서 큰 만족을 느낄 수 있습니다. 포르투 알레그레는 브라질 최고의 음식들이 풍성하게 마련되어 있습니다! 입에서 살살 녹는 스테이크부터 전통적인 지역 요리까지, 이곳의 음식 문화는 정말 훌륭해요. 게다가 친절한 고객 서비스와 빈티지 상점들이 쇼핑에 특별한 재미를 더해줍니다.

현지인들은 종종 '가우초'라고 불리며, 수다스럽기로 유명합니다. 이것은 때로 좋기도 하고 때로는 피곤할 수도 있습니다. 많은 방문객들은 이곳 사람들의 친절함을 느끼며, 대화의 주제가 자신의 삶에 집중되는 경우도 많지만, 그 또한 괜찮습니다. 이는 문화의 일부분이니까요! 스포츠 팬들은 축구에 대한 이 도시의 열정이 두 팀의 존재를 통해 확연히 드러나는 것을 보게 될 것입니다.

포르투 알레그레는 연중 좋은 날씨와 가까운 해변 덕분에 빠른 휴식을 즐기기에 최적의 장소이지만, 대중교통 옵션이 다소 제한적이라는 점은 염두에 두어야 합니다. 이 도시는 즐거움과 평온함을 동시에 제공하며, 휴식을 원하는 이들에게 완벽한 장소입니다. 단, 현지인들과의 대화에서는 약간의 인내가 필요할 수도 있답니다. 호숫가에서 석양을 감상하며 포르투 알레그레에서의 특별한 경험을 만끽해 보세요!

reviews:
Portimão, Praia da Rocha, Alvor, and the beaches of Vau and Prainha are the gems of the Algarve! 🌴☀️

- Europe's finest digital nomad community can be found in Portimão: Portimão Digital Nomads (search on Facebook). They host free events to connect with people every two weeks! 🌐👥

- The prices for food, accommodation, and entertainment are very reasonable, much more affordable than the rest of Europe. 💰🍽️🎉

- The locals are incredibly friendly and fun-loving! 😄🤝

- There's only one drawback, and that is sometimes when you arrive as a digital nomad, the place is so beautiful that you might want to stay forever! 🌅🌍✨

Portimão on loistava valinta niin diginomadeille kuin muillekin etätyöläisille. Sopivan kokoinen kaupunki tarjoaa tekemistä ja kokemista vuoden ympäri, eikä hiljene liikaa talvellakaan paikallisen yhteisön ansiosta. Täällä voi patikoida, pyöräillä, surffata, suppailla, joogata, käydä kuntosalilla ja ulkoilla eri tavoin. Kaupungissa on myös teatteri- ja konserttitarjontaa, leffateatteri, taidetapahtumia ja erilaisia festivaaleja.
Portimão Digital Nomads on ihana yhteisö, josta saa paljon neuvoja, tukea, kansainvälisiä ystäviä ja seuraa kaikenlaiseen tekemiseen.

Are you tired of the same old 9-to-5 grind? Yearning for a life of adventure, freedom, and endless sunshine? Look no further, Portimao boasts some of the most breathtaking beaches in Europe. Imagine white sands, crystal-clear waters, and endless horizons. Your office view will be envy-inducing, and your daily dip in the sea is just steps away.

Portimao is not just a destination; it's a community of like-minded individuals pursuing their dreams. Connect with fellow digital nomads, share ideas, and collaborate in a welcoming, innovative atmosphere. The opportunities for networking are boundless.

Escape the high cost of living in major cities! In Portimao, you can enjoy a high-quality lifestyle without breaking the bank. Accommodation, food, and leisure activities come at a fraction of the cost compared to other digital nomad hotspots.

Nearly every day is a sunny one in Portimao. Say goodbye to gloomy weather and hello to endless summer vibes. Perfect for those who thrive in the sun!

Celebrate life at the region's almost monthly festivals. Witness the grandeur of the Loule Carnival, one of Europe's oldest carnivals. Join in the immersive Black & White Party in Carvoeiro, where the entire town transforms into a vibrant festival of music and street celebrations. And for the music enthusiasts, don't miss the globally renowned AfroNation on Praia de Rocha.

Savor fresh seafood, local delicacies, and international cuisine at Portimao's vibrant eateries. Fuel your creativity with an array of culinary experiences, all within walking distance of your new home.

Portimao offers a variety of coworking hubs equipped with high-speed internet, ergonomic seating, and stunning views. Boost your productivity in a professional environment.

Immerse yourself in Portuguese culture, from traditional festivals to art exhibitions. Portimao's rich history and vibrant arts scene will keep your creative juices flowing.

In Portimao, work-life balance isn't just a buzzword; it's a way of life. After a productive workday, enjoy watersports, hiking, or simply unwind with a sunset beach yoga session.

Located in the Algarve region, Portimao offers excellent connectivity with international airports, making it easy to explore Europe and beyond during your breaks.

A gem with a great nomad community. Great beached, bars and plenty of restaurants. Check out the wider area and join the Portimão Digital Nomads group on fb and WhatsApp, they have regular meet ups and post details of other events. They also have a co work space in Alvor

Ik woon sinds een jaar in Portimão. In eerste instantie was het een tijdelijk idee, maar inmiddels hebben we besloten te blijven en dit zijn de redenen:
* prachtige kustlijn met veel natuurbehoud, waar we elke dag heerlijk kunnen zwemmen, hiken etc.
* Portimão is een stad waar "echte mensen wonen", dus ook buiten het toeristenseizoen blijft alles doordraaien.
* een geweldige en heel actieve digital Nomads community, dus gelijk mensen leren kennen en leuke sociale fingen ondernemen.
* 45 minuten rijden v.a. vliegveld
* alles wat je nodig hebt is in de buurt (shopping malls, ziekenhuizen, restaurants, scholen, veel sportmogelijkheden en clubs voor kinderen, etc. etc.
* Co-working faciliteiten!

If you are looking for many activity and sport options, all the conveniences, and spectacular year-round weather, Portimao is the choice for you. For me it is the best balance of a small-town community of friends together with modern infrastructure (including fast internet), not to mention an affordable cost of living, good food and a walkable size.

I've stayed in different places in Portugal, but finally decided to spend more time in Portimao. The community is amazing and rapidly growing. There are regular meetups and many groups for activities like padel, surfing, skating, etc. The beaches in Praia da Rocha and Alvor are fabulous. And the town has all the services you need. It's also well connected by direct bus with Lisbon and Sevilla. Portimao is definitely a great place to live and work from!

Portimão é a cidade de tamanho perfeito para ter todas as comodidades como centro comercial e hospital, mas suficientemente pequena para poder andar por todo o lado. Adoramos a comida e o clima, as actividades de Inverno e os desportos, e as pessoas fantásticas.

Portimao is definitely the best city to work remotely in the Algarve. It is easy to find any type of service and the city is very beautiful and dynamic. If you come here, I recommend looking for the 🧡 "Portimao digital nomads" group on Facebook, they are a very friendly group and hold many events.
Exceptional digital nomads community! Amazing cafes with ocean views to work at, cool night life, and very good sea food! All really cheap!

I moved to Portimão 4 years ago and I think it was the best decision ever. It's the right mixture of a working town and holiday destination. There's something going on all year round. Great beaches and nature, lots of outdoor activities, lovely people, the best wines 😉 there's an awesome remote worker / digital nomads community and fast Wi-Fi. I feel so lucky to live in this beautiful place!!!

We researched many towns in the Algarve before choosing Portimao, and we are so glad we did because we love it! Portimao is the best for year round activities and events and sports, wonderful weather, convenient facilities like shopping and hospitals, great food and wine options, and a low cost of living. It is easy to get by without speaking Portuguese, but there are plenty of locals to meet and practice so you can learn. It is easy to safely walk anywhere, or you can take the bus, rideshare, bicycle or train. Infrastructure is good with fast internet and plenty of places for a digital nomad to work. We chose the Praia da Rocha area for the restaurants and fun atmosphere, but there are quieter and less expensive areas like Alvor if you prefer. We
Portimao , best place for digital nomads. Everything you need, international community, many activties and sports, and great cost of living

We are a couple from Denmark, who decided to move to the Algarve in 2020 (in the pandemic); we live in many places (Tavira, Lagos, Albufeira, before finding our favorite place: Portimao). We live in the Praia da Rocha area; an area full of life "all year round"; where we can make friends of all nationalities. A very safe area with all the comforts of a big city (without being a big city). We are in love :D
Já estou em Portimão há 6 meses e posso dizer que encontrei o sítio ideal que combina qualidade de vida com trabalho remoto. Estou a considerar ficar por cá. Recomendo.

I am reading the comments and it is true; the Praia da Rocha area has a "Miami or California vibe"; It needs to have more parks and bike paths; but in general I also think that it is the best place to live in Algarve as a digital nomad all year round.

I have been living in the Algarve for 3 years. I have lived in Lagos, Albuferia, Faro and now Portimao. 
All the towns are extremely beautiful and the climate is spectacular. 
But if I had to choose one to live all year round, it would undoubtedly be Portimao. (not the prettiest, but you have everything and it makes your life easier). It also has its charm (it looks like a small Miami from the 80s).

Of all the areas of Portimao to live, I prefer Praia da Rocha. ❤️

I lived, for 2 years in Lagos (a very nice town, but a ghost town in winter). The only cities livable all year round in the Algarve are Portimao and Faro (and Portimao seems much more enjoyable to me).

We love living in Praia da Rocha, it is a very beautiful city and you have everything at hand (there are more beautiful towns in the Algarve, but they do not have all the comforts to live all year round, just like Portimao. Portimao is a working-class town , and Praia da Rocha is more of a resort town (both could be better cared for, but in general lines it is fine)

We are an Italian couple (recently moved to Portimao a few months ago). We love the Praia da Rocha area (it has a resemblance to Miami but in a small way). Spectacular beaches, warm water, low cost of living. highly recommended.

I moved to Portimao about 1 year ago (in the Praia da Rocha area) and I couldn't be happier. Locals are super friendly, and it is very easy to make friends. 

 The parties are incredible and there are many sports to do (at affordable prices). 

There is sunshine 300 days a year, the average internet speed is 100mb, and the cost of living is approx € 1600 (including the rent of 700 for a 1 bedroom apartment). 

Now I plan to move here after visiting other places in the Algarve (Lagos, Carvoeiro, Vilamoura, Albufeira), I think that Portimao is the best to live all year round (and the most fun).
portimao.description:
Portimão, located in the Algarve region of Portugal, is a lively area with sun, sea, and a strong community. Picture the soft white sands at Praia da Rocha or Alvor, where you can relax in the sun or try surfing, paddle boarding, and more. The cost of living here is a nice surprise; you will find affordable food, good restaurants, and fun activities that are budget-friendly.

The locals are friendly and welcoming, making it easy for newcomers to feel comfortable. Portimão has an active digital nomad community, with regular meetups to connect and collaborate. Most people manage without speaking Portuguese, but learning a few basic phrases can be enjoyable.

However, be prepared to want to stay longer! The city has a lively atmosphere all year due to local festivals and cultural events, so there is always something happening. If you are looking for a balance of work and leisure, along with a sense of community, Portimão could be the right place for you!
portimao.description_kor:
포르투갈 Algarve 지역의 포르티망은 태양과 바다, 그리고 풍부한 커뮤니티가 어우러진 활기찬 곳입니다. 해변에서의 편안한 여유를 만끽하고 싶다면 Praia da Rocha나 Alvor의 부드럽고 하얀 모래를 상상해 보세요. 여기서는 일광욕을 즐기거나 서핑, 패들 보딩 같은 다양한 수상 스포츠도 시도할 수 있습니다. 

이곳의 생활비는 정말 놀라운데요, 저렴한 가격에 맛있는 식사를 즐길 수 있는 좋은 레스토랑과 예산에 맞는 다양한 활동들이 준비되어 있습니다. 

현지 주민들은 아주 친절하고 환영해 주어서, 새로운 사람들도 쉽게 편안함을 느낄 수 있습니다. 포르티망에는 활발한 디지털 노마드 커뮤니티가 있어, 사람들과 연결되고 협업할 수 있는 다양한 모임이 정기적으로 열립니다. 대부분의 사람들은 포르투갈어를 하지 않아도 생활하는 데 불편함이 없지만, 기본적인 몇 가지 문구를 배우는 것도 즐거운 경험이 될 거예요. 

그렇지만, 길게 머물고 싶어질 준비는 해두세요! 이 도시는 지역 축제와 문화 행사 덕분에 연중 내내 생동감 넘치는 분위기를 유지하고 있어, 항상 무언가 재미있고 특별한 일이 일어나고 있습니다. 일과 여가의 균형을 첫 번째로 생각하고, 커뮤니티의 일원이 되고 싶다면 포르티망이 여러분에게 딱 맞는 장소일 수 있습니다!

reviews: I felt very uncomfortable here. There were people doing drugs everywhere. It was intimidating as a female traveller as i felt quite unsafe. It's a shame because i've heard good things, but personally I didnt see the appeal.

Pros: Food carts, local microbrews, lots of outdoor activities within day trip range, high property values.
Cons: trash everywhere, out of control crime, violent drug-addicted "houseless" everywhere, mediocre public schools, some of the highest taxes in the country, ineffective police force, antiquated inefficient form of city government, very high rents, passive aggressive culture.

-Very well situated between the ocean and mountains
-Cloudy winters
-Not much snow
-Large Asian minority
-LGBTQ+ friendly
-High quality of living
-Very expensive
-Very good nightlife
-A lot of parks
-A lot of outdoor activities
-1 of the best education systems in the USA
-Healthcare is excellent
-Good transit system
Hipster capital of the world
portland.description:
Portland is a city with its own style, located between the ocean and mountains. You will find a mix of local food, especially the well-known food carts and craft breweries that many people enjoy. Outdoor lovers appreciate the chance to connect with nature, as there are many day trips to nearby parks and beautiful places.

However, Portland has its problems. Some visitors say they feel uncomfortable because of issues like visible drug use and safety worries, especially for women traveling alone. The city has high living costs and property prices, which shows its attractiveness but makes life hard for some people. While Portland is known for its lively culture, not everyone gets along with the local way of life, which can sometimes feel a bit unfriendly.

With a good public transportation system and an open attitude, especially towards the LGBTQ+ community, there is much to enjoy. Just remember to plan your activities around the city’s often rainy weather. So, visit the parks, enjoy the nightlife, and see what makes Portland interesting, but also be aware of the local community!
portland.description_kor:
포틀랜드는 바다와 산 사이에 위치한 독특한 매력을 가진 도시입니다. 이곳에서는 유명한 푸드 트럭과 많은 사람들에게 사랑받는 수제 맥주 양조장이 있는 등 다양한 지역 음식 문화를 경험할 수 있습니다. 자연과의 교감을 중시하는 야외 활동 애호가들은 근처의 공원이나 아름다운 여행지에서 당일치기 여행을 즐기고 있습니다.

하지만 포틀랜드에도 몇 가지 문제점이 있습니다. 일부 방문객들은 눈에 띄는 약물 사용과 안전 문제 때문에 불편함을 느끼고 있으며, 특히 혼자 여행하는 여성들에게는 더 큰 우려가 됩니다. 이 도시는 높은 생활비와 부동산 가격으로 인해 매력적이지만 일부 사람들에게는 생활이 힘들게 느껴질 수 있습니다. 포틀랜드는 활기찬 문화로 유명하지만, 모든 사람들이 지역 생활 방식에 잘 적응하지는 못해 때때로 다소 불친절하게 느껴질 수 있습니다.

여기에는 잘 발달된 대중교통 시스템과 LGBTQ+ 커뮤니티에 대한 열린 태도가 있어 다양한 즐길 거리가 있습니다. 다만, 잦은 비를 고려하여 일정을 계획하는 것을 잊지 마세요. 그러니 공원에 가고, 밤문화를 즐기며 포틀랜드의 매력을 만끽해보세요. 동시에 지역 커뮤니티에도 관심을 가지는 것을 잊지 마시길 바랍니다!

reviews:
TLDR; I wouldn't recommend for long-term stays.

First time in Cabo Verde (Sal), and I can't say I would recommend it for anything other than tourism or short-term stays. Don't get me wrong, it's lovely and exotic, and people are warm and welcoming, but it can get pretty boring after 30 days. 

Cost of living is NOT cheap. Groceries are much more expensive than in any other places we've travelled to in the last two years. Restaurants are all the same price (around 30€ for 2 people) and pretty much serve the same thing. Food variety is not great.

If you come here for surfing, the waves are inconsistent at best and, at worst, non-existent. 

On paper, it seems like a nice idea. In reality, it feels like locals and the government hired good marketers to sell the destination to digital nomads. 

On the bright side, we had stable internet and it was sunny EVERY day. It's always windy in Santa Maria, so you don't need AC. Most people speak perfect English or understand at least.

First time in Sal and its been such an easy experience. From the airport to getting settled in. Everyone is so helpful and warm hearted. Cost of living is very reasonable - 5€ to eat at a restaurant (fish, sides, wine and dessert). I highly recommend making contact with a local taxi driver. Its easy to set up a daily agreement for your time on the island. Spending 5€ a day to be taken into town and back to airbnb. I am sure you could get it much much cheaper but I was happy to pay a bit more to contribute. 

Recommend getting a local sim too so you can hot spot where the cafes do not have WiFi. In Santa Maria it's very common to find WiFi. 

Recommend bringing a filtering water bottle the water is desalinated and you can reduce waste. Water restrictions apply on the island too due to all inclusive hotels requiring most the water. So shorter showers are better. 

Some of the supermarkets are foreign owned but the locals will tell you which ones. Island has multiple computer shops which is helpful for your office needs if something breaks or you need new equipment. 

Generally speaking if you like haggling things can be quite cheap here. Key thing is to be conscious on where your money is going. Is it locally or to an overseas person/company. 

Island hopping is near impossible without a local connection. If you book independently the prices are extortionate. So when you arrive, find a local driver, meet some local people, get involved with some local sports, etc. Then it's much easier to get what you need done. People and life here is all about connection. Get involved with the community.

Highly recommend coming here and checking out Carbo Verde
praia.description:
Located in the Cape Verde islands, Praia offers a nice spot for a tropical vacation, but it may not be ideal for living long-term. The local atmosphere is friendly, and people are happy to share their culture and smiles. The sunny weather and steady winds make it a good place for sun lovers, without needing air conditioning.

However, be aware that living expenses can increase quickly. Eating out? Plan to spend about 30€ for two people, as food options can get a bit repetitive. If you want to surf, the waves may not always be great.

In terms of transportation, public options can be limited, but a local taxi driver can make getting around easier and even help you get a better price. Enjoy local activities and haggle at markets to experience the island life. To have a better visit, consider getting a local SIM card and taking a water bottle with a filter since there are water restrictions. Get involved, make friends, and enjoy the unique feel of Praia!
praia.description_kor:
카보베르데 제도에 위치한 프라이라(Praia)는 열대 휴가를 즐기기에 아주 좋은 장소입니다. 하지만 장기 거주하기에는 조금 아쉬울 수도 있습니다. 현지 사람들은 매우 친절하고, 그들의 문화와 미소를 나누는 데 열정적입니다. 맑고 화창한 날씨와 지속적인 바람 덕분에 애리컨 없이도 태양을 즐기는 사람들에게는 안성맞춤입니다.

하지만 생활비는 빠르게 오를 수 있으니 주의가 필요합니다. 외식을 계획하고 있다면, 두 사람이서 약 30€ 정도의 비용을 예상해야 하고, 음식의 종류가 다소 반복적일 수 있다는 점을 고려해야 합니다. 서핑을 원하신다면, 언제나 파도가 좋은 것은 아니라는 점도 염두에 두셔야 합니다.

교통편은 대중교통 선택지가 제한적일 수 있기 때문에 지역 택시를 이용하면 더 편리하고 좋은 가격으로 이동할 수 있습니다. 현지 시장에서 흥정을 하며 다양한 활동을 즐기며 섬의 매력을 한껏 느껴보세요. 여행을 보다 편리하게 하려면 현지 SIM 카드를 구매하고 정수기가 있는 물병을 가져가는 것이 좋습니다. 물 사용 규제가 있으니 이 점도 참고해주세요. 프라이라의 독특한 매력을 만끽하시면서 새로운 친구도 사귀어 보세요!

reviews: Poznan is a beautiful with warm and relaxed people. I was not expecting such a vibe and beautiful City. It is way more beautiful compared to Warsaw. Nice to see there is quite alot of Nomads and Coworking spaces in Poznan nowadays :)
Not safe for women? I feel very safe here and walk late at night from the train station. Like any town, there are the gypsies and drunks but no, no real problems.

Was recently in POZNAN, and saw there was a huge pro-abortion movement in the old town + outer parts of it. 
My first impression was that the city ressembles a lot with PRAGUE and WARSAW. Hills + big squares with covered tram tracks. 
The pedestrian area is really nice. 1 or 2 days would be enough to check the city.
Good nightlife, a lot of young people too. Cozy old town center. Avoid clubs with credit card scams, avoid any invites to extravagant clubs
poznan.description:
Poznan is a city in Poland that surprises many people with its friendly atmosphere. Visitors often say it is even nicer than Warsaw. The old town center, with its areas for walking, is a nice place to explore. It has a relaxed vibe, and you will see many young people enjoying the nightlife. With many coworking spaces opening, it is also becoming a place for digital nomads.

Most people feel safe walking around, even at night, but some suggest being careful in certain parts, like in any city. There can be language barriers, but the friendly locals usually want to help. Poznan also has cultural events, like a recent pro-abortion gathering, making it an interesting place to be.

In terms of visiting, a couple of days is enough to see the main sights. However, avoid certain clubs to prevent scams. Overall, Poznan has a good mix of history, culture, and modern life—making it a city worth visiting.
poznan.description_kor:
포즈난은 폴란드에 위치한 도시로, 친근한 분위기로 많은 사람들을 매료시키고 있습니다. 방문객들은 종종 이곳이 바르샤바보다 훨씬 더 매력적이라고 말하곤 합니다. 구시가지 중심지는 산책하기 좋은 구역으로 탐험하기에 완벽한 장소입니다. 이곳에서는 편안한 분위기 속에서 많은 젊은이들이 활기찬 밤문화를 즐기는 모습을 쉽게 볼 수 있습니다. 또, 다양한 코워킹 스페이스가 생기면서 디지털 노마드들에게도 매우 적합한 장소로 자리 잡고 있습니다.

대부분의 사람들은 밤에 걷는 것이 안전하다고 느끼지만, 모든 도시에 그렇듯이 특정 지역에서는 주의가 필요합니다. 언어 장벽이 있을 수 있지만, 친절한 현지인들은 대체로 도움을 주고 싶어 합니다. 포즈난은 최근의 임신 중단 찬성 집회와 같은 문화 행사들도 열려 흥미로운 이벤트가 많습니다.

주요 명소를 둘러보는 데에는 이틀 정도면 충분하지만, 사기를 예방하기 위해서는 특정 클럽을 피하는 것이 좋습니다. 전반적으로 포즈난은 역사와 문화, 현대적인 생활이 잘 어우러진 매력적인 도시로, 꼭 방문해 볼 가치가 있습니다.

reviews:
Pro: Practically all places in Provo and Orem have fiber optic internet available.
Pro/Con: It's also home to two different 4-year Universities. 
Con: The city of Provo is so Mormon that they even have billboards that don't make sense if you aren't familiar with their culture, and if you are it's still cringe.
provo.description:
Provo is a mix of a college town and a family-friendly community, making it an interesting place to visit. With two universities, there is a youthful energy that keeps things active. One of the best things is the fast fiber optic internet available almost everywhere, which is great for remote work or watching shows.

On the other hand, Provo’s strong Mormon culture might feel a little much for some people. You might see billboards that are confusing if you don’t know the local customs. While some find this nice, others may not feel comfortable.

For visitors, walking by the Provo River or exploring the historic downtown area is important. Just remember that public transportation might not be very good, so having a car can be helpful. Overall, Provo has a mix of natural beauty and culture—you just need to be open to it!
provo.description_kor:
프로보는 대학 도시와 가족 친화적인 커뮤니티가 어우러진 흥미로운 곳입니다. 두 개의 대학이 있어 젊은 에너지가 넘치고, 덕분에 생기찬 분위기가 만들어집니다. 이곳의 큰 장점 중 하나는 거의 모든 곳에서 이용할 수 있는 빠른 광섬유 인터넷인데, 원격 근무나 TV 시청에 매우 유용합니다.

하지만 프로보의 강한 몰몬 문화는 일부 사람들에게는 다소 부담스럽게 느껴질 수 있습니다. 지역 풍습을 잘 모른다면 혼란스러운 광고판이 눈에 띌 수도 있습니다. 어떤 이들은 이를 긍정적으로 바라보지만, 다른 이들은 불편함을 느낄 수도 있습니다.

방문객들은 프로보 강을 따라 산책하거나 역사적인 다운타운을 탐험하는 걸 추천합니다. 공공교통이 다소 불편할 수 있으니, 차를 이용하면 더욱 수월합니다. 전반적으로 프로보는 자연의 아름다움과 문화가 조화롭게 어우러진 곳으로, 열린 마음만 있으면 즐길 수 있는 멋진 장소입니다!

reviews: Dirty cheap, you can live a very comfortable life there for way less than 1,000 USD. It’s literally a “new” country, young crowd, mostly unemployed but very hardworking. Energy is vibrant and people are really welcoming. It’s safe and not much to see and do, what is great for getting the work done.
pristina.description:
Pristina is a lively city, making it a good place for those who want to see a mix of energy and hard work. The cost of living is very affordable—many people live comfortably on less than 1,000 USD a month. Although it may not have many tourist attractions, that helps you focus on important things—getting your work done and enjoying the friendly atmosphere.

The people here are known for being friendly and welcoming, which makes you feel at home. Safety is good, which is a big benefit. The cultural scene is growing, showing how this new country is forming its identity. Just remember that public transportation can be lacking at times, and some may have trouble with the language.

As for activities? While the city doesn’t have many sights, there are many nice cafés and local places where you can enjoy the setting. You will likely connect with the locals and maybe find some hidden treasures in Pristina!
pristina.description_kor:
프리쉬티나는 활기 넘치는 도시로, 에너지와 열정을 경험하고 싶은 이들에게 안성맞춤인 곳입니다. 생활비가 매우 저렴해 많은 사람들이 한 달에 1,000달러 이하로도 편안하게 지낼 수 있습니다. 관광 명소는 많지 않지만, 오히려 중요한 것들에 집중할 수 있는 기회를 제공합니다. 일에 집중하고, 따뜻한 분위기를 즐기는 것이죠.

이곳 사람들은 친절하고 환영해주기로 유명해 마치 집에 있는 듯한 편안함을 느낄 수 있습니다. 안전 면에서도 우수해 큰 장점이 됩니다. 최근 문화적인 장면도 급속도로 발전하고 있어, 이 새로운 나라가 어떻게 정체성을 만들어가고 있는지를 잘 보여줍니다. 단, 대중교통이 가끔 부족할 수 있고, 언어 장벽으로 어려움을 겪는 경우도 있다는 점은 염두에 두셔야 합니다.

활동적인 면에서는 이 도시에 많은 관광 명소가 없지만, 아늑한 카페와 현지 맛집이 많아 그곳의 매력을 만끽할 수 있습니다. 현지인들과 쉽게 어울릴 수 있고, 프리쉬티나에서 숨은 보물을 발견할 수도 있습니다!

reviews: Puerto Viejo has grown in recent years. Before wifi was hard to find. Now with several high speed co working spots like "Boa Coworking and cafe". Office in the jungle but walking distance to all thats necessary!

I don’t know why Costa Rican cities aren’t ranked higher on this list. Puerto Viejo is an amazing fun little town with a lot to do. I took a bus ride here from Bocas Del Toro, Panama after spending time there and I really enjoyed it. 

It’s great because it’s like a mix of Carribean and Latin American vibes. There are so many outdoor activities to do here. there‘a Cahuita national park if you want to go hiking and see a lot of cool animals, there’s beach volleyball everyday at playa cocles, the black sand beach at playa negra is beautiful, Punta Uva has some stunning views. It also has the best food in Costa Rica since the food is more Jamaican inspired. Every evening there’s usually something going on somewhere whether it’s salsa night, reggaeton night, carribean music night, or an EDM DJ playing. The most popular places for nightlife have their outdoor area right on the beach is also really cool. I was initially worried about getting reliable Wi-Fi but it actually turned out to work fine at my airbnb and most cafe/lunch spots. There aren’t really coworking spaces though.

The main cons I see is that it’s still Costa Rica so it is pricier than other nearby countries. Also the tech & medical infrastructure is not the best and it’s kind of far from any major cities so if you get sick/injured or need to buy some tech merchandise it will cause some difficulty. Last if you’re looking for a digital nomad community to do some networking you’re not going to find that here.

Overall I give it a 6.5/10 for nomading and an 8/10 for vacation.

In general, Puerto Viejo is a nice place to visit. Safe unless you insist going around with valuables and healthy unless you Purposely look for something else. You can have a great experience if you try to talk to locals and understand local habits. I had a very nice familiar and human experience with some locals who rent a container house in Cocles, in the middle of the jungle, unique experience El Nido del Buho.
puerto-viejo.description:
Puerto Viejo is a lively place on Costa Rica’s Caribbean coast that is full of fun and a mix of cultures. Picture walking down colorful streets where every evening has different music in the air—like salsa, reggaeton, or beach sounds. And don’t forget the food! You’ll find tasty dishes with Jamaican flavors that you will enjoy.

For those who like outdoor activities, there are many to choose from, like hiking in the green Cahuita National Park or enjoying the views at Punta Uva. If you like volleyball, Playa Cocles has daily games to join. However, while Puerto Viejo is a nice vacation spot, it can be a bit more expensive than nearby countries. Also, the technology and medical services may not be great, and the area is somewhat far from big cities.

On the positive side, the local people are friendly—make sure to talk to them for a unique experience. Just keep your belongings safe and you will have a good time! Enjoy your stay in this busy coastal town!
puerto-viejo.description_kor:
푸에르토 비에호는 코스타리카 카리브 해안에 자리한 활기찬 장소로, 즐거움과 다양한 문화가 가득합니다. 매일 저녁, 서로 다른 음악이 흐르는 화려한 거리를 거닐며 살사, 레게톤, 해변의 파도 소리까지 다양한 소리를 만끽해 보세요. 그리고 맛있는 음식을 잊지 마세요! 자메이카의 풍미가 가득한 다양한 요리들도 즐길 수 있습니다.

아웃도어 활동을 좋아하시는 분들을 위해 흥미로운 선택지가 많습니다. 푸에르토 비에호 인근의 푸른 카휘타 국립공원에서 하이킹을 하거나 푼타 우바에서 아름다운 경치를 감상할 수 있습니다. 만약 배구를 좋아하신다면, 플라야 코클레즈에서 매일 게임에 참여할 수 있답니다. 다만, 푸에르토 비에호는 좋은 휴양지이긴 하지만 인근 국가에 비해 조금 더 비쌀 수 있습니다. 또, 기술 및 의료 서비스가 그리 발달하지 않았고, 대도시에서 다소 멀리 떨어져 있다는 점도 염두에 두셔야 합니다.

긍정적인 점은 현지 사람들이 정말 친절하다는 것입니다. 꼭 그들과 대화해 보세요. 독특한 경험이 될 거예요. 단, 소지품은 안전하게 챙기시고, 즐거운 시간을 만끽하시기 바랍니다! 이 활기찬 해안 마을에서 멋진 시간을 보내세요!

reviews: Very good, Glorious leader Kim Jong-Un helped me see the true beauty of TRUE KOREA.
pyongyang.description:
Pyongyang is different from any place you may have visited before. This city shows its own charm and culture, while also remembering its history and leaders. Many visitors notice the large buildings and wide, clean streets. Kim Il Sung Square is a must-see, great for taking pictures of the skyline.

While you enjoy the sights, it’s good to know that the cost of living is usually low, making it affordable to explore the city. Public transportation is easy to use, but be sure to plan ahead, as choices can be limited.

However, understand that navigating the culture can be difficult, including strict rules and a language barrier, so it might help to learn some phrases or have a guide. Safety is strong here, and you will often feel comfortable as you walk around the city.

Finally, talking with locals and taking part in traditional customs can give you a better understanding of Pyongyang's unique character. Overall, enjoy the experience and this different way of life!
pyongyang.description_kor:
평양은 이전에 방문했던 어떤 도시와도 확연히 다릅니다. 이 도시는 독특한 매력과 문화를 간직하면서도 역사와 지도자에 대한 기억을 잃지 않고 있습니다. 많은 관광객들이 거대한 건물들과 넓고 깨끗한 거리에 주목하곤 합니다. 특히 김일성 광장은 꼭 가봐야 할 명소로, 스카이라인을 사진으로 담기에 제격입니다.

관광을 즐기며, 비교적 저렴한 생활비 덕분에 도시를 쉽게 탐방할 수 있다는 점을 기억하면 좋습니다. 대중교통은 이용하기 쉽지만 선택의 폭이 한정적이니, 미리 계획을 세우는 것이 좋습니다.

다만 문화 탐방이 다소 어려울 수 있다는 점은 유념해야 합니다. 특히 엄격한 규칙과 언어 장벽이 있어, 몇 가지 기본적인 문구를 익히거나 가이드를 함께 하는 것이 큰 도움이 될 것입니다. 이곳은 안전한 편이라, 도시를 돌아다니며 편안함을 느낄 수 있습니다.

마지막으로, 현지인과 대화하고 전통적인 풍습에 참여하는 것은 평양의 독특한 매력을 더욱 깊이 이해하는 데 큰 도움이 됩니다. 전반적으로 이 새로운 경험과 다른 삶의 방식을 마음껏 즐기시기 바랍니다!

reviews:
Second time in Puerto and a lot has changed in the last year. The secret is out. Construction is rampant everywhere, it’s just build, build, build and it’s only going to get more intense. The new highway has opened up, which makes the trip from Oaxaca only 3 hours. Local Mexicans come for long weekends since the drive is now tolerable, which is packing the town. 

It feels like the majority of foreigners I meet either want to start a business or own real estate here. I never made it to Bali, but from the conversations I’ve had for other DN, this is like Bali right before post-pandemic. It’s strange - everyone you chat with knows this area is heading for Tulum, yet too many people just have dollar signs in their eyes - or in this case Mexican Pesos.

This is no longer a sleepy surf town. Come see it soon before it gets nuts. The clock is ticking.

I wrote the last review and want to give an update. I’ve been in Puerto for about 3 months now, and I feel like that’s more than enough for me. I standby everything I wrote in the previous review with a few additions:

- This town is incredibly small and word travels fast. You will see the same people when grocery shopping, when you stop at an Oxxo for petrol, and when you go to the late night bars. Lots of unnecessary immature drama/in-fighting. I try to stay away from these people. I would recommend you do the same.

- The police have stepped up the corruption. They are essentially legal criminals. Please wear a helmet and have a proper motorcycle/scooter license. Don’t carry a lot of cash on you. I’ve heard many stories of police stopping people and just taking their money.

- My friend and I were chatting and agreed that Puerto brings a lot of broken people. I’m no exception. Most of the long term people seem to be running away from something. Puerto by its nature is very remote, very hard to access. 

- The town got packed fast when busy season started in October. Prices for accommodations increased a lot. Not sure if it’s worth it unless you want to be at the “it” place.

Happy to have come here and made friends, but not a place to stay more than a few months.

Been here about a month. If you’re like me, you’ve probably seen the digital nomad subreddit rant and rave about this place and wanted to give it a shot. Puerto Escondido has a nice chill vibe, and the beaches are excellent, but deep down it’s really just another surf town. And that’s ok.

Starlink is now widely available and most hotels/guesthouses will openly advertise their internet speed. Mobile phone service and hotspots are still kinda crap and there are still areas that are completely where you will have no service. Electricity will go down once a week (at least in my area) with the longest blackout being a few hours.

As others have stated, the biggest con about Puerto is the noise. In particular, construction noise. Before booking, check to see if previous guests mentioned construction. My guesthouse didn’t mention the 7-day/week, 7am-7pm construction, with the workers living on site and partying at night. All of my housemates complained and demanded partial refunds. Non-aggressive stray dogs are everywhere, which didn’t bother me at first, but their constant barking gets annoying after a while.

The one comment I heard over and over from locals, Central/South Americans, and Western surfer-types was how expensive Puerto is becoming. The conversation of Tulum-ification came up a lot.

Overall, I like Puerto, can see myself staying here a few more months, but not long-term.

Budget:
Room at nice guesthouse next to beach: $650
Motorcycle: $250
Gym: $50
Phone sim: $30
Food + fun: $800

Definitely a place you can digital nomad at. I was here for a month and the internet was never a problem. The noise (constant construction, roosters, dogs and music) and heat were. The surfing was good but even in August there are a lot of people in this sml but developing town.

Internet is not the best but generally acceptable for the type of work I do (infrequent video calls, Slack, web applications, email, no heavy file downloading), except when the internet goes down, it is pretty widespread. Have a local backup SIM, or make sure you have a little flexibility with work. The downsides of the somewhat unreliable internet were made up for, in my opinion, by the beautiful beaches, surfing, and delicious/cheap local food in Centro (La Punta and Zicatela are way too touristy, and overpriced IMO).

I lived there for 3 years... If you wanna work, you'll really struggle. Sometimes the WiFi would be down for like 5 days. If you need to download heavy files you probably wont be able to, WiFi will fall before you can wait the 4 hours it would take. You can rely on your Telcel, but not even that one was working all the time. 
Don't believe the hype! I ended up moving out.

I work online. I found a place with satellite wifi, and while it went down sometimes, I just switched to hotspot off my telcel, or went to a cafe with fiber optic. So, if you work online, and don't need perfect Internet all the time, don't worry about it. I was here three months, was totally able to work online, do zoom calls, etc. I made it work. 

On that note, I love it here. Beautiful beaches, great food, lots of nightlife, local vibes if you get out of La Punta. It's expensive to stay in La Punta now, but the pandemic did that. Great place could easily spend years here. 

If you rent or buy a moto, you can do trips down the coast to Mazunte, Zipolite, etc.

I don't understand all the hype all around PE, there are way cooler places in Mexico that are just as affordable. It's extremely hot, high 80's/low 90's during the day and mid 80s at night. I was doing laundry constantly bc I was always soaked in sweat and I only left the house during the day if was necessary. It made getting things done frustrating. 

There are also lots of bugs. I had a tarantula and a brown recluse spider in my apartment in the first two weeks. I had salamanders falling off my ceiling. It's hard to sleep in if you live in a residential area because the roosters start crowing around 6:30, and that sets off all the dogs and at that point the whole neighborhood's awake. 

Speaking of dogs, they're absolutely everywhere. They're not aggressive, but they will sit next to you and try to beg in restaurants, and you'll even find them in clubs. Once I left my door open (for less than a minute) and I turned around to find a random dog standing in my living room. It was a lot.

A lot of places don't have A/C and you'll still pay up to $900 for a one bedroom. The wifi is really bad and the coworking spaces aren't much better (many don't even have AC but still charge a premium). 

The drinking and cocaine culture is kind of intense. Most of the people I met who loved PE were just partying (so work and WiFi weren't a problem). I couldn't deal with it but I can understand why this would be appealing to some. For me as a professional it was hard to relate to other people there and I heard the same from other nomads.

You will also have to pay way more for everything if you're a foreigner. I would hear the locals laughing with each other about screwing over tourists and that really left a bad taste in my mouth. (I speak Spanish but don't look Latina). If they mess up your order and you don't want it you're still expected to eat it and pay for it. I get the principle but by the end of my trip I was totally fed up.

I know that was a lot but seriously do your research before going. It's a pain to get to and get out of, it's not that cheap, the weather is difficult and it's hard to work. I've spent loads of time in Mexico and this was the one place I couldn't wait to leave.

Bad internet, too many insects when the sun goes down, and too many arrogant French people!
One of the few cities in Mexico I didn't like.

The scores are completely wrong for this town. I have spent 2 years in Puerto Escondido and the internet is terrible and unreliable. Sure, you can find places with high speeds... But those high speeds are not consistent. The internet gets slow at certain parts of the day because too many people are on the same network. The internet (and sometimes electricity) will cut out completely, if you're lucky it will only be for 10 minutes. It is extremely common for the internet to stop working around town for half a day or a full day. It is so unpredictable. It is very difficult to work in this town if a person has a set schedule, if your workdays are completely flexible (no reservations or strict meeting times) then it is doable.

I have to echo the other comments, internet is not sufficient for remote work. Food and taxis are more expensive than expected. However, the weather and beaches are fantastic. La Punta has a more surfer/Bali vibe, but I personally enjoyed the area around Rinconada and Centro. There are also some nice towns along the coast within an hour of P.E., Mazunte, Zipolite...

Don't agree with most of those reviews. There is good internet in some co-work places like Paulina cowork, Losodeli cowork and Blason cafe. It's chill and great to surf, but very slow with very little infrastructure. It's in development because of all tourists.
Don't go here if you actually need to work. Wifi is terrible everywhere you go, some days the whole town goes without any internet connection. Housing is also way overpriced.

Selina's cowork is going under renovations in February & March 2022, meaning it will be closed for those month. Oficia de Puerto cowork is currently day pass only as they sold out week passes. Outside of coworks, the internet is non-existent. 
Playa zicatela is great if you're a great surfer. I'm not sure it's the best for those who aren't.

Great place for a holiday but nearly impossible to work as a nomad here. The internet is terribly slow when it works and sometimes goes down for hours/days at a time. However there are some incredible restaurants and beaches worth discovering. Don't be fooled, it appears close to Oaxaca City but it takes roughly 6 hours by bus on some sketchy mountain roads to get here. Direct flights are hard to come by and you'l likely have to fly back to CDMX just to get to PE.

Been here about 3 weeks & staying another month. If you do your due diligence when looking for a hotel/hostel/airbnb - you can find places with good internet speeds. Casa Bonita has 100MB+, lots of AirBnbs have 10-20+. However, wifi can go down for the day in the whole town (plus 4G). So if you work a 9-5 might not be ideal. 

The weather on Nomadlist is incorrect - the coldest it gets at night here is about 25 & that's in December. In July it's about 32 at night.

I stayed there for about 3 weeks, cheapest beach town I've been in Mexico. Wifi like most people said it already is awful! i can't stress this enough, it's almost nonexistent. The town itself is pretty chill, nice restaurants and beaches, but for nomads not a great place.

The good: 
Great surfing, great food (and pretty cheap), amazing vibe, good nightlife, overall nice lifestyle.

The bad:
- Wifi... it's terrible. The only place I've found with good wifi is Selina Coworking—it's a must.
- Accommodation is actually fairly expensive for what you get in return.
wifi is terrible, unreliable, sometimes the hole city runs out of internet, but still a wonderful place.

Puerto Escondido is wonderful - feels Tulum-y, but much cheaper. However, unlike Tulum, the wifi is terrible. Tried dozens of places, and the speeds are rarely higher than 2-4mpbs, but also unreliable. One exception - Playa Bacocho beach club has good wifi.

i dont know why this tool shows the weather in Puerto Escondido as in the 70s (f). It's always in the mid to high 80s. We're here now (Jan-Feb 2021), and it has consistently been about 85F-88F every day, with low temps around 70F....
puerto-escondido.description:
Puerto Escondido is full of activity and change! Once a quiet surf town, it now attracts everyone from locals on weekend trips to expats looking for new opportunities. With the new highway, it takes only 3 hours to get from Oaxaca, so the beaches are busy with sunbathers and surfers. The charm is still present, with nice beaches and lively nightlife, but be ready for construction noise—it's everywhere!

The weather is generally nice, reaching the high 80s or low 90s, but it can be very hot. Long-term stays can be expensive, especially near tourist areas like La Punta. The WiFi can be mixed; it's usable, but many people experience outages, especially if they have strict work schedules.

Safety can feel uncertain sometimes with some reports of corruption, so it's smart to carry less cash. Despite issues like stray dogs and the occasional bug in your home, the relaxed atmosphere and tasty local food make it a good experience. Just get ready for a blend of fun and disorder, making Puerto Escondido memorable!
puerto-escondido.description_kor:
푸에르토 에스콘디도는 활기로 가득한 변화의 장소입니다! 한때 조용한 서핑 마을이었던 이곳은 이제 주말 여행을 즐기는 현지인들과 새로운 기회를 찾는 외국인들로 넘쳐납니다. 새로운 고속도로 덕분에 오악사카에서 단 3시간 만에 도착할 수 있어, 해변은 일광욕을 즐기는 사람들과 서퍼들로 붐빕니다. 멋진 해변과 활기찬 밤문화 덕분에 여전히 매력적인 곳이지만, 건설 소음이 어느 곳에나 존재하니 이에 대한 준비도 필요합니다. 

날씨는 대체로 좋고 기온은 섭씨 25도 후반에서 30도 초반까지 올라가지만, 매우 더울 때도 있습니다. 관광지인 라 푼타 근처의 장기 숙박은 꽤 비쌀 수 있습니다. WiFi는 상황에 따라 다르지만 사용 가능하긴 해도, 정전 문제 때문에 불편을 겪는 사람들이 많으므로, 특히 업무 일정이 타이트한 경우엔 주의가 필요합니다. 

부패와 관련된 보고서가 가끔 있어 안전에 대한 불안감을 느낄 수 있으니, 현금을 최소한으로 가지고 다니는 것이 좋습니다. 유기견이나 때때로 집 안에 나타나는 벌레 같은 문제는 있지만, 여유로운 분위기와 맛있는 현지 음식은 분명 좋은 경험을 제공합니다. 푸에르토 에스콘디도를 기억에 남는 장소로 만들어줄 즐거움과 약간의 무질서가 공존하니, 마음의 준비를 해두세요!

reviews: Being born there, it's hard to be objective, as most exciting stuff looks dull and tired. But walking in the old town and looking at the castle always makes me feel proud. The city is very cheap considering the living standard (and comparing to other similar Canadian cities). Internet speed are incredibly high and stable even in cheap coffee shops. The coworking scene, either in coffee shops or dedicated workplaces is very interesting. In winter, it gets WAY too cold, but the coldest period lasts from November to March so it's not that bad. Definitely worth a try.
A truly magnificent city with a magnificent culture, architecture and history. Truly worth visiting!
quebec-city.description:
If you’re looking for history and charm, Quebec City will impress you. Walk through the old town, where streets made of stones lead you to the famous castle that never gets old, no matter how many times you see it. The city has a strong culture and interesting buildings that tell stories from long ago.

Living here is quite affordable compared to other Canadian cities, making it a good place for newcomers. Plus, you’ll be pleased to know that internet speeds are very fast, even in small coffee shops, which is great for remote workers or freelancers. However, be prepared for winter—it gets very cold from November to March. But if you dress warmly, it’s part of the city's appeal.

Don’t miss local customs and tasty food that show the region's culture. Keep in mind that language can be a challenge, as French is the main language. Overall, Quebec City is a nice place with friendly locals and a special atmosphere, making it worth a visit or a stay!
quebec-city.description_kor:
역사와 매력을 동시에 느끼고 싶다면 퀘벡 시티는 당신을 감동시킬 것입니다. 돌길을 따라 옛 마을을 거닐고, 언제 보아도 퇴색하지 않는 유명한 성으로 향해 보세요. 이 도시는 깊은 문화와 오랜 역사 이야기를 간직한 흥미로운 건축물들로 가득 차 있습니다.

이곳에서의 생활비는 다른 캐나다 도시에 비해 매우 경제적이어서 새로 이사 오는 이들에게 이상적인 장소입니다. 게다가, 작은 커피숍에서도 인터넷 속도가 매우 빠르니, 이는 원격 근무자나 프리랜서들에게 큰 장점이 될 것입니다. 다만 겨울 준비는 철저히 하셔야 합니다. 11월부터 3월까지 기온이 매우 낮아지기 때문인데, 하지만 따뜻한 옷을 입으면 그것 또한 이 도시의 매력 중 하나가 될 수 있죠.

이 지역의 문화를 체험할 수 있는 현지 풍습과 맛있는 음식을 꼭 경험해 보세요. 프랑스어가 주요 언어이므로 언어가 도전 과제가 될 수 있다는 점도 알아두시면 좋습니다. 전반적으로 퀘벡 시티는 친절한 현지인들과 특별한 분위기를 가진 멋진 장소로, 방문하거나 머무를 가치가 충분합니다!

reviews: Stayed here for about a month. Queretaro is a great foodie place, and you'll enjoy the old colonial city and a view of the aqueduct. The weather is favorable, safety is high, middle class majority and also very walkable. But aside from that, it can get really boring like a mexican suburbia. It is like a watered-down version of mexican culture.

Queretaro is a fantastic cheap and liveable city. Need some spanish here but the wifi is fast and I'm catching up on my budget from traveling around very quickly.
Staying with friends in more of a neighborhood but the downtown is charming, super clean and walkable. Also, a great place to stock up necessities, I can get all of my "brands" here at a regular price. Enjoying indulging in some home luxuries in this city. No party life here really, super safe, heavy large suburb vibes.

Queretaro is a great under the radar city. For those that want a quieter lifestyle with superb weather year round and a US friendly time zone, this place is hard to beat for the price. One of the largest middle classes in Latin America allows it to have a very high quality of life. Some of the biggest pros are, low crime (lowest I've experienced in Latin America and safer than my hometown in the US), cleanest city in Latin America that I have ever been to, incredibly well preserved colonial downtown yet the city as a whole feels first world and modern, more than enough coworking spaces, wine country just a half hour away with some high quality CHEAP wine, outdoor activities galore with the Sierra Gorda near by, and Mexico City is a short 2.5 hour drive for weekend getaways when you're missing the chaos of a large city. Some cons are that unless you live in the central area of town a car would likely be needed (Ubers are very cheap though), night life is lacking, and this particular region of Mexico is known for having very unremarkable food. The locals are very warm and inviting. I've met quite a lot of expats but few digital nomads, most friends made have been locals. The airport is newly remodeled and has daily direct flights to multiple US cities, and very cheap flights to beach destinations including Cancun, Puerto Vallarta, Merida, Huatulco, and Ixtapa.

Queretaro is great. Much dryer than I expected. Very safe (I disagree with the score). Need some Spanish here. Internet at my apartment is blazing fast 200mps. Beautiful, colonial downtown. Extremely walkable. Anything you need here. Not really a great party life...
queretaro.description:
Queretaro is a city in Mexico that mixes old colonial buildings with modern life. You can walk through its clean streets, see the colonial architecture, and look at the famous aqueduct. The city is easy to walk around, making it simple to find local shops and good food. However, don’t expect a lively nightlife like in bigger cities; it is quieter with nice cafes.

Many people feel safe here and enjoy walking around. The cost of living is low, so you can enjoy some comforts without spending too much. The weather is also good most of the year.

The local food might not be very impressive, but the friendly locals and growing foreign community help you feel welcome. It’s helpful to know some Spanish.

Queretaro is a good choice for those who want a calm lifestyle with outdoor activities nearby and easy trips to busy Mexico City on weekends. Just keep in mind that if you go outside the central area, a car might be useful.
queretaro.description_kor:
케레타로는 멕시코에 위치한 도시로, 오래된 식민지 건물과 현대적인 생활이 조화를 이루고 있습니다. 깨끗한 거리에서 산책하며 식민지 시대의 아름다운 건축물을 감상하고, 유명한 수로교를 바라볼 수 있습니다. 이 도시는 걸어 다니기 쉬워 지역 상점이나 맛있는 음식을 쉽게 찾을 수 있습니다. 하지만 대도시에서 느낄 수 있는 활기찬 밤문화는 기대하지 않는 게 좋습니다; 대신 조용하고 아늑한 카페들이 많습니다.

많은 사람들이 이곳에서 안전하다고 느끼며 자유롭게 돌아다니는 것을 즐깁니다. 생활비도 저렴해 큰 돈을 들이지 않고도 여러 가지 편안함을 누릴 수 있습니다. 날씨 또한 대체로 좋습니다.

지역 음식은 기대한 만큼 인상적이지 않을 수 있지만, 친근한 지역 주민들과 성장하고 있는 외국인 커뮤니티 덕분에 따뜻한 환대를 받을 수 있습니다. 스페인어를 조금 아는 것이 도움이 될 것입니다.

케레타로는 야외 활동이 풍부하고 주말에 바쁜 멕시코 시티로 쉽게 접근할 수 있어 조용한 라이프스타일을 원하는 사람들에게 좋은 선택입니다. 단, 중심 지역을 벗어나면 자동차가 필요할 수 있다는 점을 기억하세요.

reviews: Very quiet city, beautiful architecture and near the ocean and beaches. People are really nice, and there are a lot of restaurants & activities to choose from. It's easier if you speak french or arabic. Don't recommend if you don't want to learn these languages.

there is a lot of harassment of foreigners by pan handlers and scammers. You can't sit in a cafe without numerous people persistently trying to sell you something or outright begging. They come in waves, the time it takes to drink a single espresso you'll have to fend off a minimum of 3 different people trying to sell the same thing.
rabat.description:
Rabat is located between the ocean and its interesting buildings, offering a calm place to visit in Morocco. This city is seen as quiet and friendly, making it a nice spot to explore. There are many restaurants and things to do, so you will have plenty of options! Just be ready to use some French or Arabic, as it will help your experience.

However, the city does have its challenges. Many visitors notice that there are often panhandlers and street vendors. You may have to politely refuse sales offers during a quick coffee break, which can be a bit much. This is part of the local scene, but staying aware can help you enjoy your visit more.

If you want to enjoy the ocean breeze and interesting buildings while taking in the culture, consider visiting Rabat. Just bring some patience, learn a few French phrases, and explore some quieter areas to really experience this unique city!
rabat.description_kor:
라바트는 바다와 매력적인 건물들 사이에 자리 잡고 있어, 모로코에서 차분한 분위기를 제공하는 방문지입니다. 이 도시는 조용하고 친근한 느낌을 주며, 탐험하기에 좋은 장소입니다. 다양한 레스토랑과 즐길 거리도 많아 선택의 폭이 넓습니다! 다만, 프랑스어나 아랍어를 조금 배워 두면 더 좋은 경험을 할 수 있을 것입니다.

하지만 이 도시에는 몇 가지 도전 과제도 있습니다. 많은 방문객들이 거리에서 구걸하는 사람들과 노점상을 마주치곤 합니다. 빠른 커피를 마시는 동안 판매 제안을 정중하게 거절해야 할 수도 있어, 가끔은 다소 부담스럽게 느껴질 수 있습니다. 이런 모습은 지역의 일부분이지만, 주의를 기울이면 방문을 더 즐겁게 만들 수 있습니다.

바다의 바람과 흥미로운 건물들을 즐기며 문화를 체험하고 싶다면 라바트를 꼭 방문해 보세요. 인내심을 가지고 몇 가지 프랑스어 문장을 익히고, 한적한 지역을 탐험하면 이 독특한 도시를 진정으로 느낄 수 있을 것입니다!

reviews:
I've spent the past four months living in Quito, and to be honest, I've decided that I won't be returning to this country again. My experience here has been incredibly frustrating, especially when dealing with the average Ecuadorian citizens. For instance, when you go to a store and ask for a specific item, you often end up with something entirely different. Additionally, using Uber has its challenges, as many drivers keep their phones in their laps, constantly glancing down at the GPS instead of using a phone holder for safety.

While I've always had a love for dogs and grew up with them, my time here in Quito has led me to develop a genuine fear and dislike for them. It's not just the stray dogs causing issues on the streets; it's also the ones owned by people in lower-income areas. Many of these dogs are not properly controlled and have a tendency to randomly attack passersby. I had a particularly distressing encounter with a group of aggressive dogs during my third month here.

Moreover, if you happen to wear shoe sizes above 10 and a half, you'll face difficulties finding suitable footwear, as these sizes are rarely available anywhere in the city.

As for the dating scene, I found it to be quite lackluster, especially as a male. Quito doesn't offer a wide range of activities or a thriving expat culture. Most locals you encounter seem to be interested in forming friendships only to gain something from you.

On a more positive note, I did find some redeeming qualities in Quito, such as the ability to take quick trips to places like Banos and the overall cost of living. However, based on my experiences, I wouldn't recommend living in Quito for an extended period, as it doesn't offer much in terms of a fulfilling experience. You're not missing out on much by choosing to explore other places instead.

I have been living in Quito for almost 3 years, and at this moment in time, I can not recommend it as a travel or remote work destination. A number of high profile terrorist attacks have rocked the country, and the prevalence of random violence and kidnappings in urban areas is increasing. Drug trafficking has decreased safety throughout the country, and no one is out at night past 8 pm. The streets are literally empty once it gets dark. I wish it weren't so, but I'm not considering leaving because of how bad the security situation has gotten since I moved here.

I've made Quito my base and it has its pros and cons. It's not a lively city but there's still decent events if you know where to go to. I recommend staying in La Carolina, more specifically around avenida Portugal. El Cafecito in La Mariscal is my favourite place to work from (they have great breakfasts).
