While parts of Tallahassee may have a "redneck" look, the combination of towns and nature gives it personality. Getting around can be difficult too, so having your own car might be a good idea.

For those wanting to explore, check out the local parks, but remember to be aware of your surroundings. Tallahassee shows Florida’s natural beauty, but with a bit of caution.
tallahassee.description_kor:
탈라해시(Tallahassee)는 플로리다의 수도로, 자연과 대학 생활이 조화롭게 어우러진 매력적인 도시입니다. 방문객들은 근처의 공원과 자연 지역에서 카약이나 카누를 즐기는 등 다양한 야외 활동을 할 수 있습니다. 특히 탈라해시 자연 박물관은 인기가 많으며, 사이프러스 늪 위를 지퍼라인으로 타는 경험은 정말 특별합니다! 하지만 일부 지역, 특히 밤에나 주유소에서 이동할 때는 안전에 유의하는 것이 중요합니다.

이 도시는 플로리다 주립대학교(Florida State University)의 본거지로 젊음과 활력이 넘치는 분위기를 자아내지만, 일부 방문객들은 특정 지역이 다소 불안하게 느껴질 수 있다고 이야기합니다. 탈라해시의 일부분은 전형적인 '레드넥' 이미지로 보일 수도 있지만, 그 속에서 마을과 자연의 독특한 매력을 발견할 수 있습니다. 대중교통이 다소 불편할 수 있으니, 개인 차량을 이용하는 것이 편리할 수 있습니다.

탐험을 원하신다면 지역 공원을 꼭 방문해보세요. 하지만 주변 상황을 항상 인식하는 것을 잊지 말고요. 탈라해시는 플로리다의 자연 아름다움을 경험할 수 있는 좋은 기회를 제공하지만, 조금만 주의를 기울이면 더 안전하고 즐겁게 보낼 수 있습니다.

reviews: Tampa is my “home base” I return to, and I love it! Only drawback - like most other American cities the cost of living is high. Clearwater Beach was rated #1 beach in the US multiple years in a row by TripAdvisor, and for good reason. The sunsets are spectacular, water warm as bath water the majority of the year, and sand so soft and fine it’s like corn starch. Great sports town if you like sports, with pro teams in the NHL. MLB, and NFL that consistently perform well. Skyline is beautiful and there are many great restaurants. Temperatures are comfortable year-round, and Tampa Bay is the “sweet spot” in Florida for avoiding hurricanes because of the jet stream and avoiding heat discomfort in the summer because of the wonderful cross-breezes that blow the humidity away. I highly recommend the Tampa Bay Area if you can afford it!

I have grown up in Tampa Bay and can give some quick insight. 

If you want to genuinely experience the overall area or its history you'll want to visit both Ybor City and St Petersburg (First two areas that were initially settled). Clearwater is a tourist trap but has a beautiful manufactured beach (the sand as imported to make this beach what it is today). 

Saint Petersburg, FL: 
St Petersburg offers a few co-working spaces and at one time boasted the largest number of Kava Bars in a given city in the US (which are often used as cowork space by locals). The Brewery scene in St Petersburg is unmatched, with over 50 different breweries located in Pinellas County alone. 

Nightlife:
EDM/Dance Music is primarily seen in Tampa/Ybor City especially for harder genres like Dubstep/Riddim and Drum & Bass, as well as Tech House. However, St Petersburg has a reputation for being the more artistic side of the Tampa Bay area and thus has a strong community for Techno and House music. 

Daytime Fun:
- Kayaking through the mangroves in Lido Key (Day trip)
- 'Hiking' in Weedon Island Preserve
- Daytime in Ybor City (great restaurants, bars, and a bit of history)
- Busch Gardens Theme Park (Excellent rollercoasters)
- Art walk in St Pete
- Dali Museum (St Pete)
- Fort Desoto

Cons:
-5 years ago Tampa Bay was extremely affordable by all accounts, but is currently pacing to become much more expensive with a 25% increase in housing costs in the last year alone and one of the highest overall inflation rates in the country.
-Traveling around Tampa Bay can become expensive due to the physical size of the city and how scattered things can be. Public transit is not worth the money saved, but if you're remaining in one area, Uber is very reasonably priced. 
-There are a lot of people from other cities in the US moving into Tampa Bay, so there are many people that are not a reflection of the locals here.

Lively city with excellent internet and other infrastructure. Beaches are everywhere - both gulf beaches and bay beaches. Head for the gulf side if you want spectacular sunsets and surf, and the bay beaches if you want calm waters. Clearwater Beach was rated #1 on TripAdvisor 2 years in a row, and for good reason. The water is beautifully clear and the sand as soft as baby powder. Public transportation options could be better. Awesome restaurants. This is the "sweet spot" in Florida in the summer - because of the cross-breezes between the gulf and bay the humidity doesn't stagnate in the air and it feels much cooler than places like Orlando and Miami. It also hasn't had a direct hit from a hurricane in decades. I loved it so much the first time I came here I bought a condo here, and it's now my "home base."

Tampa and St. Pete neighbors, with St. Pete being the much better choice. Summers are hot and humid in Florida, with October through May being the sweet spot. St. Pete, 25 minutes from Tampa, is the hidden gem. Friendly, food, night light, vibrant arts and Entrepreneurial communities, LGBT+ friendly, laid back vibe yet everything you could want for. World-class beaches, fantastic dining options, plenty of party options, and endless parks and sidewalks/lanes for biking, jogging, strolling. Out of the 91 countries visited, it's my favorite city to stay in! Enjoy!

Tampa/The Tampa Bay area is okay. Clearwater beach feels a like an tourist trap but the beach is high quality (they ship in white sand from Bahamas, lol). Downtown Tampa is gentrifying from a business district to a tourist focused. The international plaza shopping mall is cool.. Tampa’s Cuban district is fun! Nearby St. Pete is like a mini-Tampa, but much calmer imho. Hopefully Tom Brady brings the city luck.

Gorgeous city, but very hot. But if you've been in Florida before, you'll know this is the norm. I explored towns in the bay area as well, which are quaint but still have much to offer. Clearwater beach has a lot going for it as well.
tampa.description:
Tampa has a mix of sunny weather, sports, and nice beaches that attract people and make them want to return. Enjoy the beauty of Clearwater Beach, which is regarded as one of the best in the U.S. – its soft sand feels very fine, and the sunsets are impressive. For sports fans, Tampa’s teams in hockey, baseball, and football provide excitement all year.

The city’s skyline is interesting, with many restaurants to try. Keep in mind that the cost of living has been increasing, so plan your budget carefully. Public transportation can be difficult to navigate, and it is often easier to use Uber for getting around. A visit to Ybor City gives you a glimpse of history and nightlife, while St. Petersburg offers a more relaxed atmosphere with good art and music.

If you want some daytime activities, kayaking in Lido Key or visiting Busch Gardens can be fun. Just remember it gets hot and humid in summer, so get ready for that! Overall, Tampa has a lively vibe, friendly people, and plenty of outdoor activities, making it a good spot to live or visit.
tampa.description_kor:
탬파는 맑은 날씨와 스포츠, 매력적인 해변이 어우러져 사람들을 매료시키고 다시 찾고 싶게 만드는 도시입니다. 미국에서 손꼽히는 해변 중 하나인 클리어워터 비치의 아름다움을 만끽해보세요. 부드럽고 고운 모래와 함께 인상적인 석양을 즐길 수 있습니다. 스포츠 팬들에게는 탬파의 아이스하키, 야구, 축구 팀들이 연중 내내 흥미진진한 경기를 제공하니 놓치지 마세요.

도시의 스카이라인 또한 흥미롭고, 다양한 식당에서 다양한 미식을 경험할 수 있습니다. 생활비가 점차 상승하고 있으니 예산 계획에 신경 써야 합니다. 대중교통은 가끔 이용하기 불편할 수 있으므로 이동할 때는 우버를 이용하는 것이 훨씬 편리합니다. 이보르 시티를 방문하면 역사와 밤 문화에 대해 알아볼 수 있고, 세인트피터즈버그에서는 예술과 음악이 어우러진 보다 여유로운 분위기를 느낄 수 있습니다.

하루 동안 즐길 거리를 찾고 계신다면 리도 키에서 카약을 하거나 부시 가든을 방문하는 것도 좋은 선택입니다. 여름철은 덥고 습하니 이에 대한 준비도 해두세요! 전반적으로 탬파는 활기찬 분위기와 친절한 사람들, 다양한 야외 활동이 가득해 살거나 방문하기에 정말 좋은 곳입니다.

reviews: Summers in Tallinn are very pleasant (if not the best, tbh). There is no need for a car or a bus to move from one point to another in the city center. I've been working in Maakri area, which is local City. Really loved my time here, especially variety of quality food options available. My favourite upscale place to eat was FARM restaurant, which is a gem of a resto located in the beginning of Tallinn's Old Town. The restaurant is also the only provence style restaurant in the country, according to my understanding.

I lived in Tallinn for four months. It's a great city overall. Life quality is excellent with transportations and everything else working excellently.
I loved the fact that you can travel to other countries easily and inexpensively (Russia, Finland, Sweden, Latvia, etc.). At the same time, I think the city gets monotonous fast compared to other places where I lived in a similar size. Estonian people don't appear to be very active. It's understandable because most of them are hard-working and outside of the tech-scene lots of people and students work two jobs.
It is not so international, and flight connections are not so many. It's also harder to make friends compared to other cities. Additionally, it's getting more and more expensive.
Overall, I wouldn't live there again. There are many better cities around, but it was fascinating to live there for a while.

I visited Tallinn Old Town (Vanalinn) in November and absolutely loved it. The Christmas Market in the old town square had just opened but it was not super crowded. I worked from my AirBnB for 2 weeks and Internet was always on point. The entire city was very walkable, there were cafes and pubs and restaurants just a few doors down (I was near St Olaf's Church), to no more than 10 minutes away by foot. Uber and others were no more than 2 or 3 minute wait. Definitely go check out the memorial to Estonia's victims of communism or the former KGB prison cells. Very sobering.

Tallinn is very livable in the summer. The city center is human-sized; you do not need a car or buses to move from one point to the other in the city. I've been co-working in the Telliskivi "hipster" part of the city, at LIFT99; I've loved the co-working and area! I've been sleeping around Pirita Beach for 3 weeks, which is a calm area (beach + forest), 15 minutes of taxi from the city.
tallinn.description:
Tallinn, the capital of Estonia, is a mix of history, culture, and nice summer days. You can walk through the cobblestone streets of the Old Town and visit small cafes. One popular place to eat is FARM, which serves Estonian food. The city is easy to navigate without a car; everything is within walking distance, and you can quickly find an Uber.

The summer weather is good for visiting Pirita Beach or the busy Telliskivi area, which has many creative spaces. However, some visitors feel that while it is enjoyable at first, it might become quiet or dull over time. Making friends can also be difficult, and the cost of living is going up.

If you plan to visit, don’t forget to see important memorials to Estonia’s history, like the KGB prison cells. Overall, Tallinn is an interesting city that gives you a view of Nordic life!
tallinn.description_kor:
탈린은 에스토니아의 수도로서, 역사와 문화, 그리고 아름다운 여름 날씨가 어우러진 매력적인 도시입니다. 구시가지의 자갈길을 걸으며 아기자기한 카페들을 둘러볼 수 있습니다. 이곳에서 꼭 가봐야 할 인기 있는 식당 중 하나는 에스토니아 전통 음식을 맛볼 수 있는 FARM입니다. 탈린은 자동차 없이도 쉽게 돌아다닐 수 있는 곳으로, 대부분의 명소가 도보 거리 내에 있으며, 필요할 때는 우버를 간편하게 호출할 수 있습니다.

여름엔 피리타 해변이나 창의적인 공간이 많은 텔리스크비 지역을 방문하는 것이 좋습니다. 다만 어떤 방문객들은 처음에는 즐겁지만, 시간이 지나면서 조용해지거나 지루해질 수도 있다고 느낄 수 있습니다. 또한, 친구를 사귀는 것이 어려울 수 있고, 생활비가 계속 오르고 있다는 점도 고려해야 합니다.

탈린에 방문할 계획이라면, KGB 감옥 셀과 같은 에스토니아의 역사적 기념물들을 꼭 둘러보세요. 전반적으로 탈린은 북유럽의 삶을 엿볼 수 있는 흥미로운 도시입니다!

reviews: We stayed in Tampere for a month this summer and it was wonderful. My husband's father and family live in the area, so we've visited multiple times but this was the first time we went on an extended trip and worked remotely. Choose a place to stay where you're in walking distance of a public swimming beach so you can take a dip in the evening sunlight.
tampere.description:
Tampere is a charming city that is hard to resist. It is located between two lakes and has a good mix of nature, culture, and a friendly feel. Visitors appreciate the nice waterfronts and enjoy walking to local swimming beaches for a swim as the sun sets.

One benefit of living here is the easy pace of life. The cost of living is reasonable compared to other cities in Finland, but eating out can be a bit expensive. Public transportation is okay, but it may not be as good as in larger cities.

Local culture includes many festivals and art events throughout the year. There may be some language barrier; while many people speak English, learning a few Finnish phrases can be helpful. To experience the area like a local, visit neighborhoods like Tulli or Pispala, known for their friendly atmosphere and colorful houses. Overall, Tampere is a nice place to enjoy city life and nature!
tampere.description_kor:
탐페레는 매력적인 도시로, 누구나 한 번쯤 가보고 싶어 하는 곳입니다. 이 도시는 두 개의 호수 사이에 위치하여, 자연과 문화, 그리고 따뜻한 분위기가 조화롭게 어우러져 있습니다. 방문객들은 아름다운 해안선을 따라 산책을 즐기며, 해질 무렵에는 지역 수영 해변으로 나들이를 가기도 합니다.

이곳에서의 생활의 큰 장점 중 하나는 느긋한 생활 속도입니다. 다른 핀란드 도시들에 비해 생활비는 비교적 합리적이지만, 외식 비용은 조금 비쌀 수 있습니다. 대중교통은 괜찮은 편이지만, 대도시에 비해 다소 부족할 수 있습니다.

탐페레의 문화는 연중 내내 다양한 축제와 예술 행사로 활기찹니다. 언어 장벽이 있을 수 있지만, 많은 사람들이 영어를 할 줄 알아서 기본적인 핀란드어 문구 몇 개만 배우면 큰 도움이 됩니다. 현지인처럼 이 도시를 만끽하고 싶다면, 친근한 분위기와 다채로운 집들이 특징인 툴리(Tulli)나 피스팔라(Pispala) 같은 동네를 방문해 보세요. 전반적으로 탐페레는 도시 생활과 자연을 동시에 즐기기에 최적의 장소입니다!

reviews: Internet connection is stable. Mobile broadband speed in range of 3-7 Mbps from home (10 km from center of Tashkent), fiber-optics connection is also stable - up to 50 Mbps at the daytime (from 12 pm till 12 am) and up to 200 Mbps at night (from 12 am till 12 pm)

Delicious food, which is also cheap. Lots of cafes and restaurants. Activities are various: bazar visit, trip to nearby mountains, “chayxana” - traditional Uzbek tea house/restaurant, clubbing, horse riding. Beautiful subway which resembles the one in Moscow. Groceries are of high quality. Most people speak Russian, and are nice to foreigners. Almost no crime. It’s difficult to drive around, because of local driving culture. Thus, it’s better to move around on taxi which is cheap. City is somewhat multinational with majority being Uzbek. Society is religious, yet the state is secular. “Foreigner-looking” people aren’t condemned for their outfit. All four seasons are present, yet the amount of sunny days in a year is very high.
tashkent.description:
Tashkent is a city in Uzbekistan that combines tradition and modern life. It is known for its tasty and affordable food, with many cafes and restaurants serving dishes that will please your appetite. Exploring busy markets is important, and you should visit a “chayxana” for some traditional tea. 

Getting around can be a bit challenging because of local driving habits, but taxis are cheap and a good way to move around the city. Tashkent has a nice subway system that makes traveling convenient, similar to the ones in Moscow. 

The city is safe with a low crime rate. Most locals speak Russian, and they are friendly to visitors. Tashkent has four seasons but enjoys many sunny days, making it pleasant to visit all year. Just be aware of the local culture—people usually dress modestly due to the city's religious influences. Whether you are riding horses in the nearby mountains or enjoying a night out at a club, Tashkent offers a memorable experience!
tashkent.description_kor:
타슈켄트는 전통과 현대가 조화롭게 어우러진 우즈베키스탄의 도시입니다. 맛있고 저렴한 음식으로 유명하며, 다양한 카페와 레스토랑에서 입맛을 사로잡는 요리를 즐길 수 있습니다. 바쁘게 돌아가는 시장을 탐험하는 것은 필수이며, 전통차를 맛보고 싶다면 "차이하나"를 꼭 방문해 보세요.

현지의 운전 습관 때문에 이동이 조금 불편할 수 있지만, 택시는 저렴하고 도시를 돌아다니는 데 아주 편리한 수단입니다. 타슈켄트에는 모스크바와 비슷하게 잘 갖춰진 지하철 시스템이 있어 여행이 훨씬 수월합니다.

이 도시는 안전하고 범죄율이 낮아 비교적 걱정 없이 다닐 수 있습니다. 대부분의 현지인들이 러시아어를 할 수 있어 의사소통도 어렵지 않습니다. 타슈켄트는 사계절이 있지만 맑은 날이 많아 언제 방문해도 쾌적한 경험을 할 수 있습니다. 다만, 현지 문화를 존중해 주세요. 주민들은 종교적 영향으로 인해 대체로 단정한 복장을 선호합니다. 근처 산에서 말을 타거나 클럽에서 신나는 밤을 보내든, 타슈켄트는 잊지 못할 특별한 추억을 선사할 것입니다!

reviews:
You'll be surprised how people are welcoming. Food is the best thing. Everything is cheap.
But consider govt is religous, woman have to wear hijab. I think safety is not that bad, just don't go outside very late, there isn't night life there at all and watch out when you use your mobile in street.
Before going there, get a vpn subscription from ExpressVpn (it works great), without vpn internet is nearly useless.
It's a great place for a short visit, but not recommended for a long time stay.
No internatianal banking system works there!
North areas are more expensive and better.

Tehran is a great city and much more developed that I thought. However, those intrepid nomads willing to come should be aware that internet and currency situation isn't the best because of international sanctions. 

Iranian people are really nice, educated, welcoming and hard-working, you'll make brothers and sisters here, not only friends. Food scene is great and subway system is surprisingly good. Airbnb doesn't work here but I recommend talking to people through Couchsurfing, some of them will be able to recommend you places or even host you for very reasonable fees. Iran is an amazing country and I do recommend explore the rest of the country -- it's safe, cheap and fun!

Disgusting treatment towards women, it's filthy and hygiene is basic. Don't visit a place like this. There is nothing to do, Internet is appalling. Its just a really bad place to visit never mind live.
tehran.description:
Tehran is a city with a rich culture and friendly people. Many visitors enjoy the food, which is both tasty and affordable. The locals are welcoming and often treat strangers like friends or family.

However, it is important to know that Tehran has strict rules, especially about women's clothing, so you will need to wear a hijab. The city does not have much nightlife, and it is safer to stay indoors at night. While public safety is generally good, be careful with your mobile phone in public and consider using a VPN for internet access.

For a short visit, Tehran gives a good look at Iranian life, but there can be issues with language, banking, and hygiene. The northern neighborhoods are nicer and worth visiting if you have the budget. Overall, it is a city full of experiences, but it may not be the best place for a long stay.
tehran.description_kor:
테헤란은 풍부한 문화와 친절한 사람들로 가득한 도시입니다. 많은 방문객들이 저렴하면서도 맛있는 음식을 즐기곤 합니다. 지역 주민들은 매우 환영하는 태도로 낯선 사람들을 친구나 가족처럼 대합니다. 

하지만 테헤란에서는 여성의 복장에 대한 엄격한 규정이 있으므로, 히잡을 반드시 착용해야 한다는 점을 유의해야 합니다. 이 도시는 밤문화가 활발하지 않아서, 밤에는 실내에서 보내는 것이 더 안전합니다. 전반적으로 공공 안전은 양호하지만, 공공장소에서는 휴대전화 사용에 주의하고 인터넷 접속을 위해 VPN 사용을 고려하는 것이 좋습니다.

짧게 방문하는 동안 테헤란은 이란의 생활을 잘 보여주지만, 언어, 금융, 위생 문제 등도 있을 수 있습니다. 북부 지역은 상대적으로 더 안전하고 괜찮은 편이므로, 예산이 허락한다면 꼭 방문해볼 만합니다. 전반적으로 경험이 풍부한 도시이지만, 장기 체류를 위한 최적의 장소는 아닐 수 있습니다.

reviews: One of my favourite places to visit. Best vegetarian food in the world.

One of my favorite places. It is a bit more expensive, but if you are ok with spending more for living, you will get sun, beaches, safety (I never felt threatened), culture. Jerusalem is just an hour bus ride away for touristing (bus prices are super cheap). You have to be ok with soldiers with guns walking around. And you have to get used to getting your bags searched every time you go into a mall or movie theater. I got used to it pretty quickly. I loved Tel Aviv.

As a local I would say it's great for you to visit, friendly people and great weather, However, if you're on budget, try to find in advanced the Bnb/CS/Hostel places to stay at. Eating outside might also be pricey, so be ready to cook.
I have been to Tel Aviv and everywhere else in Israel, I loved it, 11/10 experience, the food, culture, the people, the technology, amazing, this country is amazing and awesome, Israel for life!!!!
tel-aviv.description:
Ah, Tel Aviv! This city on Israel's coast has sun, beaches, and a culture that is lively. Visitors talk about the great vegetarian food—you'll find some of the best dishes that even meat lovers can enjoy!

Living here isn’t the cheapest, but those who can spend a bit enjoy the sunny days and friendly atmosphere. Safety is good; many feel comfortable walking around, but you’ll see soldiers with guns and have to get used to bag checks in malls and theaters. It’s part of local life that soon feels normal.

Public transport is fairly easy to use, and if you want to explore, Jerusalem is just a cheap bus ride away. For budget travelers, looking for affordable places to stay like hostels or BnBs can save you money, and cooking at home is a good way to enjoy your meals without spending too much. The friends you’ll make and the experiences you’ll have? Invaluable! Whether you’re enjoying the beach or exploring local culture, you’re in for a great time in Tel Aviv!
tel-aviv.description_kor:
아, 텔아비브! 이스라엘 해안에 위치한 이 도시는 햇살, 아름다운 해변, 그리고 활기찬 문화로 가득 차 있습니다. 방문객들은 채식을 포함한 다양한 훌륭한 요리를 경험할 수 있으며, 육식 애호가들도 맛있는 요리를 즐길 수 있는 곳이에요!

여기 살기는 다소 비쌀 수 있지만, 여유가 있는 사람이라면 맑고 화창한 날씨와 친근한 분위기를 충분히 즐길 수 있습니다. 안전 상태도 양호해 많은 사람들이 거리를 편안히 걷고 있지만, 군인들이 총을 든 모습을 보게 되며 쇼핑몰이나 극장에서 가방 검사를 받는 것이 익숙해져야 합니다. 이런 것들은 일상적인 풍경이 되어 자연스럽게 느껴질 거예요.

대중교통은 비교적 편리하게 이용할 수 있고, 탐험을 원한다면 저렴한 버스를 타고 예루살렘으로도 쉽게 갈 수 있습니다. 예산 여행자에게는 호스텔이나 BnB 같은 저렴한 숙소를 찾는 것도 좋은 방법이며, 자취하며 요리하면 비용을 절약하면서 맛있는 식사를 즐길 수 있습니다. 무슨 친구들과 어떤 경험을 나눌지? 그건 정말 소중한 부분이지요! 해변에서 휴식을 취하든, 지역 문화를 탐방하든 텔아비브에서 멋진 시간을 보내실 수 있습니다!

reviews: No Uber, difficult getting things from Amazon. This is too bad because without these two huge disadvantages, Tenerife would be pretty great.

Guys , If you want the perfect weather and a lively nomad scene go more in the south around Los cristianos. Of course if you go to Puerto you'll be bored . Tenerife is amazing. Amazing hikes to do all around the island. A nice digital nomad community (Join the whatsapp groups) and a perfect weather the whole.

Hi guys!
Tenerife is amazing. Good weather all year round, fast internet, friendly people (especially if you speak a few words Spanish), low criminality. I was in the South in Adeje where I found an amazing coliving place (check google: Ojala Casa Tenerife). It's by far the best place to be in Europe.

Boring :-( Here for 2.5 months in summer. Puerto was supposed to be a nomad city, but I can't seem to meet them. Just 1-2 meetups that only 5+ people come to. A lot of lower middle class tourists. Santa Cruz has more to offer. La Laguna is nice for a day trip, but kinda dead too. Yes, there's beautiful nature and hikes, but people/community/city-wise not impressed at all.

I live here with my girlfriend close to Santa Cruz now for around 1 year. We lived before in Alicante and Gran Canaria. Lots to discover if you like Hiking or Surfing. Nomad scene is here with a couple of Meetups and Activities if you look for it. It's relative cheap compare to West Europe. Food is difficult to find Restaurants what you can eat well. 

Pros:
Weather always perfect even in winter

It's an Island, so there are many beaches

2 Airports with many flights all over Europe 

Fresh Fruits and Vegetable as many things grow here.

Cons:
If you are a foodie its difficult to find any good food what is not Spanish or Italian

Even the Bus System is really good they need to improve with walkways or bike roads, but this is a problem in all over Spain.

Order online is a gamble sometimes is fast but as the Canary Islands are outside the European customs union you have to declare goods what the value us over 15o EUR
Too touristic - Restaurants, experiences, shops.. all designed for tourists which makes the place not as enjoyable in my experience.

Spent two weeks all over the island in July 2022. Wasn't super interested in Santa Cruz after one night there. Spent a week at a private finca near Guia de Isora and really enjoyed what I saw of that area. Seemed like there was lots to do in nearby Playa San Juan. Stayed another week in Puerto de la Cruz which didn't have a whole lot going on despite seeming to be a popular destination for tourists. Still a beautiful place to explore on foot for a few days.

Weather seems to be pretty much flawless year round. My hotel room in Puerto de la Cruz (Coral Teide Mar) was pretty nice and super affordable ($34/night). Food around town was just ok.

The biggest highlight of the trip was taking an interpretive hike with a guide around the base of Teide. Got to see some stunning views above the cloud line and learned a lot about the geology and natural history of the islands. I would highly recommend exploring the volcanoes with someone who can explain why it's all so cool.

If I could do it again, I think I'd spend all my time in the south/west areas of the island.

Pro tip: there are cannabis clubs scattered all around the island, but most don't do any advertising because they don't want to attract tourists (technically you're only allowed to get in if you're a resident). There is one in Puerto de la Cruz called The Bud Company that you can find on Instagram and Weedmaps. You can email or DM and ask to join the club, and as long you're chill they'll instruct you on how to proceed. Good luck finding the place! 😂☠️ Look for `Edificio Belitope` on Google Maps and pay close attention to the photo of the door on Weedmaps. You're welcome.

I lived in Puerto De La Cruz between October and December.

Pros;
- Quiet, safe neighbourhood
- Well stocked supermarkets
- High speed broadband in my Airbnb
- Very hot and sunny days in October / November
- Cheap Taxis
- Lots of hikes 
- Legal, cheap cannabis
- Access to southern Tenerife for partying

Cons;
- English is not that great, but can get by.
- High humidity and rainfall
- Not great social scene
- A lot of sub-par restaurants (I recommend 'Vulk' and anything south american)
- Boring nightlife
- Super expensive car rental (1k month)
Perfect place to live with a spouse, smoke weed and work out your airbnb, whilst hiking around and swimming on the weekend,

I was staying in the western part of the island for about 3 months in winter months of 2021. My impression is that it is a clean and sunny place, that could be much better than it is. Unfortunately it was too cold to swim in the ocean. Some people did, but it's definitely not comfortable, water is just cold and the overall temperature is in the 20 degrees Celsius range, so it was not hot by any measure. The place is filled with British retirees and Eastern European tourists. There are just a few stores, one 24/7 off license and one Lidl store. The availability of goods is limited. As for dining, it's ok, but nothing to write home about. Housing is meh. Despite being small and sparsely populated it managed to be loud. As for the scenery, apart from palm trees and a few patches of grass maintained within the town, it is barren land. Essentially a piece of rock sticking out of the ocean. I've heard it's greener in the North.

Maybe there are interesting people to meet in more popular areas like La Playa las Americas, but where I was at it felt empty, boring, and mediocre. A very underwhelming experience - I will definitely not be wasting my time coming back here.

I lived here in Tenerife from October until December. My thoughts are below

Pros: 

- Lovely weather at this time of year, really pleasant in the low 20s 
- The island has lots to see and some of the national parks are just spectacular. There's so much beauty on the island
- It's relatively cheap, so a nice modern Airbnb in the centre of Santa Cruz for instance will set you back 1300-1500 EUR
- WiFi is very good in the Airbnbs so no problem there, was able to take video calls easily and it never cut out

Cons: 

- I struggled to find a good meal in Puerto de la Cruz whilst I was there for a month. I wasn't the only one it seems, as I had another couple approach me to ask about the food in the restaurant I was eating at and they said all the places they had tried were terrible. 
- Online dating is much harder than other places I've been to (I spent all my time in North Tenerife FYI), and I think the level of English amongst the locals might have something to do with it. I didn't have a single date in the months I was here, compared to having lots of dating experiences in many different countries. 
- Really no decent places to work from outside of your apartment. Cafes in the centre will have dodgy WiFi (if any at all) and the coffee in general isn't that great in my opinion.

I spent an amazing 2.5 months in Tenerife during COVID times from April to June of 2021. One of the best decisions of my life. The island has so much to offer; dramatic nature hikes, good food, excellent weather, fun parties/raves (yes, even during covid times), water sports, beaches, etc. The general vibe is very chill and it's easy to talk with both locals and tourists. Everyone is simply having a good time. There´s a reason this island is so popular among tourists.

At the same time, the island's popularity is also its achilles heel. Once countries opened uptheir borders again and tourists started flooding in around June, the quality of living went down dramatically. Hard to find parking, beaches overcrowding, drunk people on the streets (Las Americas), prices increasingly steeply etc. I honestly wouldn´t want to spend a full-on non-corona summer here, even though it is possible to avoid them, for instance by sticking to the north side of the island.

My recommendation would be to visit Tenerife as a digital nomad, in off-season times only. For me personally, 2.5 months was enough to see and do most of the things there, and I don't feel the need to come back per se. Most Digital Nomads I met were also staying somewhere between 1-4 months before moving off again. And that´s completely fine of course :)

I went to Tenerife thinking I was going to stay for a month, I ended up being there for 2.5 months. Absolutely amazing place, good work/life balance, great nature. Cost of living is not so high.

Important recommendation: avoid the north. It's much better to stay in the South-area, especially Las Americas. The weather is much nicer and most importantly, there is much more to do.

I've spent a few months in Tenerife in 2020. I think it's the best of the Canary Islands for remote workers. The South has better weather and more touristy vibe, the North is colder but with more long-term people. Nomads seem to be living around El Medano, Puerto de la Cruz or Las Americas.

Pros:
- Lots of nomads. Seems to be a good solution for those who have to remain in EU timezones or just starting out they nomad journey and don't want to take too much risk.
- Awesome weather.
- Nature. Surfing, kitesurfing, diving, hiking, mountain biking and all kinds of outdoor activities are great on the island.
- Decent public transport, nice roads, generally good infrastructure.

Cons:
- Zero hipster cafes that are good for work.
- Very few co-working spaces.
- No ride-hailing apps. You have to make a phone call to book a taxi like it's 2005. Best to get a car or motorbike.
- Online shopping can be a hassle due to the distance from the mainland.
- Difficult to find high quality accommodation, even if you have the money to burn.
- Lots of drunk retired British expats and businesses catering for them.

Overall, I think Tenerife is great and has great potential at becoming an "European" nomad hotspot -- if it isn't one already.

WOW, cool platform. Even for freelancers like me. I am currently staying on a beautiful finca (Finca San Juan) in the north of Tenerife. The climate is amazing. It is not too hot and sometimes partly cloudy and still it is green and very calm and quiet. The Finca is in San Juan de la Rambla (Hotel Finca San Juan) and provides super fast 600 MBit fiber with strong WIFI broadcast on the whole premise. It consists of some complexes to rent for long-term with a huge discount and a lot of included Services. It has many chillout areas to withdraw and even isolate a bit. Also it has a big pool and showers, restaurant, bar and a projector to give seminars. The island is full of other facilities to live and work, but I like this the most and I will stay here until end of February. Hit me a message to Dave Travolta in one of the social networks. I am usually up for brainstorming session or social drink.

We spent January in Santa Cruz and had a fantastic stay. The people we met were nice, the weather was fantastic, prices for things were reasonable, good selection of locally grown produce, good internet connectivity, there were lots of outdoor activities to do, and not too touristy or crowded (at least Santa Cruz in January). Other parts of the Island felt more resort-like and it wasn't so easy to get to places outside of Santa Cruz without a car.
If you live in the south of the islands, the temperature is never under 20 degrees during winter time, so eternal spring ¡¡

Tenerife is really a great place for nomads! we've stayed here for a bit over 3 months and loved everything about it! in my opinion the north is more authentic and has way more to offer to nature lovers than the south. We stayed at an amazing coliving in la Orotava (nine coliving) and I would definitively recommend this place! The nomad community is pretty active as well and several events are organized monthly which is nice!
tenerife.description:
Tenerife, one of the Canary Islands, is a place where nature meets a relaxed atmosphere. With good weather all year, it's easy to see why many people like this place. Whether you're hiking up Teide volcano or relaxing at the beaches in Los Cristianos, there's a lot to see and do. The southern part has many digital nomads, and joining local WhatsApp groups can help you meet people with similar interests. Also, there is good Wi-Fi for remote work and nice shared living spaces, like Ojala Casa Tenerife.

On the other hand, Tenerife has its issues. Public transport is okay but could be better, and ordering online can sometimes be difficult. If you enjoy trying different foods, you might find that the restaurants focus more on tourists. Additionally, language barriers can be hard—knowing some Spanish phrases can help a lot!

Even with some challenges, Tenerife's beauty and friendly atmosphere make it a special place for both adventure lovers and those who want to relax. Just make sure to explore beyond the usual tourist spots to truly enjoy this island!
tenerife.description_kor:
테네리페(Tenerife)는 카나리 제도(Canary Islands) 중에 위치한 멋진 관광지로, 자연과 한가로운 분위기가 어우러진 곳입니다. 이곳은 연중 내내 화창한 날씨를 자랑해 많은 사람들이 찾는 이유를 쉽게 이해할 수 있습니다. 테이데 화산(Teide volcano)에서 하이킹을 즐기거나 로스 크리스티아노스(Los Cristianos) 해변에서 여유로운 시간을 보낼 수 있는 다양한 활동과 볼거리가 풍부합니다. 특히 남부 지역에는 디지털 노마드들이 많이 거주하고 있어, 현지의 WhatsApp 그룹에 가입하면 비슷한 관심사를 가진 사람들과 네트워킹할 수 있습니다. 또한, 원격 근무를 위한 훌륭한 Wi-Fi 환경과 Ojala Casa Tenerife 같은 멋진 공동 작업 공간도 마련되어 있습니다.

하지만 테네리페에는 몇 가지 단점도 있습니다. 대중교통 시스템은 괜찮지만 개선이 필요하고, 온라인 주문은 때때로 불편할 수 있습니다. 다양한 음식을 시도하는 걸 좋아한다면, 일부 식당들이 관광객을 주로 겨냥하고 있다는 점을 유의해야 할 것입니다. 그리고 언어 장벽도 존재하는데, 스페인어 몇 마디를 알고 있으면 많은 도움이 됩니다.

여러 가지 도전 과제가 있긴 하지만, 테네리페의 아름다움과 친근한 분위기는 모험을 사랑하는 이들과 여유를 만끽하고 싶은 사람들에게 소중한 경험을 제공합니다. 이 섬을 진정으로 즐기고 싶다면 기존의 관광 명소를 넘어 새로운 탐험에 나서보세요!

reviews:
Thessaloniki is Greece's capital of food. No matter where you go to, you will always find fantastic food around you.

The place is great for nomads as you can find a lot of cheap places to stay with decent internet speeds. There are a lot of coffee shops to work from the city center. People are super friendly here and you can easily start a chat with anyone. Lots of young people due to the universities, so the atmosphere is great.

There are not that many unique experiences to do here though, other than some museums and touristic attractions. If you need a chill place to be though with fantastic food, this is the place.

Thessaloniki is a city spread over the hills by the side of the Aegean. A cultural crossroads since Byzantine times, it has amazing cuisine and is full of reasonably priced tavernas and restaurants. Full of neo-classical buildings, there are lots of great living options available close to the city center and beyond. The pace of life is stately or as locals call it "hallarah" and most are not in a rush. There is a nice film festival in the Fall and many other public celebrations.
thessaloniki.description:
Thessaloniki is a mix of history, culture, and great food. Imagine walking through streets with old buildings, where you find new tavernas or cafés at every turn. This city is a food lover's dream, and it’s hard to find a bad meal. The atmosphere is lively because of the many universities in the area with friendly young people.

For freelance workers and travelers, Thessaloniki has affordable places to stay and many coffee shops with good internet, making it easy to work or relax. Life here is calm, or as the locals say, "hallarah," meaning there is no rush.

Keep in mind that while there are museums and some attractions, you may not find as many unique experiences as in larger cities. Public transport may not be very wide-ranging, and sometimes, language differences can be a challenge. However, with a little patience and a willingness to talk to locals, you will enjoy your time here! Don’t miss the beautiful film festival in the fall and the lively local celebrations throughout the year—there is always something going on in Thessaloniki!
thessaloniki.description_kor:
테살로니키는 역사와 문화, 그리고 맛있는 음식이 조화롭게 어우러진 도시입니다. 오래된 건물들이 늘어선 거리를 거닐며 매 코너마다 새로운 타베르나나 카페를 발견하는 상상을 해보세요. 이곳은 음식 애호가라면 정말 꿈같은 곳으로, 나쁜 음식을 찾기란 거의 불가능합니다. 여러 대학이 자리 잡고 있어 활기찬 분위기와 친근한 젊은이들이 많이 있습니다.

프리랜서와 여행자들에게 테살로니키는 합리적인 가격의 숙소와 빠른 인터넷이 있는 많은 카페 덕분에 일하거나 휴식을 취하기에 안성맞춤입니다. 이곳의 삶은 차분하고, 현지인들이 자주 사용하는 "할라라"라는 표현처럼 서두를 필요가 없습니다.

박물관과 몇몇 명소들이 있지만 큰 도시들에 비해 독특한 경험은 다소 적을 수 있습니다. 대중교통은 그리 발달하지 않았고, 가끔 언어 장벽이 도전이 될 수 있지만, 약간의 인내심과 현지인들과 소통하려는 노력이 있다면 이곳에서 멋진 시간을 보낼 수 있을 겁니다! 가을에 열리는 아름다운 영화제와 연중 내내 열리는 활기찬 지역 축제를 놓치지 마세요. 테살로니키에서는 항상 흥미로운 일이 벌어지고 있습니다!

reviews: I live in Timisoara since 2 years. It's a good place , very cheep and quiet. during summer this year a lot of festivals and cultural events. I love the weither, cold in winter but not so munch just under zero degré like minus 5 maybe 1 week or two, and very hot in July. A lot of sun anyway all the year. The food is excellent . And people are very kind and open to help you if you ask them. The nature is beautiful just 1 hour driving and the mountain are amazing, hotel confortable and very cheap.

You can still find 1 bedroom apartments near the centre for 350 euro. The city centre is great, it is almost devoid of shops and is almost all bars and restaurants. Great for having a great night out. The food seems to be between 5 to 10 euros but is of excellent quality. So far I have not been disappointed on the food front. I have been making Tiisoara my DN home base since this summer and have been finding quite a few others are doing the same. Having an airport close by and being connected to the rest of Europe easy is a big bonus. Romania's Micro Company scheme makes it an excellent country to base yourself and from there explore. I checked out Brasov, Bucharest and Sibiu but Timisoara makes the best case.

Prices aren't that low anymore. 1br apartment in the centre would cost you around 400 euros, maybe even 500 if you go for something more luxurious.

Airbnbs are 40-50 euros per night (central ones).
Dinner would be anywhere from 5 to 10 euros and even more if you go to the fanciest restaurants.
There's a decent tech scene around (lots of software engineers in the city).
I'm living in Timisoara since 2011.

Timisoara is an interesting place. The centre square is where it all happens. We stayed a couple days to break up our journey in Romania. Lots of cafes and restaurants. It’s very safe, apart from the occasional person asking for money. English in the centre is pretty well spoken, but out of that, it’s hard to find an English speaking/understanding person. If in real trouble go talk to youth, they will be beat option. The food is quite good and beer is cold. The cost was very reasonable too. 6.5/10 is a pretty fair score I’d say.
timisoara.description:
Timisoara has a nice mix of culture and friendliness that makes visitors want to return. The weather is usually sunny, except for a few cold weeks in winter, and the city has lively summer festivals. You can enjoy a meal outside at a comfortable restaurant for just 5 to 10 euros, which is good value. If you want to have a fun night out, the city center has many bars and restaurants that are great for relaxing after exploring.

Living costs are quite reasonable. Apartments near the center are going for about 400-500 euros, but you can find comfortable Airbnbs for around 40-50 euros per night. Just a heads up: it might be a bit challenging to communicate outside the center if you're not confident in English, but the locals are friendly, and younger people usually speak English better.

However, public transportation can be limited, so having a car or getting used to walking is helpful. Overall, Timisoara has a good mix of interesting history, nice nature nearby, and a welcoming community that is open to newcomers. Enjoy your time there!
timisoara.description_kor:
티미쇼아는 문화적 매력과 친근함이 잘 어우러져 있어 방문객들이 다시 찾고 싶어하는 장소입니다. 날씨는 대체로 맑고, 특히 겨울철에 며칠 정도 추운 날이 있긴 하지만 전반적으로 온화한 편입니다. 여름에는 활기찬 축제도 열리니 놓치지 마세요. 

편안한 레스토랑에서 외부에서 식사를 즐기면 5유로에서 10유로 정도로 훌륭한 가성비를 자랑합니다. 즐거운 저녁 외출을 원하신다면 도심에는 탐방 후 쉴 수 있는 바와 레스토랑이 많이 있으니 좋은 선택이 될 거예요. 

생활비도 꽤 합리적입니다. 중심가 근처 아파트는 대략 400-500유로에 거래되지만, 편안한 에어비앤비는 1박에 40-50유로 정도로 찾을 수 있습니다. 다만, 중심가에서 벗어나면 영어로 의사소통이 어려울 수 있지만, 현지인들은 매우 친절하고 젊은 사람들은 대부분 영어를 잘합니다.

대중교통은 약간 불편할 수 있으니, 자동차를 소유하거나 걷는 게 도움이 될 것입니다. 전반적으로 티미쇼아는 흥미로운 역사, 아름다운 자연, 그리고 새로운 사람들을 환영하는 따뜻한 커뮤니티가 잘 어우러져 있습니다. 거기서 즐거운 시간 보내세요!

reviews:
I spent a month in Tirana in February 2022 and then returned in October for a one-week stay. Generally, I was pleasantly surprised and would recommend Tirana. Here are my Pros and Cons:

Pros:
- Cheap: Airbnbs are cheap (especially on a monthly basis), food is very cheap (around a third of what you would pay in Germany) and still good quality (most of the time).
- Walkable: The city center is pretty compact and everything can be reached on foot
- Green: The city center has multiple parks around the main boulevard. The big city park has an artificial lake and paths for runners and cyclists.
- Nice People: All locals that I talked to were very nice. I once went to the barber who was the nicest dude ever. We talked for around 1.5 hours about Albania, politics, economics and so on. That way, I learned a lot about the country.
- Great coworking cafes: I can recommend the Destil Creative Hub and the Coolab. Nice people, good coffee and a good internet connection. Stay away from the #TECHSPACE, though. Very bad internet, tedious to even get in, not a good experience there.
- Safe: I never felt unsafe, even when walking back to my Airbnb at night. There also were a lot of women walking around at night. Also, locals told me that pickpocketing is not a problem in Tirana since there are only few tourists.
- Night Life: There are many bars around the city center. Even during the week, there are many people out partying.

Cons:
- Boring: There is not much to do generally. There are a few museums like the National History Museum, the two Bunk'art museums (old bunkers from communist times) and the House of Leaves. All of them are focused on Albanian History. I can especially recommend Bunk'art 1. It's impressive to wander through this huge bunker. The National History Museum starts strong with a really cool exhibition of relicts and statues from Ancient times on the ground floor. On the top floors, most texts are not translated into English. Also, the exhibitions are partially very old school or trashy (the exhibition about Mother Teresa looks like it was designed by a child in Word 2003).
- No digital nomad community: I would have loved to meet more digital nomads, but sadly there is no real community there (yet).
- Cars: Traffic is insane in the city. And people drive like crazy. Take care when walking over the road (even at crosswalks). I was almost hit by a car on the crosswalk twice. Also, I was surprised that I made it from the airport to the city and back without an accident, considering the driving style of most drivers.
- Coldness: Since it's pretty hot in Albania for most of the year, most buildings don't have heating or well-isolated walls (apartments as well as restaurants, museums etc.). I was there in February and I was constantly cold. So I would recommend visiting Tirana in spring or autumn when it's neither cold nor super hot. In October, the temperature was nice.
- Public Toilets: Toilets in public places and restaurants are mostly filthy and unhygienic. Most places don't have urinals, still most men appear to urinate standing up and have terrible aim. That leads to piss being all over the toilet and on the floor. It was like this almost everywhere I went.

Generally, I enjoyed my time in Tirana and I definitely plan to visit a third time. I can recommend it to everyone, but especially to people who are on a budget. 
In spring, you can get a nice Airbnb in the city center for around 500€ - 700€ a month, WizzAir offers cheap flights to Tirana from many major European cities (100€ - 150€ there and back) and food is pretty cheap (main course + drink around 10€ at most restaurants). So I estimate you can visit Tirana for a month at around 1000€ - 1400€ in spring.
I really like Tirana, one of my favorite places in the Balkans. The people are really friendly towards Americans as well. The mountains surrounding the city are also lovely.

Tirana is modern, walkable and seems to have good nightlife while feeling safe (lot of kids, families and women walking around at night). But it is also very crowded of people and cars, there is a lot of garbage and inpleasant smells. I would defenitly prefer the coastal area for a longer stay

Tirana was a pleasant surprise for me! It wasn’t on my initial list for places I’d planned to go this year, but after researching countries in Europe that allows U.S. citizens to enter with COVID, it piqued my interest. I stayed in the Blloku area and would definitely recommend it. It’s littered with bars and cafes you can work from (Mon Cheri and Mulliri Vjeter became fast favorites because of consistency!). I was also genuinely grateful to get the chance to learn about the very recent communist history in more detail while I was there. There’s not a ton to do culturally, but in general, Tirana is a very comfortable, vibrant, and livable (albeit small) city if you’re looking to settle in somewhere for a month or two.

Big no from me. After being around all the balkans, this place felt off.
Locals are friendly IF they know you're a tourist, otherwise, they're loud and rude to each other.
The way they converse, drive, or behave is a intimidating to say the least.
Electricity outages as seen in India or Nepal (sometimes daily occurrence!) 
Everything seems to be of low quality,
Locals seem disinterested in learning from other cultures.
Locals prefer to sit in cafes all day, they DRIVE to that cafe even though its a 2 minute walk.
They drive instead of walking, so the whole street will see their BMW.
Perhaps this is the influence left by Enver Hoxha. 
Avoid this place if you can, 
Macedonia , Bulgaria, Serbia or Montenegro next door are just as affordable.

Beautiful, joyful and surprisingly modern city. People are extremely friendly. There are nice cafes and restaurants throughout the city, serving a unique combination of Turkish, Greek and Italian cuisine. Spectacular modern architecture and urban planning. Amazing value for money.
Forget about Tirana, go to the coast! Sarandë and Ksamil are the best places in Albania, if you’re in doubt just google it :)

I really like this city. Great place for food, a lot of cafe's and relatively easy to reach. Growing startup ecosystem, a few nice coworking spaces, you can walk everywhere and housing is still very affordable compared to western europe

Very costly. 
The salaries are ridiculous. 
The air is terrible. 
People are really friendly. 
Corruption is a high level. 
Political situation is unrest all the time.

Brilliant, vibrant city in a beautiful country.

I've lived in the balkans for a few years, and I'm not sure I've ever met friendlier people.
tirana.description:
Tirana is a lively city that often surprises visitors with its special character. Located in Albania, this city is known for being inexpensive, with affordable Airbnbs and tasty meals that cost about a third of what you would pay in Germany. The city center is easy to walk around, allowing you to explore its parks and busy streets with friendly locals.

However, Tirana has its own unique features. While there are interesting places like the Bunk’art museums that focus on Albania's communist past, some people find the cultural scene a bit limited. Public transportation can be difficult, with heavy traffic making walking a bit of a challenge. Also, be careful with public toilets, as they are not very clean!

While visiting, consider staying in the Blloku neighborhood for its lively café scene and nightlife. Locals are usually friendly, but they can be a bit loud when they are with each other. Spring or autumn are good times for pleasant weather. So, pack your bags and get ready to enjoy the warm welcome and unexpectedly modern feel of Tirana!
tirana.description_kor:
티라나는 활기 넘치는 도시로, 그 특별한 개성으로 많은 방문객들을 놀라게 합니다. 알바니아에 위치한 이 도시는 저렴한 비용으로 유명하며, 에어비앤비와 맛있는 음식 가격이 독일에서 지불해야 하는 비용의 약 3분의 1에 불과합니다. 도심은 걷기 편리해서, 친근한 현지인들과 함께 공원과 분주한 거리들을 탐험할 수 있습니다.

하지만 티라나에는 독특한 매력이 있습니다. 알바니아의 공산주의 과거를 집중적으로 다룬 Bunk’art 박물관 같은 흥미로운 명소가 있지만, 일부 사람들은 문화적 분위기가 다소 제한적이라고 느낄 수도 있습니다. 대중교통 이용이 어렵고, 교통량이 많아 걷는 것이 다소 힘들기도 합니다. 또한 public 화장실이 깨끗하지 않으니 주의가 필요합니다!

방문하는 동안 활기찬 카페 문화와 밤문화를 만끽하고 싶다면 블로쿠(Blloku) 지역에 머무르는 것을 추천합니다. 현지인들은 보통 친절하지만, 가끔 함께할 때는 조금 시끄러울 수도 있습니다. 봄이나 가을의 날씨는 정말 쾌적하니, 짐을 챙겨 따뜻한 환영과 예상치 못한 현대적인 매력을 품고 있는 티라나를 즐길 준비를 해보세요!

reviews: Good city to live in, welcoming to foreigners. Lived here for decades and always felt welcome by the people. Cost of living is low, only negative thing is that it is relarively new, with no real historic areas, and there isn’t as much to do as there is in other larger cities.
torreon.description:
Torreón is a friendly city in Mexico where you can feel at home quickly, especially if you are new. The locals are warm, making it easy to settle in, and many people enjoy living here for years. One of the main advantages is the low cost of living, allowing you to have a comfortable life without spending too much money.

However, it is important to know that Torreón is a relatively new city, so there are not many historical sites to visit. While it may not have as many attractions as larger cities, it still has a simple charm. You can enjoy a slower pace of life, which is nice for relaxed weekends.

Getting around can be a bit difficult, as public transportation is not very good, so having a car could be useful. Overall, Torreón has a friendly community feel, making it a good choice for those who want a welcoming place to live. Just keep in mind, there may not be many activities, but the people here make the experience enjoyable!
torreon.description_kor:
토레온은 멕시코의 아늑한 도시로, 특히 새로 오는 이들에게 금세 편안한 집처럼 느껴질 수 있는 곳입니다. 현지 주민들이 따뜻하게 맞이해 주기 때문에 쉽게 정착할 수 있고, 많은 사람들이 수년 동안 이곳에서 즐거운 시간을 보내고 있습니다. 주요 장점 중 하나는 낮은 생활비로, 많은 돈을 쓰지 않고도 쾌적한 생활을 할 수 있다는 점입니다.

하지만 토레온은 비교적 새로운 도시라서 역사적인 명소는 그리 많지 않다는 점을 알아두는 것이 좋습니다. 큰 도시들에 비해 관광지가 적을 수 있지만, 여전히 소소한 매력이 있습니다. 여유로운 주말을 보내며 느긋한 삶의 속도를 즐길 수 있습니다.

대중교통이 그리 발달하지 않아 이동이 다소 불편할 수 있으니, 차를 갖고 있는 것이 좋습니다. 전반적으로 토레온은 따뜻한 공동체 감각이 있어 편안한 환경에서 살고 싶어하는 사람들에게 훌륭한 선택이 될 수 있습니다. 활동이 많지는 않겠지만, 이곳 사람들과의 소중한 경험을 잊지 마세요!

reviews: Renting a flat as a freelancer here is incredibly difficult. The city isn't small but there's not enough to do in my opinion apart from drinking and eating. Locals mostly keep to themselves and don't mix much. Not enough nomadlisters. The co-working space here is alright (Harry Cow is €20 per day) but when it gets busy with 4-5 people having meetings and generally not being mindful of others, it's headache inducing. A lot of homeless weirdos with dogs asking for change who will insult you if you don't give them something (just ignore them). Bad behavior from cyclists and motorists towards pedestrians in the city centre. I've not felt unsafe in the city at night but I have to remain situationally aware when crossing paths with the usual weirdos you encounter. If you are already in a group or joining one here, you'll probably have fun. As a solo, I don't recommend staying here more than 2-3 weeks, you'll get bored.

Honestly, was a bit dissapointed about the number of things that you cannot do there or do in the small old part of it. Seems quite juvenile + lots of students and it is the main factory of AIRBUS planes.

Toulouse is a nice, balanced city that you'll enjoy live in for a while. Still, the limited size might bore out people who enjoy the never ending animation of big cities. The city is also a good base to explore the region with the Pyrénées in the south and the Cathar castles / Carcassonne in the east for example.
toulouse.description:
Toulouse is a city known for its history and culture, but it also has some unique features. Located in southwestern France, this place has good food and a relaxed atmosphere. While local people are usually friendly, many prefer to stay with their own groups, so it might take some time to feel comfortable if you're new.

Finding an apartment can be a bit difficult, especially for freelancers, and using public transport can be a challenge since it is not as extensive as in bigger cities. However, if you like a slower pace of life and don't mind some unusual experiences, you will find interest in Toulouse's old streets.

The city is a good starting point for adventures, such as visiting the Pyrénées or the famous Carcassonne. But if you are traveling alone, it might not be the most exciting place for a long stay—two to three weeks is enough to enjoy it without getting bored. Overall, Toulouse has a mix of experiences, but it is better to come ready and with a group if you're looking for a fun time!
toulouse.description_kor:
툴루즈는 역사와 문화로 유명한 도시일 뿐만 아니라 독특한 매력을 지니고 있습니다. 남서부 프랑스에 자리 잡은 이곳은 맛있는 음식과 아늑한 분위기로 잘 알려져 있습니다. 현지 사람들은 대체로 친절하지만, 많은 이들이 자신의 친구들이나 가족과 함께 있는 것을 선호하기 때문에 새로 이곳에 온 사람은 편안함을 느끼기까지 시간이 걸릴 수 있습니다.

아파트를 구하는 일은 다소 힘들 수 있으며, 특히 프리랜서인 경우에는 더 그렇습니다. 대중교통도 대도시에 비해 제한적이어서 이용하기에는 어려움이 있을 수 있습니다. 하지만 여유로운 라이프스타일을 즐기고 특별한 경험을 하는 것을 좋아한다면, 툴루즈의 고풍스러운 거리에서 흥미로운 발견을 할 수 있을 것입니다.

툴루즈는 피레네 산맥이나 유명한 카르카손을 방문하는 훌륭한 기점이 됩니다. 하지만 혼자 여행하는 경우에는 장기간 머물기에는 재미가 떨어질 수 있습니다. 지루하지 않게 즐기려면 2~3주 정도면 충분합니다. 전반적으로 툴루즈는 다양한 경험을 제공하지만, 재미있는 시간을 보내고 싶다면 준비를 잘 하고 친구들과 함께 오는 것이 좋습니다!

reviews: I agree with one of the previous reviews. Tucson is a great place for outdoor activities, hiking, rock climbing, etc. Yes it's hot in the summer, but monsoon rains are magnificent when they come. The cost of living is lower than a lot of other areas in the country, and as a woman I've never felt particularly unsafe.

I’m not sure about how accurate nomadslist really is. When I search for locations in the USA with good hiking what comes up first? Atlanta. Second is NYC. Huh? 
I think Tucson is a great city for the nomad who likes a bit of quiet. It’s small enough to be cozy but big enough that you can find everything you need. Want to party non stop and socialize with other nomads? Probably not your number one choice. Want good weather most of the year and lower cost of living? Love hiking, nature and being outdoors? This is a great location. Summer is HOT. Avoid. Otherwise it’s mostly sunny and dry. If you have a car and like road trips on your time off you can go north to the Grand Canyon and on to Utah or east to New Mexico. California and Mexico are short drives away too. 
There’s some great food especially Mexican food and a few really fun breweries. There are bike paths around town and tons of trails for hiking.
Actually ignore all I said. I like having Tucson to myself! Lots of silver haired snowbirds know about it but the younger nomads haven’t really figured it out yet.

IMO Tucson is a great nomad city! Cost of living is insanely low even to live downtown, so assuming you're being paid by a company based elsewhere your money will go a lot further in Tucson. Recently three new coworking spaces opened downtown, which has been cool to see, as it feels like the city is starting to become supportive of all the remote workers living here. Plus it's an outdoors paradise so there's that!

I'm not sure where all the low ratings on "fun" and "nightlife" are coming from: there is tons to do here wrt outdoors AND cultural activities, and it's much easier to get to it than in a larger city.

If you are carfree, public transit is available and reliable, as are bikeshares. Cabs are pricey, and I don't have a clue about Uber because I don't use it. 

Stay on the west side if you can, near the mountains.

Unless you are here in summer (mid-May through end of Sep) when temps are 100F/38C, this city is one of the best in the US IMO. It is easy to get around without a car if you live near the downtown (and there is a cheap bike share available). Internet is fast, nightlife is great and outdoor activities (hiking in mountains, road/mountain biking) are abundant. Living outside of downtown (outside of the neighborhoods labeled as South Tucson and Bario Viejo on the map) can turn into dull urban sprawl but the housing is cheaper there. The Scores indicate bad scores for fun & nightlife--the only way this is true if you are outside of downtown.
Tucson is great! That is all.
tucson.description:
Tucson, Arizona, is a great place for anyone who enjoys the outdoors. It has good hiking trails and rock climbing areas, making it great for adventure lovers. Yes, summer can be very hot, but the monsoon rains are an interesting sight. Many locals enjoy the relaxed feel of this city, where the cost of living is low, allowing you to save money—especially if you are working from home.

While Tucson may not have a busy nightlife, it has its own appeal with tasty Mexican food and some lively breweries. It is also fairly safe, making it a comfortable place for everyone, including women alone. The public transport system works well, especially if you are near downtown, where new coworking spaces are being created, making it better for those working remotely.

For the best experience, consider staying on the west side near the mountains, and be ready for the summer heat. If you want a quiet city full of nature and chances for exploration, Tucson is worth a visit!
tucson.description_kor:
투산, 아리조나주는 야외활동을 즐기는 사람들에게 정말 훌륭한 장소입니다. 다양한 하이킹 코스와 암벽 등반 지역이 있어 모험을 좋아하는 이들에게 특히 좋습니다. 여름에는 기온이 매우 높지만, 몬순이 내려주면 멋진 풍경이 펼쳐집니다. 많은 현지 주민들은 이 도시의 저렴한 생활비와 느긋한 분위기를 즐기며, 특히 재택근무를 하는 경우 더 많은 비용을 절약할 수 있습니다.

투산은 바쁜 밤문화가 없을 수도 있지만, 맛있는 멕시코 음식과 활기찬 양조장들이 있어서 그 나름의 매력이 있습니다. 또한 안전한 편이라 혼자 다니는 여성들에게도 안심할 수 있는 곳입니다. 대중교통 시스템도 잘 갖춰져 있어, 특히 도심 근처에서는 새로운 공동 작업 공간이 생겨나면서 원격 근무자들에게 더 좋은 환경을 제공하고 있습니다.

최고의 경험을 원하신다면, 산 근처의 서쪽 지역에 머물면서 여름의 더위에 대비하는 것이 좋습니다. 자연과 탐험의 기회가 가득한 조용한 도시를 찾고 계신다면, 투산은 꼭 방문해볼 가치가 있는 곳입니다!

reviews: Good food and rich history. You have good options using the Louage if you want to travel cheap in the country. Was there 1 week, and would probably not consider living there. A bit too much trash, restaurants sometimes have double or tripple price for "white folks", but it is definently worth a visit.

Growing city, very beautiful scenery in Sidi Bousaid and the Medina. Great night life in Gamarth with a lot of new co-working spaces opening up in the "Banlieu Nord" and "Lac de Tunis" areas. Bolt is available for transportation and taxis are very affordable. A lot of italian/Tunisian food options.
tunis.description:
Tunis is a busy city that attracts visitors with its history and tasty food. If you like to explore, you’ll enjoy walking through the streets of the Medina and the beauty of Sidi Bousaid. Don’t miss the nightlife in Gamarth, where new co-working spaces and places to visit are opening, making it an interesting area for both locals and visitors.

Getting around is easy with affordable taxis and services like Bolt, and if you want to save money while traveling in the country, the Louage is a cheap option. While many people like the city's food—especially the Italian and Tunisian mix—some visitors mention that prices can be very different, especially for tourists.

However, it's worth seeing despite some issues like litter in some areas and a language barrier. For a true experience of Tunis, join in the culture, enjoy the local customs, and enjoy the tasty food. Just keep an eye on prices, and it’s a city you should definitely visit!
tunis.description_kor:
투니스는 풍부한 역사와 맛있는 음식으로 방문객들을 사로잡는 활기찬 도시입니다. 새로운 것을 탐험하는 데 관심이 있다면, 메디나의 골목길을 걷거나 시디 부사이드의 아름다움을 만끽하는 걸 추천합니다. 그리고 가마르트의 밤문화는 새로운 공동 작업 공간과 방문할 장소들이 생겨나고 있어, 현지인과 관광객 모두에게 흥미로운 경험을 제공합니다.

저렴한 택시와 볼트(Bolt)와 같은 서비스 덕분에 이동이 편리하며, 국외 여행 시 비용을 절약하려면 로와지(Louage)가 좋은 선택입니다. 많은 사람들이 이 도시의 음식을 사랑하지만, 특히 이탈리안과 튀니지 음식의 조화가 매력적입니다. 그러나 관광객에 따라 가격 차이가 있을 수 있으니 유의해야 합니다.

일부 지역에서는 쓰레기 문제와 언어 장벽 같은 점들이 있지만, 그럼에도 불구하고 볼 만한 가치가 충분합니다. 진정한 튀니스의 매력을 느끼고 싶다면 문화에 참여하고, 지역의 관습을 경험하며, 맛있는 음식을 즐겨보세요. 가격에 조금만 신경 쓴다면, 이곳은 반드시 방문해야 할 도시입니다!

reviews:
Just spent three nights here. Tulum is a triangle: the ruins, the zona hotelera, and Tulum Pueblo. Zona Hotelera is expensive and far from services. Tulum Pueblo is ugly, noisy, and full of development. A boom town where everyone seems out to fleece the gringo. It's also an ecological disaster. Watch the Dark Side of Tulum. And think twice before swimming in some of the local cenotes: they're full of E Coli. 
The public beach in winter was nice. But this is a shitty place to work from, unless you want to drop a lot of money, and even then, it's a party atmosphere.

Seaweed - Summer is seaweed season and it stinks which ruins the awesome beaches. Town center is very hip and trendy now and prices are going up. My tip, winter is best, the weather in summer is scorching. Oh, and find a place with AC, you'll need it

Stayed for 5 days in Tulum in March 2023, here are a few things to consider.

-The Pros are: there a ton of very solid accommodations for ~$50 per night on a short term basis (1BR apartment, pool, etc.). You can get it down even further with a longer term commitment. It feels like there is a growing nomad community, but it's more of NYC/LA types than down to earth vagabonds. There are a bunch of great restaurants that cater to the health conscious and gyms to check out. There are some very posh NYC/LA type bars and clubs with good DJs if that's your thing.

-The Cons: the taxis are THE MOST EXPENSIVE IN THE WORLD-they banded together to chase out all competition (no Uber) and each ride is $15-$40. You have to get a scooter or other mode of transportation in order to get around comfortably unless you live right in the middle of everything. The people that go to Tulum are heavily into Drugs and Alcohol (a plus for some but not for me) and very superficial. The beaches are difficult to get to and are often swamped with seaweed. It feels dangerous from a traffic perspective trying to get around (horrible roads and crazy drivers). Overall, it is expensive for Mexico and most prices are comparable to the US.

-Overall, Tulum is great for some people but wasn't a fit for me long term. Although many settle there as nomads, I'd personally only go back on a short term basis to stay at Tulum Beach if I was in a party mode. If you want a LA/NYC feel in Mexico and are into partying/drugs/alcohol, Tulum could be a good fit for you

Been there for a day as a day-trip from Cancun. It has some serious Canggu vibes, not gonna lie. Is a great spot to hang out for a couple of days, enjoy some parties and nice food. However you should bring some money as everything is tailored towards American tourists. 
Pros:
- many food options
- nice, chill vibe
- obviously greata weather
- nice beaches 
- great archaelogical zone

Cons:
- traffic is bad
- super expensive 
- touristy

Everything is for American tourists. Prices are sometimes even higher than in the US. Beach is beautiful, there's nothing to do downtown. Cenotes, archaeological zone are cool, worth a visit. Covid is like it doesn't exist. Internet was cool in Selina. Cool to stay for a couple of nights of chilling, but not for living.

This place is a lot of fun, has beautiful beaches, and gives easy access to amazing cavern diving. That said I wouldn't recommend it, overall. You have two parts, centro and hotel zone. Hotel zone is essentially as if Bali existed in the US, but inexplicably is somehow in Mexico. Roughly 3-4x the price of Bali and the rest of Mexico, almost no real mexican food (the best reason to go to Mexico) in the hotel zone, a bunch of beach hipsters (Tuluminati), relatively terrible internet (some 10Mbps+ spots tho), and "eco" branding everywhere yet power provided by huge, loud generators. Tulum centro actually has some solid restaurants and gives you a bit of the nature vibe mixed in with a small mexican town, but unfortunately no beach. If you're looking for a month or longer stay in the mexican caribbean, Playa del Carmen is the far more livable city and it's only like 45mins by car, so you can still do the nature stuff very easily without having to deal with actual Tulum.

Coming from Bali, Tulum is probably 7 years behind. Wifi and cell signal isn't great everywhere. Not many co-working spaces. Similar prices to what you would find in USA. Covid restrictions don't really exisit.

Tulum is loaded with cenotes for exploring and cooling off, beautiful and unique! Find local Maya and listen to their dialect. Learn a few words in Maya, they love to share it! The only beachfront Mayan Ruins are here! Iguanas galore and photo opps! Get a guide, it's worth the history lesson, wear your suit under clothes for a refreshing swim afterwards. Most hotels offer beach clubs, low cost or cost of lunch/drinks, plus they have free wi-fi. Happy hours 2/1 with live music and the recently opened museum are diverse options. In town, restaurants abound and the food is a gastronomic delight! Local taco stops are the best value for a full stomach , happy tastebuds and a light wallet. Fresh sugar cane squeezed by a hank-cranked press offers a variety of Mojitos with live variety shows and music! Other night life, that I love, is watching sea turtles lay their eggs! Fun activities near by are: numerous parks with zip-lines, animal sanctuaries, cultural shows, snorkeling, scuba diving, fishing..... I would describe Tulum as bohemian / hippie/ ish, more relaxed than resorts. It has changed quickly in the last few years to accommodate not only the backpacker but the upscale tourist as well. It's a small but growing community with friendly people and a safe environment.

Most of the cafes do not have aircons, so during summer time you won't be able to work here comfortably. Better rent a place or use one of the coworking spaces listed here (didn't check them myself yet). 

Make sure to check the seaweed situation in Tulum before coming here. Seaweed is covering all of the shore in the moment :( ruined my beach experience for the whole trip. 

Check Central Park condo residence. It's kind of pricey, but has good internet connection, restaurant, gym.. everything you'll need to stay productive and still enjoying your time here. 

I wouldn't trust 4sq ratings for restaurants and other venues. Better ask locals.
tulum.description:
Tulum has nice beaches, interesting culture, and a relaxed atmosphere, but there are some things to consider. The archaeological ruins and cenotes attract many visitors, but be careful about swimming in some local areas for safety reasons. Tulum has two sides: the Zona Hotelera has many luxury places but often lacks local character, while Tulum Pueblo feels more genuine but can be noisy and busy with new development.

Public transportation is not great; taxis can be expensive, and a scooter may help you get around. The city has a lively party scene, which some people enjoy but might be overwhelming for those looking for a quiet trip. The cost of living is quite high, often similar to prices in the U.S.

Winter is usually the best time to visit. Make sure to try the local food—taco shops offer delicious meals at good prices. Also, learn a few Maya phrases; locals will appreciate it! Lastly, check the seaweed situation before going to the beach for a better experience.
tulum.description_kor:
튤룸은 아름다운 해변과 풍부한 문화, 한가로운 분위기를 가진 곳입니다. 하지만 몇 가지 유의할 점이 있습니다. 고고학 유적지와 세노테는 많은 방문객들에게 인기를 끌지만, 안전상의 이유로 일부 지역에서는 수영을 할 때 주의가 필요합니다. 튤룸은 크게 두 가지 모습이 있는데, 조나 호텔레라는 고급 호텔이 많지만 현지의 매력이 부족할 때가 많고, 반면 튤룸 푸에블로는 더 진정한 느낌을 주지만 새로운 개발로 인해 번잡하고 시끄러울 수 있습니다.

대중교통이 그리 편리하지 않고, 택시 요금이 비쌀 수 있어 스쿠터를 이용하는 것이 이동에 더욱 편리할 수 있습니다. 이곳은 활기찬 파티 문화가 발달해 있어 이를 즐기는 사람에게는 좋은 지역이지만, 조용한 여행을 원하는 사람에게는 다소 압도적일 수 있습니다. 생활비 또한 꽤 높아 미국의 가격과 비슷한 경우가 많습니다.

겨울철이 보통 방문하기에 가장 좋은 시기로 여겨집니다. 현지 음식을 꼭 맛보세요. 타코 가게에서 훌륭한 가격에 맛있는 음식을 즐길 수 있습니다. 또한 몇 가지 마야어 구문을 배워보면 현지인들이 매우 반가워할 것입니다! 마지막으로 해변에 가기 전에는 해조류 상황을 체크하는 것도 좋은 경험을 위해서 잊지 마세요.

reviews: Beautiful city and well worth a weekend trip. Pretty safe in most areas, though you should keep an eye on your belongings at the Porta Palazzo market. One thing worth noting is that the air quality can be quite bad, and the drivers are also quite erratic. Probably wouldn't live in Turin long-term, but it's worth a visit for sure.

Great city if you come here as a tourist
But after one month here it has not been my best experience 
The city is dirty and peoples don't talk great english 
but defenitively some nice place to visit like the egyptian museum or the museum of cinema and also the muntain are not that far away.
For thr price it's not the best blace to go unless you absolutely want to learn italian.
And gosh try not to be run over by cars there.
One of the best Italian pearls I have seen in this classy country. Fully recommend for it's great mountain scenery saw from above the city. Better city than Milan I guess.
turin.description:
Turin is a nice place in Italy, good for a weekend trip. You will find small streets, interesting history, and beautiful mountain views to explore. The Egyptian Museum and the Museum of Cinema are important places to visit that show the city's culture.

While the city looks nice, be aware of a few issues. The air quality can be poor, and driving here can be challenging—be careful of the drivers and keep an eye on your things, especially at the Porta Palazzo market.

Overall, it's a safe city, but English is not spoken by many people, which might be difficult. If you're thinking about staying longer, some people find it a little dirty and expensive unless you really want to learn Italian.

Enjoy the local atmosphere, and don’t forget to see the beautiful scenery. The mountain views from the city are truly special!
turin.description_kor:
투린은 이탈리아에 있는 매력적인 도시로 주말 여행지로 제격입니다. 아기자기한 거리와 흥미로운 역사, 그리고 탐험할 수 있는 아름다운 산々의 경치를 만날 수 있습니다. 이집트 박물관과 영화 박물관은 도시의 문화적 매력을 잘 보여주는 필수 방문 코스입니다.

도시가 아름답긴 하지만 몇 가지 유의할 점도 있습니다. 공기 질이 좋지 않을 수 있고, 이곳에서 운전하는 것은 다소 도전적일 수 있습니다. 운전할 때는 조심하고, 특히 포르타 팔라초 시장에서 물건을 잘 챙기는 것이 중요합니다.

전반적으로 비교적 안전한 도시이지만, 많은 사람들이 영어를 사용하지 않기 때문에 의사소통이 어려울 수 있습니다. 좀 더 오랫동안 머물려고 한다면, 여기가 조금 더럽고 비싸다고 느낄 수도 있는데, 이는 이탈리아어를 배우고 싶지 않으신 분들에게 특히 해당됩니다.

현지 분위기를 만끽하고 멋진 경치를 즐기는 것을 잊지 마세요. 도시에 있는 산들의 모습은 정말 특별하답니다!

reviews: Maybe not all the ratings are true , but dont forget you area local and view things differently. people coming from the west will view most of russian cities like that because they compare it to standards back at home
As a local I can't agree with the most of the ratings. I'm curious who voted like that
ufa.description:
Ufa, the capital of Bashkortostan, has a special quality that is best appreciated by those who live there. Locals often feel that visitors can be too critical, possibly because they compare it to Western cities. However, there is a rich culture and active community here that many people enjoy.

The cost of living in the city is low, making it a good place to live or visit without spending too much. Public transportation is not as extensive as in larger cities, but it works, so getting around is easy enough. Safety is generally good, with friendly locals who are willing to help.

Be sure to visit the Ufa Arena and try traditional Bashkir dishes at local restaurants. The city’s parks and the Belaya River are also nice places to explore. Just remember that language can be a challenge, as not everyone speaks English well.

For visitors, taking a walk through the historic areas will show you the city’s unique character. As with any travel, stay open-minded and be ready to create memories—Ufa has many things to offer!
ufa.description_kor:
우파, 바시코르토스탄의 수도는 그곳에 사는 사람들만이 진정으로 느낄 수 있는 독특한 매력을 지니고 있습니다. 현지인들은 방문객들이 종종 너무 비판적이라고 느끼는 경우가 많아, 이는 아마 그들이 우파를 서구의 도시와 비교하기 때문일 것입니다. 하지만 이곳에는 많은 사람들이 즐길 수 있는 풍부한 문화와 활발한 커뮤니티가 존재합니다.

이 도시의 생활비는 저렴해서 많은 비용을 들이지 않고도 살거나 방문하기 좋은 곳입니다. 대중교통은 대도시에 비해 다소 제한적이지만, 실용적으로 잘 운영되어 이동하기 어려움이 없습니다. 안전한 편이며, 도움을 주려는 친절한 현지인들도 많이 있습니다.

우파 아레나를 방문하고 현지 레스토랑에서 전통 바시크 요리를 꼭 맛보세요. 또한, 도시의 공원과 벨라야 강은 탐험하기 좋은 아름다운 장소입니다. 다만, 영어를 잘 하는 사람이 많지 않기 때문에 언어가 어려울 수 있다는 점을 기억해 주세요.

방문객들에게는 역사적인 지역을 걷는 것이 이 도시의 특별한 매력을 느낄 수 있는 좋은 기회가 될 것입니다. 여행을 떠날 때와 같이 열린 마음을 유지하고 기억에 남을 순간들을 만들 준비를 하세요—우파는 여러분에게 많은 것을 선사할 것입니다!

reviews: Oh Vadodara (Or Baroda if you have an old map)... I was there September 8-14, 2019. A friendly and beautiful city, but it helps to have a guide. I did a hotel stay as the prices were a tiny percentage of the same accomodation in Mumbai. Internet was good. Tunnel worked here (but that may just have been my access point). There are internet cafes (Cafe Coffee is one)... but there is also Starbucks. Prices at restaurants are lower than other spots I visited in India. I did not do the street food here, but thats just me. By nature this is a very vegetarian region of India, so be prepared... however, they sure can cook, so you may not miss it. I came in by train from Mumbai, but the airport has a fancy new (and empty) terminal. Get around by UBER or Auto (tuk-tuk), but you need cash for the latter. There was flooding in August, the month before I arrived, but all was well by early September... keep an eye on the monsoon forecast. The historic sites are stunning, the mosaic tile work, etc at the palaces... and please realize that they were only built around 1900 (yes that palace photo above in Nomadlist is a building built in 1900 by a British architect, not 500 or 1000 years earlier... but it IS gorgeous in person). I will return to Vadodara again... but I'll give you a tip- pronounce it as Baroda and you will be fine.
vadodara.description:
Vadodara, also known as Baroda by some locals, is a nice place where modern life combines with history. Visitors talk about the friendliness of the people and the old palaces that have nice tile work. It is a good choice for anyone who likes learning about culture without spending too much money—restaurants here offer good meals at lower prices compared to bigger cities like Mumbai.

Getting around is simple; you can use Uber or take an auto-rickshaw, but remember to have some cash for the auto-rickshaw. While the city mainly has vegetarian food, the local dishes are enjoyable. You might want to avoid street food if you are careful, but the restaurant options will satisfy you.

On the other hand, it is important to be aware of the monsoon season as flooding can occur. English may not be common, so having a guide can help your visit. Overall, if you are ready to enjoy a mix of culture, good food, and interesting buildings, Vadodara will be a great place for you!
vadodara.description_kor:
바도다는 현대적인 삶과 역사가 조화를 이루는 멋진 장소입니다. 방문객들은 이곳의 친절한 사람들과 아름다운 타일 장식이 있는 오래된 궁전에 대해 자주 이야기합니다. 문화에 관심이 있으시다면, 대도시인 뭄바이보다 저렴한 가격에 맛있는 음식을 즐길 수 있는 식당들이 많은 바도다는 훌륭한 선택입니다.

이곳에서는 이동이 정말 쉽습니다. 우버를 이용하거나 오토리크샤를 타면 됩니다. 다만, 오토리크샤를 탈 때는 꼭 현금을 준비하세요. 이 도시는 주로 채식 위주의 음식을 제공하지만, 지역 음식도 맛있답니다. 조금 조심스럽게 접근한다면 길거리 음식은 피하는 것이 좋고, 식당 선택지는 꽤 괜찮습니다.

또한, 우기가 되면 홍수가 발생할 가능성이 있다는 점을 유념해야 합니다. 영어가 잘 통하지 않을 수 있으니 가이드를 활용하는 것도 좋은 방법입니다. 전반적으로 문화, 훌륭한 음식, 흥미로운 건축물의 조화를 즐기고 싶다면, 바도다는 여러분에게 정말 좋은 장소가 될 것입니다!

reviews: Honestly, it's pretty awful if you're trying to work. Only good for a one or two day tour with some beautiful street art and a couple museums. But I showed up and it really smells, is incredibly dirty, locals tell me it's dangerous and the wi-fi consistently cuts out. I was panning to stay in the area 3 days and instead leaving the day I arrived.
valparaiso.description:
Valparaíso is a unique city that leaves a strong impression. It is known for its street art and lively culture, attracting visitors with its artistic atmosphere, museums, and hilly streets that give nice ocean views. You can explore the narrow alleys and enjoy what this city has to offer.

However, it is not always perfect. Some visitors say it can be disappointing if you plan to stay longer. Issues like cleanliness and safety can be problems, and the city is not always the best for working remotely, especially with unreliable Wi-Fi. Some locals may also share safety concerns, so it is important to stay alert.

If you are just visiting for a day or two, be sure to check out the street art and consider taking a funicular for great views. Just bring your essential items, stick to familiar areas, and enjoy Valparaíso's unique character while being aware of your surroundings!
valparaiso.description_kor:
발파라이소(Valparaíso)는 강한 인상을 남기는 독특한 도시입니다. 이 도시는 거리 예술과 생동감 넘치는 문화로 유명하며, 예술적인 분위기, 다양한 박물관, 그리고 아름다운 바다 전망을 자랑하는 경사진 거리가 방문객들을 매료시킵니다. 좁은 골목을 탐험하며 이 도시가 주는 매력을 만끽해보세요.

그러나 항상 완벽하기만 한 것은 아닙니다. 몇몇 방문객들은 장기 체류를 계획할 경우 실망할 수도 있다고 언급합니다. 청결과 안전 문제는 염려스러운 부분이 될 수 있으며, 특히 불안정한 Wi-Fi로 인해 원격 근무를 하기에는 적합한 환경이 아닐 수도 있습니다. 일부 지역 주민들도 안전에 대한 우려를 나타내므로 항상 경계를 잊지 않는 것이 중요합니다.

하루나 이틀 동안 방문할 계획이라면, 꼭 거리 예술을 감상하고 아름다운 전망을 위해 케이블카를 타는 것을 고려해보세요. 필수적인 물품만 챙겨 익숙한 지역에서 머물며 발파라이소의 독특한 매력을 즐기되, 주변에 주의하는 것도 잊지 마세요!

reviews: Varna is a nice city. Very eastern block style mostly, but the center has a nice promenade and the beach area is pretty good. I spent there about three weeks in September and the weather was great.

great city. lovely beach, bars, people are nice, food is amazing.
there is no more "Beehive" co working space though.

I spent two months in Varna (mid-September to mid-November) and loved it! Mild weather, very affordable, great expats community and a lot of things going on. Next time, I would like to visit it in the spring!
From July to September one of the best Citys in Europe for me.

I spent 11 days here. I like it a lot. Beaches, affordable, interesting architecture. Cool place and I could spend a summer here easily if I had a friend. Though, if you're single it wouldn't be hard to make one, as people here are amazing looking. 

I like the park a lot, and it has some interesting museums. Not a big hipster scene if that's your thing. More tourists, mostly from Bulgaria, Russia and Turkey. 

Nightlife is... okay. Mostly mafia and gypsy bars. But I do love this one bar called Cubo, on the beach. Great place. Very reasonable prices. Cheap actually. 
Nice place that needs more hype. 

I don't like that there's no ride hailing apps, and Google maps doesn't tell bus schedules. So transportation sucks. But most stuff is walking distance or a short bus ride, once you figure it out.

The data on Varna here is hilarious. Nomad costs 1.800 $? When the local live on 400$? The rent cost here 300 $ for a good apartment in the center. Then add 10 $ a day for food. You'll end up at 600-700 $. Add additional expenses for partying.
The only downside is the cold weather in january and february. Other than that it's a pretty great place. Better than Sofia, any day.
Varna is a nice city, specially during spring and summer, great beaches and nightlife on high season
varna.description:
Varna is a nice city on the Black Sea coast that shows off its attractions. Walking along the promenade, you can see good views of the beach while enjoying the lively atmosphere filled with friendly people and good food.
